headline: Money, Not Vietnam, Key Issue At a Small College in Nebraska
lead_paragraph: WAHOO, Neb., May 15—The unease at John F. Kennedy College is different.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: GOLDBERG BACKS WAGE‐PRICE CURB
lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Goldberg, a candi date for the Democratic nom ination for Governor, declared yesterday that this country faced a “galloping” recession unless it imposed selective wage, price and credit controls and developed a job program for the unemployed.
author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: RELIGIOUS LEADERS PLAN PEACE DRIVE
lead_paragraph: Sixty Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders have announced the convening of an “emergency religious convocation” in Wash ington this week to mobilize support to end the war in Indo china.

headline: Capital Knee Deep In Mail on Kent and Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On an in side corridor of the ground floor of the Executive Office Build ing, next to the White House, there is a big room awash with mail. Two hundred and fifty thousand letters were backed up there the other day, letters to the President of the United States on the issues of Cam bodia and Kent. At least an other 100,000 already had been processed, and about 75,000 more were in the pipeline.

headline: Cambodian Drive Called Success by U. S. Commanders
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 23—Nearly a month after American and South Vietnamese troops began attacking Commu nist sanctuaries inside Cam bodia, allied commanders are describibg the campaign as an outstanding military success.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: 7 SENATORS URGE PLANES FOR ISRAEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23— Seven leading Senate opponents of the war in Indochina assured the Nixon Administration today of their support for a policy of American firmness against the “ominous and provocative” Soviet thrust against Israel.
author: By Irving Spiegel Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD ADVOCATES RELIGIOUS VALUES
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 23—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told 500 Presbyterians this morning that Christianity demanded that men in public office be “dual servants of both God and of the people.”
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Brandeis Building Is Center for Student Strike Data
lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — In the montage of student activism that papers the walls of a small building on the green, sloping campus of Brandeis University, the photograph of a dark‐haired girl screamng above the body of a Kent State student is taped next to a computer‐arawing or Snoopy, the insouciant beagle.
author: By Linda Charlton Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR YOUTHS IMPRESS SENATOR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 — Senator William B. Spong Jr. sat patiently at the head of a long table the other day as stu dents poured into the small conference room of the Senate Agriculture Committee.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: SIHANOUK VIEWED AS ASSET FOR MAO
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23—A highly profitable political part nership appears to have bloomed in Peking over the last two months between Mao Tse‐tung, Chairman of the Chi nese Communist Party, and Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who was ousted as Cambodia's Chief of State last March 18.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Williams Steps Up Opposition to War Policies as Vietnam Becomes a Dominant Issue in Jersey Race
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, May 23—With the war in Vietnam one of the dom inant Issues in New Jersey's Senatorial primary election, Senator Harrison A. Williams, a democrat, has spoken out more and more in opposition to the United States military in volvement in Indochina.
author: By Ronald Sullivan Special to The New York Times

headline: For G.I., It's War as Usual in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: QUANLOI, South Vietnam —Most of the G.I.'s went into Cambodia without say ing anything. Like all the combat assaults they had been on before, when muscles knot, throats dry and stom achs seem to go berserk, this assault—into another coun try—was greeted mostly with silence.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Television
lead_paragraph: IN a time of national divi sion the practice of au tomatically according the President such free tele vision time as he asks clearly needs careful review. Since the President is Commander in Chief of the country's armed forces and the nation's duly elected leader, there is no question of television's obligation to carry his speeches and major deci sions.
author: By Sack Gould

headline: In The Nation: Who Is Saving Whom From What?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice Pres ident Ky, who is South Viet nam's Agnew, has called the statement that South Vietna mese troops would withdraw from Cambodia when Ameri ca's troops did “a silly argu ment of silly people.” This is a harsh way for an ally to speak of President Nixon, who said on May 9 that he “would expect that the South Vietna mese would come out approxi mately at the same time that we do because when we come out, our logistical support and air support will also come out with them.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: 15 Reported Dead at Chup
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 23—Witnesses reported today that five fighter planes of the South Vietnamese Air Force bombed and strafed the rubber processing plant at Chup this morning, leaving it aflame and causing at least 15 deaths among the 550 workers. Eighty persons were said to have been wounded.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Suharto Fears a Widening of War in Indochina
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 — President Suharto has ex pressed concern that if the big powers cannot control the In dochina conflict, it could lead to a third world war.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. POLICY ROUSES AFTRA CONTROVERSY
lead_paragraph: Efforts by the New York local of the American Federa tion of Television and Radio Artists to arrive at o public position on United States in volvement in Indochina have provoked bitter controversy within the union.

headline: China and Russia Argue but Hanoi Runs The Show
lead_paragraph: Moscow and Peking are at each other's throats again in an effort to gain influence in Indo china. These great‐power shout ing matches dominate the head lines; but it is the country they are seeking to influence, North Vietnam, that runs the show in Indochina.

headline: 500 Nurses March to Protest the War
lead_paragraph: Five hundred nurses and nursing students, about two‐ thirds of them in white uni forms, marched from Bryant Park down Fifth Avenue to Union Square yesterday sing ing, “All we are saying is give peace a chance.”
author: By Thomas F. Brady

headline: Vietnamizing Cambodia
lead_paragraph: Saigon's announced determination to keep South Vietnamese troops in Cambodia indefinitely, which has now been publicly sanctioned by Defense Secre tary Laird, is a direct challenge to the Administration's own professed efforts and those of Congress to re establish limits to the Southeast Asian conflict.

headline: Employes' Petition Backs Allen's Antiwar Position
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 — Five hundred employes of the Office of Education have signed petitions supporting Dr. James E. Allen Jr., Commissioner of Education, in his disagreement with the Administration over the Vietnam war.

headline: HOFSTRA STUDENTS AID ARMED FORCES
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, L.I, May 23 (UPI)—Despite opposing view points about the war, students, faculty members and adminis trators at Hofstra University in Hempstead have contributed 275 pints of blood to United States forces in South Vietnam and Cambodia.

headline: Washington: Whither Art Thou, Spiro?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23— Among the few certainties in this, uncertain age is Vice President Spiro Agnew. Some how he vanishes during the week, but almost always he shows up at the weekend some where in Iowa, South Carolina or Texas, shaking his fist at the press and trying to divert every body's attention from the war and the economy to the hairy scoundrels in the universities and the press.
author: By James Reston

headline: 2 War Protesters Vow to Fast Until U.S. Leaves Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23—Two of the gentlest war protesters President Nixon will ever see— if he ever sees them—lay in the shade of a horse chestnut tree today across the street from the White House.
author: By Nan Robertson Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 Democratic Senate Nominees Trade Charges in Their First Debate on Television
lead_paragraph: The four candidates for the Democratic Senate nomination met for the first time yester day in one of the television debates that have become a feature of New York political campaigns, and two of them went on the attack.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: Marine Lieutenant Charged With Murder in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 24 (AP)—A lieutenant in the Marine Corps has been charged with premeditated murder in the death of a Viet namese near Danang on March 28, a marine spokesman re ported today.

headline: 5 NEWSMEN IN WAR DETAINED AND FREED
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24 (AP) — Five newsmen, in cluding a Pulitzer Prize‐winning photographer, were detained by North Vietnamese soldiers in Cambodia this weekend but were quickly released.

headline: LINDSAY SUPPORTS PAY‐PRICE FREEZE TO CURB INFLATION
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay called yester day for a mandatory six‐month freeze on wages and price rises as the first step in bringing in flation under control.
author: By Iver Peterson

headline: Kunstler Barred on Coast
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP)—Glenn Dumke, chancellor of the California state college system, banned today the sched uled appearance Tuesday night of William M. Kunstler at San Jose State College. Mr. Kunst ler was the chief defense law yer of the Chicago 7. In a directive, Mr. Dumke said: “Disorders involving personal Injuries and property damage have occurred following cer tain of Mr. Kunstler's appear ances.” He then barred the lawyer.

headline: As American as Antiwar Dissent
lead_paragraph: The flags waved and the speeches jingoed when the United States embarked on its first armed adventure in Asia. Even before the shooting war began in the Pacific the dis senting war broke out in America.
author: By Herbert Mitgang

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Incursion Scored

headline: Wicker Says Americans Hunger for a Useful Life
lead_paragraph: CARLISLE, Pa., May 24 — Tom Wicker, associate editor of The New York Times, told the graduating class of Dick inson College today that “the deepest hunger in the Amer ican soul today... is for something truly useful to do with one's life.”

headline: Cambodia Foreign Minister Arrives in Saigon for Talks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 25 (Reuters)— Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur of Cambodia arrived here today for talks with South Vietna mese leaders about incursions into his country by South Viet namese and American troops.

headline: Cambodia Denies Spokesman Was Attacking Saigon's Role
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24 (Agence France Presse)— The Government radio today countered a declaration by a military spokesman Thursday that Cambodians would prefer to die rather than “live under Vietnamese domination.”

headline: ROGERS HINTS U.S. WON'T CURB ALLY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24—Sec retary of State William P. Rogers indicated today that the Administration would not op pose continued South Viet namese operations in Cambodia after American forces are pulled out, and he left open the pos sibility that American air sup port would be provided.
author: By Peter Grose Special to The New York Times

headline: PHAN KHAC SUU, 65, SAIGON OFFICIAL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 (AP)—Phan Khac Suu, a political leader, died today after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

headline: Student Group Finds All 4 Democratic Senate Candidates in State Acceptable
lead_paragraph: In the belief that all four candidates would support the goals they seek to achieve, student representatives for the New York Region of the Move ment for a New Congress have not endorsed any of them for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: BIG RUBBER TRACT IN CAMBODIA FALLS TO SAIGON TROOPS
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24—A South Vietnamese task force seized the large rubber plantation of Chup late yester day and witnesses reported to day that the force had confis cated all movable assets and had given the French managers three days to leave.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Potofsky, in Labor Split, Denounces War Policy
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, May, 24— The head of one of the nation's largest trade unions broke to day with the leadership of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and condemned the Vietnam and Cambodian war policies of the Nixon Ad ministration.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Going on Channel 13
lead_paragraph: “News in Perspective,” Na tional Educational Television's weekly topical discussion pro gram, will present an exclusive interview with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam tomorrow night. The program, to be seen here on WNDT, Channel 13, was filmed last Saturday in Saigon. Clifton Daniel, an associate Editor of The New York Times is the moderator.

headline: Presbyterian Leaders Ask Nixon to Explain Asia
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 25—The General Assembly of the Unit ed Presbyterian Church, em broiled in debate over the Vietnam War, asked today that President Nixon or an official representative come here and outline United States policy in Southeast Asia.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: F.C.C. Petitioned to. Curb Talks By Nixon on TV About War
lead_paragraph: A group of Yale University professors, law students and leaders of the New Haven black coalition have filed a petition with the Federal Communica tions Commission asking a curb on President Nixon's access to the television networks when opponents of the Indochina war have not been accorded an equal opportunity for air time.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: U. S. SAID TO PLAN TO QUIT CAMBODIA BEFORE DEADLINE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 — The withdrawal of all United States ground troops from Cambodia is to be completed ahead of the June 30 deadline under present plans of the Nixon Administration, senior. Government officials said to day.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Pacification Set Back Slightly in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25—Pacification in South Viet nam is reported to have suf fered a slight setback last month.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Administration's Credibility: Doubts Inside and Out
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 — This capital is worrying about “credibility” again, but the worry this time is just as great inside the Government as among its critics.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Saving’ Cambodia
lead_paragraph: The strong public opposition to widening the war in Southeast Asia has not prevented the Administra tion from pursuing the Cambodian intervention by proxy, sustaining South Vietnamese troops in opera tions that go far beyond the announced objective of cleaning out border sanctuaries.

headline: 3 Senators and Former Defense Aide Attack War
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, May 25— Former Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul C. Warnke and three United States Senators called here today for speedy disengagement by the United States from the wars in Viet nam and Cambodia.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter Special to The New York Times

headline: In The Nation: Still Running Against Hoover
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25—A fairly good political case could be made that in every election since 1932, each time the Demo crats have had a good chance to run against Herbert Hoover and the Depression, they have elected a President. In this anal ysis, the Republicans have taken the White House only when they have been able to shift the issue from the state of the economy to Korea and Commu nism (1952) or to Vietnam and crime (1968). President Nixon, for one, is said to be convinced that it was the recession of 1960 that really did him in, the first time he ran.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: PARIS STOCK MARKET AFFECTED BY WAR
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 25—Battle dam age to French investments in Cambodia is aggravating both the pessimism on the Paris Stock Exchange and the anxi ety in France over latest Amer ican policy in the Far East.

headline: Cambodian Minister, in Saigon, Plans No Talks on Military Ties
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25—Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur of Cambodia said here today that although his country “highly appreciated the coop eration of the South Viet namese armed forces in rooting out Communist military bases in Cambodia,” he did not intend to raise the question of “a for mal military alliance” with South Vietnam.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: Court Upsets Ban on Uniforms Worn by Actors Mocking Army
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25— The Supreme Court unani mously struck down today a provision of a Federal statute that makes it a crime for an actor to wear United States military apparel in a theatrical production if the portrayal re flects discredit on the armed forces.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: War's Effect on Health Care
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) —About 250 medical personnel from Harvard University visited Capitol Hill today to tell Sena tors, Representatives and aides of the impact that the Vietnam war was having on the health care profession. They voiced concern about the ability of the nation to meet critical needs in the quality of health care, medical search and education becaure of the war.

headline: Tape Recorders for Vietnam
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, May 25 (AP)—Japan exported to South Vietnam last year 213,897 tape recorders worth $22.5‐million, Finance Ministry officials said today. They said most of the tape re corders were believed to have been purchased by American soldiers in South Vietnam.

headline: Soviet Warns Pnompenh Of ‘Long Fratricidal War’
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, May 25—The So viet Union has warned the cur rent Cambodian leaders that Cambodia “will be plunged into a long fratricidal war” un less United States and South Vietnamese forces are with drawn from their country.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: The Times did a disservice to the state primary by suggesting [editorial May 13] that with the Liberal party” supporting my op ponent the primary race for Governor was now “academic”. I disagree.

headline: SUIT STILL STIRS MARYMOUNT GIRLS
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 25—Marymount College is still feeling the effects of a court suit filed earlier this month against a strike at the college —even though the suit was settled out of court and the college says it was never on strikp to begin with.
author: By Linda Greenhouse Special to The New York Times

headline: College Group to Explain Political Endorsements
lead_paragraph: Considerations that entered into endorsements by the New York Region of the Movement for a New Congress, a college political action group, will be among subjects discussed at 2:30 P.M. news conference to day by Stephen A. O. Golden, regional director, in the. Co lumbia Law School faculty lounge.

headline: Cambodia War Said to Cause Major Peking Shift
lead_paragraph: Information reaching New York from sources close to Communist leaders in Asia sug gests that the United States move into Cambodia has trans formed the Indochina situation more radically than originally estimated. This evaluation is be ing taken seriously in Wash ington.
author: By Harrison E. Salisbury

headline: ROGERS, IN ROME, BIDS U.S. AIDES BACK NIXON
lead_paragraph: ROME, May 25—Secretary of State William P. Rogers today defended United States inter vention in Cambodia as “one of the most courageous and suc cessful actions for many years.”

headline: 12 Days of Peace Cost City an Extra Million
lead_paragraph: The city spent $1,158,000 in overtime pay for police men assigned to keep order during downtown demonstra tions in the 12‐day period from May 11 to May 22.

headline: O'Dwyer Calls for Giving Free Narcotics to Addicts
lead_paragraph: Paul O'Dwyer broke yester day with the other three can didates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate by urging estab lishment of government centers to administer free drugs to narcotics addicts.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: Just as each publisher must have his sex book, his sports book and his Vietnam book, so each publisher must also have his autobiography of a young radical. Auto biographies of young radicals arrive these days in dozens, like cartons of eggs, and reviewers tend to try to make omelets out of them. It won't work. All the eggs may look alike to the eye of a construction worker or a Vice President or a Bruno Bettelheim, but inside each Is inconvenient ly unique. James Kunen is not Dotson Rader is not Paul Cowan is not Jerry Rubin is not Don MacNeill is not Bobby Seale.
author: By John Leonard

headline: SIHANOUK ARRIVES IN HANOI FOR VISIT
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, May 25 (Reuters) —Prince Norodom Sihanouk. the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, arrived in Hanoi to day amid indications that North Vietnam would not send more troops into Cambodia.

headline: U.S. Says 201 G.I.'s Have Died In 25 Days of Cambodia Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25 (AP) — The United States command reported to day that American battlefield deaths had reached 201 in 25 days of operations in Cam bodia.

headline: U.S. Aide Assails Swedish Protesters
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM. May 25—Dr. Jerome H. Holland, the United States Ambassador to Sweden, complained today that he had been subjected to “disgrace ful” demonstrations protesting United States policy in South east Asia and warned that they could have “far‐reaching im plications.”

headline: Morton Shows Poll Backing Nixon Move
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25— Countering Democratic charges that Americans are losing con fidence in President Nixon, the Republican National Chairman released poll figures today in dicating that a majority of the voters approve of the Presi dent's decision to send Ameri can troops into Cambodia.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Has 513 Generals
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) —There are now 513 Army generals, about 50 per cent more than before the Vietnam war. Part of the reason is the increased size of the armed forces and part is that promo tions come more quickly in time of combat.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Case for the SST

headline: MANY TO FORGO CONVENTION TALK
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26— George Meany, who was billed as the sole speaker Thursday at the convention of the Amal gamated Clothing Workers of America, will not come here to address the 417,000‐member union.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON TO RENEW TIES TO CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 27 — The Governments of South Vietnam and Cambodia agreed here to day that South Vietnamese troops would be pulled out of Cambodia “as soon as their mission is completed.”

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: Arts. President Nixon an nounced the appointment of 49 persons to be members of the Advisory Committee on the Arts of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts.

headline: U.S. Reports Increased Attacks in Fishhook Region
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 (AP)—United States infan trymen were reported battling enemy forces at four points around the Cambodian town of Memot today, the third straight day Americans have reported increased enemy attacks in the Fishhook region over the bor der north of Saigon.

headline: ROMNEY DEFENDS CAMBODIA POLICY
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May. 26—George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, today asked the general assembly of the United Preshyterien Church to withhold judgment on the in vasion of Cambodia, “for a few weeks.”
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. Raids Miami Office Of Group Opposing Castro
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, May 26 (AP) — Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the headquarters yesterday of Al pha 66, a militantly anti‐Castro group, days after a Government decision that attacks on Cuba from United States territory by exiles must stop.

headline: CONVICTED MARINE IS SEEKING RELEASE
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me., May 26—A former Marine Corps lance cor poral who was convicted by a court‐martial of murdering five Vietnam civilians in 1968, is trying for the third time to be released from his 20‐year sen tence.

headline: LAIRD SAID TO ASK IF ASIA PULLOUT CAN BE ADVANCED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26—Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is said to have asked American commanders in Viet nam whether, in light of recent operations against suspected enemy base areas in Cambodia, the United States can withdraw more troops from Vietnam by May 1, 1971 than the 150,000 announced by President Nixon last month.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Group Favors Equal Time For Reply to Talks on War
lead_paragraph: The Yale University group of professors and law students, expanding on the release of their petition to the Federal Communications Commission, stressed yesterday that it did not wish to impair the right of President Nixon to use the television networks as he felt necessary in the public interest.

headline: KENTUCKY PRIMARY WON BY FOE OF WAR
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (UPI)—State Senator Romano J. Mazzoli, 37 years old, a dove on the Vietnam war, won today the Democratic nomination for Representative from the Third District (Louisville and south ern suburbs) by a substantial margin over his hawk oppo nent, State Senator Tom Ray.

headline: SENATE SUPPORTS NIXON ON PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26—In the first vote in a prolonged Cambodia debate, the Senate made clear today that it en dorsed President Nixon's troop withdrawal plans, although it remained divided on curbing any future military involvement in Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Vietcong Finds Life Easier as a Scout for U.S.
lead_paragraph: FIRE‐SUPPORT BASE SA BER, Cambodia, May 21— The Indochina war could not look meaner or messier than it does here, with tanks and men and guns in the mud.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: BEIRUT CONSIDERS ASKING TROOP AID FROM ARAB LANDS
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26— Premier Rashid Karami said to night in the National Assembly that the Lebanese Government was considering calling in troops from Morocco and Tuni sia or other Arab countries to help defend Lebanon against Israel.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: International

headline: NIXON AIDES SAY ECONOMIC MOVES ARE SUCCEEDING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26 — The Nixon Administration, un der a barrage of criticism from, politicians and financiers, stood firmly by its economic policies today.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: 350 SCHOLARS JOIN ANTIWAR EFFORTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26— The antiwar lobbying effort on Capitol Hill was reinforced today by delegations of nation ally known clergymen, by scholars and suburbanites.
author: By E. W. Kenworthy Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Discloses China Increases Aid for 1970
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 27—Com munist China will provide more military and economic aid to North Vietnam under an agree ment announced today.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Greets Suharto and Briefs Him on Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26— President Nixon welcomed President Suharto of Indo nesia to the White House today and told him during a 90‐minute conference that the joint United States South Vietnamese operation in Cambodia was a success. The two men held the first of two meetings scheduled during President Suharto's three‐day stay in Washing ton. He is on a week‐long state visit to the United States. At his arrival at the White House President Su harto said that “my visit comes at a time when the need for sincere and realistic efforts in the interest of peace and stability in the world, and in Southeast Asia in particular, has become ever more pressing.” Speak ing in Indonesian during the welcoming ceremonies, Presi dent Suharto told Mr. Nixon through an interpreter: “The restoration of peace and stabil ity in this region will require the combined endeavors of all countries in the area as well as of those external powers hav ing a responsibility; in the maintenance of world peace.”
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. BACKS PROTEST BY ENVOY IN SWEDEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26—A State Department official said today that the department agreed completely with state ments made yesterday by the United States Ambassador to Sweden, who, complained of “disgraceful” demonstrations by Swedes protesting American policy in Southeast Asia.

headline: BAR EXAM DENIAL AT N.Y.U. IS UPHELD
lead_paragraph: The New York Court of Ap peals yesterday rejected a re quest from the faculty of the New York University Law School to allow striking law students to take the state bar examination without first tak ing this semester's final exami nations.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: Screen: A Plastic Garden:Don Johnson Portrays 'Stanley Sweetheart'
lead_paragraph: Stanley Sweetheart, a junior at Columbia, lost his virginity at 16, wears his hair discreetly long and has the kind of trouble with girls that a liberated Henry Aldrich might have. After a very earnest campaign, he succeeds in deflowering one of Grosse Pointe's prettiest and dimmest candidates for higher education. Later, he himself is seduced by her ravenous, overweight roommate (while starring her in an underground movie called "Masturbation"). Depending on the way you regard such things, Stanley finally hits bottom, or top, when he winds up in an East Village ménage à trois with two extremely cheerful (and flexible) Lesbians.Stanley is a role-player—basically innocent. "The Magic Garden of Stanley Sweetheart" isn't.It peers and peeks more than any average Russ Meyer movie, and it talks dirtier than just about any commercial movie that I can remember. Its camera swings and there is a lot of rock music on the soundtrack. However, like so many other places of expensive, modish, retail merchandise, it remains calculatingly bland, with no more wit or point of view than "Search for Tomorrow," although it occasionally takes a reproving, almost motherly look at the dirty dishes, the piled-up garbage and empty beer cans that litter Stanley's apartment.The film, which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, was adapted for the screen by Robert T. Westbrook from his own quite funny, reportedly semi-autobiographical novel. Although the novel was not specifically dated in time, it was apparently meant to be more or less contemporary.The novel's Stanley is not a political animal (the book makes no attempt to cover the Columbia riots of 1968), but its Stanley is facing Vietnam and, in one of Stanley's nicest, Mittyesque moments, he commits himself to non-commitment by tearing up his draft card and sending it off to his draft board with a letter that starts: "I've been watching your ugly, stupid viciousness on TV for long enough. . . ."In spite of the fact that the movie's Stanley goes to the real-life Columbia (the film was photographed entirely in New York), there is no draft and no Vietnam. There is only a terrible feeling of déjà vu about the life styles it does cover. Underground movies were funny about seven or eight years ago, and Don Johnson plays Stanley as if he were imitating Marlon Brando, who was imitable 20 years ago. Stanley's encounters with women seem not to be patterned on life as much as on movies like "Finders Keepers, Lovers Weepers." Women rampant leave him exhausted, and exhaustion, more than anything else, is the basis of his sentimental education.Of the women in the film, two are memorable: Dianne Hull, who manages to act the role of a sweet, dull girl without ever being dull, and Holly Near, who plays a big fat girl with the unfinished facial features of an irritable 6-year-old and the sexual hungers of Catherine of Russia. The film is the first theatrical feature directed by Leonard Horn, who comes from television where, among other things, he directed segments of "Mannix" and "Mission: Impossible." He's been a bad boy and someone should take away his zoom lens.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: EARTHY UPHELD ON BALLOT PLACE
lead_paragraph: Representative Richard Max McCarthy's nominating petitions were upheld yesterday, without a signature to spare.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: Rogers Backs NATO Move Toward East‐Bloc Accord
lead_paragraph: ROME, May 26—Secretary of State William P. Rogers endorsed today proposals by European allies of the United States foria mutual and balanced reduction of the forces of the Atlantic alliance and the Warsaw pact in central Eu rope.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: Most Indonesians Welcome Stability Under Suharto
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 —Peace and stability have settled over this archipelago na tion of some 120 million people.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Meets Heads Of 2 City Unions; Hails War Support
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26 — President Nixon told leaders of the building trades and long shoremen's unions of New York today that he had found their public demonstrations of sup port for his Vietnam policy reassuring and “very meaning ful.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Aide Hints a Veto by Nixon If War Curb Is Too Severe
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27—An official of the Nixon Adminis tration raised the threat today that the President would veto any measure on Cambodia en acted by Congress that re stricted his constitutional powers as Commander in Chief.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Liberal Party Backing in Democratic Primary
author: James A. Means

headline: Transfer of Arms Authorized
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27— State Department officials dis closed today that the South Vietnamese and Thai Govern ments were empowered to turn over to the Cambodian Army military equipment that had been supplied by the Unit ed States.

headline: Foreign Ministers' Pact
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27—The foreign ministers of South Vietnam and Cam bodia signed documents here today giving South Vietnam a broad and open‐ended mandate for military operations in Cam bodia.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: GOLDBERG AIDING BOSTON CANDIDATE
lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Goldberg took time out yesterday from his own campaign yesterday to aid an antiwar Roman Catholic priest in Bosfon in his bid to take the Democratic nomination away from an incumbent Con gressman generally favorable to President Nixon's policies on Vietnam.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: BIPARTISAN GROUP BACKS POLICY CURBS
lead_paragraph: Fifty members of the Young Republican and Young Demo cratic Cubs of New York City voted last night at a joint meet ing here to support two Senate bills aimed at ending American involvement in Southeast Asia.

headline: Shriver Urged to Help Democrats' Fall Campaign
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27— Friends of Sargent Shriver are trying to persuade him to accept a new national role as campaign speaker and fund raiser for the election of liberal antiwar Democrats to Congress He was said to be undecided.
author: By Ben A. Franklin Special to The New York Times

headline: Presbyterians Will Seek $70‐Million to Help Poor
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 27 — The general assembly of the 3.2‐ million‐member United Presby terian Church overwhelmingly approved today a campaign to raise more than $70‐million to be used its “depressed areas and among deprived people.”

headline: Thieu Sees Indefinite Stay
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27—South Vietnamese troops will continue to operate in Cambodia for an indefinite period after United States units are withdrawn and will require continued American logistical and combat support to sustain those operations, President Nguyen Van Thieu has de clared.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Envoy to Sweden Is Praised Amid Epithets
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, May 27—The new United States Ambassador to Sweden, Dr. Jerome H. Hol land, is winning applause here for his spirited efforts to repair Swedish‐American relations de spite the eggs and epithets hurled against him by youthful eictremists.
author: By John M. Lee Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 U.S. Jets, in Reprisal, Attack Gun Positions in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27 —A Pentagon spokesman said today that two American fighter‐bombers attacked anti aircraft gun sites in North Viet nam on Monday after a recon naissance plane they were es corting had been fired on about 90 miles north of the demili tarized zone.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Suharto Says Red Troop Intervention in Asia Must Be Prevented
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27— President Suharto of Indonesia declared today that “other for eign troops” must be prevented from replacing those of the United States as Americans withdraw from the Asian main land.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Reported Recruiting Cambodians in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27—American soldiers were re ported today to be recruiting ethnic Cambodian residents of the Mekong delta for fighting in Cambodia.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon arid the Protests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27—A month has passed since Presi dent Nixon ordered American troops into Cambodia and there are now three quite different views here about how his Ad ministration is reacting to the turmoil that ensued.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Student Group Plans Memorial Day War Protests
lead_paragraph: As antiwar demonstrations continued on some campuses yesterday, a student group in Washington announced plans for demonstrations in several cities on Memorial Day and a drive to spread the protest movement beyond the colleges and universities into union halls, military installations and migrant labor camps.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: DAVITS URGES SPEED IN WAR WITHDRAWAL
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacob K. Javits caller yesterday for an acceleration of the United States withdrawal from Vietnam and termed it “the biggest single thing the Administration could do” to re store business confidence and reverse the economic down trend.

headline: AGNEW CRITICIZED BY CLOTHING UNION
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, May 27— The Amalgamated. Clothing Workers of America today criticized Vice President Agnew for public statements that the union contended threatened dissent, free speech and free dom of the press.

headline: Pope Addresses G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: ROME, May 27 (AP)—Pope Paul VI told a group of United States servicemen en route home from Vietnam today: “We want to tell you how much we have prayed in favor of peace and how we want to see the end of the war and the affirma tion of love.”

headline: The President's Allies
lead_paragraph: American labor, like the nation at large, is divided in its views on the war in Vietnam and President Nixon's policies toward ending it. Jacob Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, this week described the American involve ment in Southeast Asia as a mortal threat to the nation's democratic processes; two days later, leaders of the building trades, longshoremen's and other unions called on Mr. Nixon to praise his military policies and promise continuing demonstrations in their support.

headline: Transcript of Nixon Talk Before Billy Graham Rally at University of Tennessee
lead_paragraph: Following is the transcript of President Nixon's remarks at the Billy Graham Rally in Knoxville, Tenn., last night, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

headline: Burns Promises Economic Credit to U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28— Arthur F. Burns has pledged that the Federal Reserve Board, acting as a “lender of last re sort,” would not let the econo my collapse because of a short age of ready funds in banks or other financial institutions.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. WAR DEATHS AT 142 FOR WEEK; A DECLINE OF 35%
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 — The allied com mands reported today that American combat deaths de clined by 35 per cent last week while the number of South Vietnamese soldiers killed rose by 25 per cent.

headline: Falbright Describes Ky As ‘an Asian Agnew’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)—Senator J. W. Ful bright, describing Vice Presi dent Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam as “an Asian Ag new,” charged today that Sai gon's leaders were determined “to keep the Americans mired in the swamp” of Cambodia.

headline: OHIO WITHDRAWS TROOPS AT O.S.U.
lead_paragraph: The approximately 1,700 members of the Ohio National Guard remaining on the recent ly embattled Ohio State Uni versity campus were withdrawn last night, after a day in which student demonstrators pelted them with marshmallows.

headline: MUSKIE SAYS NIXON IS DIVIDING NATION
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, May 28— Senator Edmund S. Muskie to day accused the Nixon Admin istration of dividing the nation and threatening democracy by its military and economic policies.

headline: AGNEW PREDICTS ECONOMIC UPTURN
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 28 — Vice President Agnew sought to reassure the financial community today by predicting that “1970 is going to be a good year for business, with an upturn in the second half.”
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON EMPHASIZES YOUTH CAN EFFECT PEACEFUL CHANGE
lead_paragraph: Transcript of Nixon's speech is printed on Page 8.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Patriotic Town Is Angry Over Teachers' Protest
lead_paragraph: PLAINFIELD, Ind., May 27 —In the Buick showroom, a salesman was listening with affability and patience—atti tudes that sometimes wear thin in this rigidly conserva tive town—as a long‐haired young customer in shorts and sandals, expounded on the dangers of pollution. Above their heads a cardboard sign spun in the air conditioning cur rents, periodically displaying the message that the 1970 Buick was “Something To Believe In.”
author: By Joseph Lelyveld Special to The New York Times

headline: Relic of Civilization
lead_paragraph: The Vietnam wars of this century, involving Japa riese, French, Americans and Vietnamese, have left more than enough ruins in Indochina. These ruins we could do without; but there is one ruin, from another century, that we could not do without. It is of course Angkor Wat, potentially endangered by extension of the war into Cambodia.

headline: Antiwar Concert Monday
lead_paragraph: Misha Dichter, pianist; Itzhak Pearlman, violinist, and Walter Trampler, violist, will appear in a concert Monday night at the Juilliard Theater at Lincoln Center for the benefit of the National Coalition for a Re sponsible Congress, the anti Vietnam war organization. The performers will be supported by the Juilliard Theater Orches tra.

headline: An Asian Policy for Cambodia
lead_paragraph: Extension of the Indochina war to Cambodia has been sharply criticized by one of the most important Asian leaders friendly to the United States.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: SST Recommendations.

headline: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS CAMBODIA INVASION
lead_paragraph: The State Department's legal adviser yesterday defended the American invasion of Cambodia as legitimate self‐defense, legal under international law.

headline: Sihanouk Aide, in Paris, Appeals for Soviet Support
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 28—A high aide to Prince Norodom Sihanouk appealed here today for Soviet support for the Cambodian in surgent movement.

headline: Bar Association Urges Pullout Of U.S. Troops From Indochina
lead_paragraph: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night passed a vigorously de bated resolution urging the im mediate withdrawal of Ameri can forces from Southeast Asia.

headline: Police Tear Gas Stops Saigon Demonstrations
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 (Reuters)—The police used tear gas today to fore stall two student demonstra tions, and some of the stu dents retaliated by throwing stones and firebombs.

headline: 2 Officers Charged With Ordering G.I.'s To Shoot Into Huts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28 — The Army charged two junior officers today with attempted murder in connection with a 1969 incident in South Vietnam in which an American platoon was allegedly directed to fire at some huts for “target prac tice.”
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: POLICE ENJOINED ON WAR PROTEST
lead_paragraph: Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley last night issued an order obliging every mem ber of the Police Department to protect antiwar demon strators here against “actual or threatened physical harm” dur ing the Memorial Day weekend.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: North Vietnamese Reported Recruiting Guerrillas in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 —North Vietnamese troops are reportedly conduct ing an intensive recruiting and proselytizing campaign among the rural population of Cam bodia in what official sources here see as an attempt to cre ate a broadly based Communist guerrilla organization similar to the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: KAZIN DELIVERS LECTURE ON FLAG
lead_paragraph: Alfred Kazin, the author and literary critic, denounced yes terday what he called the “flag business,” the use of the Ameri can flag by construction work ers and others as a patriotic symbol against war dissenters.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Majority of U. of California Found Involved in Protests
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)—For the first time, stu dent protest on University of California campuses encom passes a majority of the aca demic community, the system's president, Charles H. Hitch, said today.

headline: SAIGON'S MARINES TRY TO END SIEGE NEAR PNOMPENH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 30—More than 1,000 South Vietnamese ma rines battled North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops today in the besieged Cambodian town of Preyveng, 30 miles south east of Pnompenh.

headline: Vietcong Long a Fixture at Snoul, Deputy Says
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 29—Heour Lay Inn is the Na tional Assembly Deputy from Snoul and Chhlong, his native town. He cannot go home to his district because the ruins of Snoul, leveled and captured by the Americans earlier this month, are inaccessible from here and the Vietnamese Com munists hold Chhlong.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodian Foray After a Month: From Arms and Rice to Buttons
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29—The allied military campaign in Cambodia is a month old.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: COURT NULLIFIES ORDER TO POLICE
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit nullified a Federal District Court order yesterday that would have required the city's Police Department to remind every member of the force this weekend of his duty to protect antiwar demonstrators from physical assaults and threats.
author: By Craig R. Whitney

headline: Thousands of Saigon Students Demonstrate at State Funeral
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29 (UPI) — Several thousand students today staged the big gest anti‐Government demon stration in recent weeks at the state funeral of Phan Khac Suu, a former South Vietnam ese Chief of State.

headline: Alexandra Russell Is Married To Timothy Birch of the Army
lead_paragraph: Miss Alexandra Brenda Russell, granddaughter of the 10th Duke of Marlborough and a descenant of Commo dore Cornelius Vanderbilt, was married here yesterday to Specialist 5 Timothy Campbell Birch, whose Army service has included duty in Vietnam.

headline: Veterans Occupy Ministry
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, May 29 (AP)—Some 200 disabled veterans tempo rarily occupied offices of the Veterans' Ministry here today.

headline: CHARGES RIDICULED BY CAPTAIN'S FATHER
lead_paragraph: SCRANTON, Pa., May 29 (AP) — The father of an Army captain charged with attempted murder “of an unspecified num ber of human beings” in Viet nam says the charges are ri diculous.

headline: EX‐G.I. DESCRIBES SHOOTING AT HUTS
lead_paragraph: SAN. FRANCISCO, May 29 —An eyewitness to a shooting incident in South Vietnam that led yesterday to charges of at tempted murder against two Army officers said today that he and other soldiers saw ci vilians moving around a clus ter of huts in the Mekong Delta before the huts were fired on for “target practice.”
author: By M. A. Farber Special to The New York Times

headline: Rabbi and Woman Arrested For Disrupting Temple Rite
lead_paragraph: Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman adviser to the Radical Jewish Union of Columbia University and 22‐year‐old Annie Rosen a member of the union, were arrested last evening after they disrupted services at Temple Emanu‐El. They were charged with interfering with a wor ship service.

headline: O'Brien Assails President On Aid to War Veterans
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)—The Democratic Nation al Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused the Nixon Ad ministration of a negative, foot dragging attitude toward Con gressional efforts to improve the lot of Vietnam war vet erans.

headline: Sihanouk Acknowledges He Aided Reds
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 29 — Prince Norodom Sihanouk said in Hanoi yesterday that while in office he had given to “the Vietnamese people fighting against the United States im perialists an effective support and assistance that is not verb al.”
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Enjoining the Police
lead_paragraph: The cancellation by the United States Court of Appeals of a lower court order requiring the New York Police Department to fulfill its legal obligation to protect anti‐war demonstrators on this Memorial Day weekend removes an unwarranted slur on the entire police foree—one that was particularly unfor tunate in a week when two young policemen were brutally killed in the line of duty.

headline: President, on Coast, Confers With Aides On Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 29—After nearly seven weeks of almost continuing crisis, President Nixon settled in here today for a vacation weekend at his Western White House.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Peace Seats Ruled Out
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan., May 29 (AP) —The Kansas Board of Regents informed Gov. Robert Docking today that there would be no special seating section or recog nition for peace advocates at commencement exercises Mon day at the University of Kansas.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To Back President

headline: Upstate Man Seized For Flying U.S.Flag With Peace Symbol
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG VILLAGE, N. Y., May 30— W. Fleming, former associate dean of the University of Buffalo Law School and now the university's advocate, was arrested here this afternoon and charged with descrating the flag.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Though I agree far more often than not with the Vice President, I submit that his ulti mate glory lies in an unblem ished sense of personal integ rity that by all rights should have been defeated long ago. Defeated by those who see in his presence a reminder of that which they themselves have be trayed and compromised many times over through their eva sions, half‐lies, Inconsistencies, unyieldinc, conformity to dog ma—in short, an intellectual hypocrisy of the worst sort.

headline: Bullet Is Taken From G.I.'s Heart
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 (AP)—Army surgeons have removed an enemy bul let from the heart of a 20 year‐old American soldier. Pfc. Donald H. Light of Red bud, 1ll., who was wounded in Cambodia Tuesday, was reported in good condition today and was able to talk with members of his family by telephone.

headline: R.O.T.C. PROTESTS WORRY PENTAGON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)—More than 30 Reserve Officers Training Corps build ings have been fire‐bombed on campuses this term by antiwar protesters, and the Defense De Dartment is worried.

headline: Congress Gets No Help on Cambodia Compromise
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over breakfast table in the National Press Club, an Administration of ficial last week told a small group of reporters something that the White House has not yet told its own Republican Sen ators — namely, that the White House saw no compromise pos sible on the restrictive Cambo dian amendment before the Sen ate.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: Samuels Endorses Starting ‘National Day of Sanity’
lead_paragraph: Howard J. Samuels, cam paigning yesterday at the Brooklyn beaches with his wife, Bobbi, and their four daugh ters, aged 11 to 24, urged that hereafter Memorial Day be ob served also as “a national day of sanity” in which the genera tions would communicate with each other. Mr. Samuels, who isseeking the Democrat ic nomination for Gov ernor, read to picnick ing crowds at Man hattan and Brighton Beaches and at Coney Island a statement he had sent to the Memorial Day Peace Ac tion Coalition.
author: By Will Lissner

headline: Universities in Saigon, Shut May 6, to Reopen Tomorrow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30(Reuters) — Universities and colleges in Saigon will resume classes on Monday after having been closed for more than three weeks, the Saigon radio an nounced today.

headline: Nixon Summons Top Aides
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 30—President Nixon summoned his ranking military advisers today for a full‐scale review of the Cambodian operation and his program to turn the war over to the South Vietnamese.

headline: Ottinger Uses TV As Medium For the Message
lead_paragraph: Three months ago Senator Charles E. Goodell took a poll that evaluated his potential Democratic opponents and found that 63 per cent of the state's enrolled Democrats had never heard of Richard L. Ot Unger. An Ottin2er poll turn weeks ago showed that 63 per cent had not only heard of him, but knew he was a Congress man running for Senator and was against the war in Vietnam and pollution of the Hudson River and was for Israel and old people.

headline: CANDIDATES HERE LINK CAMPAIGNS TO HOLIDAY THEME
lead_paragraph: Pleas for better treatment of veterans and for “sanity” in the discussion of national prob lems were voiced by political candidates yesterday as they intensified their campaigns on Memorial Day.
author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: ENEMY ASSAULTS MOUNTAIN RESORT IN SOUTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. May 30—Enemy troops attacked the mountain resort city of Dalat and surrounding military posts early this morning. It was the most serious attack since the Tet offensive in early 1968.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Mr. Nixon Speaks to Youth
lead_paragraph: President Nixon is understandably anxious to show that he is able to speak face‐to‐face to the nation's youth. His early morning stroll among student dem onstrators at the recent peace rally in Washington fitted into that effort; his address to the Billy Graham meeting in the football stadium at the University Tennessee was a more spectacular appeal to a massed audience of young America.

headline: Indochina 1: Saigon's Plans in Cambodia Ambiguous
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—In a small ante chamber just off the main en trance to South Vietnam's For eign Ministry building last week, the Foreign Ministers of Cam bodia and South Vietnam signed a series of documents reopen ing diplomatic relations between the two neighbors after a lapse of seven years.

headline: Sorensen Is ‘Celebrity’ In a Visit to the Catskills
lead_paragraph: MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 30 —The first event chalked on the board at the patio at the Evans Hotel in Loch Sheldrake today was a golf tournament at 10; the second was, “Yoga: wear shorts.” at 11.
author: By Maurice Carroll Special to The New York Times

headline: The Day Wall St. Met the President
lead_paragraph: In a suite at Washington's Madison Hotel Wednesday evening, a group of Wall Street chieftains got to gether to talk about the day's events. Their host was Bernard J. Lasker, chairman of New York Stock Ex change's Board of Gover nors, and all of them were about to attend a White House dinner.
author: By Terry Robards

headline: Sihanouk Says U.S. Foiled Him
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sunday, May 31 (AP) — Prince Norodom Siha nouk, ousted March 18 as Cam bodia's Chief of State, says forces loyal to him would have captured Pnompenh, the Cam bodian capital, if United States and South Vietnamese forces had not intervened, the Com munist Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported today.

headline: Memorial Day: 2 Outlooks
lead_paragraph: Two Memorial Day parades, widely separated in ideology, were held here yesterday to honor America's war dead.
author: By William. E. Farrell

headline: Foreign Affairs: The Arrogance of Ignorance—I
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Just one month ago the President announced that American ground forces had been ordered into Cambodia. At that time I wrote: “If Nixon can swiftly smash the sanctu aries outside Vietnam without dangerous escalation or con frontations elsewhere, he will ultimately emerge triumphant at home as well as overseas. Nothing succeeds like success but, if he fails, nothing fails like failure.”
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Medicine's War Role
lead_paragraph: The Army, which accounts for more Vietnam war casual ties than any other service, reports that more than 81 per cent of its wounded are sur viving in Vietnam, compared with 74 per cent in the Korean War and 71 per cent in World War II.
author: By M. D. Howard A. Rusk

headline: Foe's Cambodia Strategy Alters U.S. Aides' Views
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30— Senior officials of the Nixon Administration are reportedly moving to the conclusion that Cambodia will need increasing military assistance from South Vietnam and Thailand, includ ing troops from South Vietnam at least.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Seeks U.S. Funds To Meet Economic Crisis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 — South Vietnam is seeking up to $200‐million in emergency aid from the United States to help tide it over an economic crisis caused by severe inflation at a time of its increasing commitment in Cambodia.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: Martial Law in Cambodia To Be Invoked Tomorrow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 31 (AP)—The Cambodian radio said today that martial law would go into effect in Cambodia tomorrow and that heavy prison terms or death sentences would be im posed for a long list of crimes.

headline: GRADUATION SPEECH GIVEN BY BREWSTER
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass., May 30 (AP) — Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale, spoke at the 100th commencement of the University of Massachusetts to day. He used Memorial Day as his theme and the division of opinion over the Indochina war as an example of patriotism.

headline: Church in Pnompenh Becomes A Vietnamese Refugee Village
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 30 (AP)—Almost every village in Cambodia has a church in it. The Catholic Church of Notre Dame on the banks of the Bassac River has a village in it.

headline: Indochina 3: Alliance With Lots Of Mutual Distrust
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia—The Cambodian military units in the southern region are insignifi cant in numbers compared to the South Vietnamese troops engaged there, a high official close to Premier Lon Nol said the other day, but at least they can act as gendarmes.
author: —Henry Kamm

headline: CAMBODIA RENEWS TROOP‐ISSUE PLEA
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 31—The Government disclosed today that it had renewed an earlier appeal to the Soviet Union and Britain, co‐chairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1954, to send the International Control Commission back to investigate its charge that North Vietnam and the Viet cong were stepping up their military activities against Cam bodia.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Sam Thong, Key Laotian Town, Reported Retaken From Enemy
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 31 —in an unexpected show of strength, Laotian troops have driven North Vietnamese sol diers from several hilltop posi tions overlooking Sam Thong and re‐entered the mountain valley town, 80 miles northeast of here, it was reported today.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: 6‐MONTH TERM SET IN VIETNAM DEATH
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 31—A military court sentenced First Lieut. James B. Duffy to six months in confine ment today in what the court decided was the involuntary manslaughter of an unarmed Vietnamese prisoner.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: NIGH COURT BACKS GAGGING TO CURB TRIAL DISORDERS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31— The Supreme Court said today that trial judges could have dis ruptive defendants bound and gagged, jailed for contempt of court or expelled from court if such measures were necessary to preserve order.
author: By Graham Fred P Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Jet Downs Hanoi MIG In Battle Over the North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1—A United States Navy F‐4 Phantom jet fighter‐intercepter shot down a North Vietnamese MIG‐21 jet fighter over North Vietnam last Saturday, spokesmen for the United States military com mand reported yesterday.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Vietnam: Moral Issue
author: Phyllis Smith

headline: Saigon's Raid in Cambodia Stirs U.S. Aides' Concern
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1—The South Vietnamese Army's penetration of Cambodian territory last week has caused considerable concern among United States diplomats here.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Announcement Expected On Further Troop Withdrawals
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31— Pentagon officials said today that they expected President Nixon to announce further troop withdrawals from South Vietnam sometime in April, de spite reports that some top military men were urging a delay in the next phase of the withdrawals.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: LINDSAY TO SPEAK AT PEACE RALLY
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay will speak at a Vietnam peace rally April 15 in Bryant Park, the Vietnam Moratorium and Peace Parade Committees announced yester day. Mr. Lindsay's office said the Mayor had accepted the in vitation of the organizers.

headline: MARCOS DISCOUNTS U.S. FUNDING DISPUTE
lead_paragraph: MANILA, March 31 President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called the issue of American funding of the Philippine contingent to Vietnam an internal quarrel be tween the two political parties in the United States who were “dragging in the Philippines.”

headline: 134 Wall Street Lawyers Criticize Behavior of Judge Hoffman
lead_paragraph: A group of 134 young lawyers from Wall Street firms have signed a petition asking for an investigation and possible censure and removal of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoff man, who conducted the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Premier's Brother Slain
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, March 31—A brother of Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol, the Cambodian Premier, was stabbed to death last Saturday at his home in Chup, near the troubled city of Kompong Chain, by a gang of Vietnamese rubber plantation workers.

headline: ‘Cutting into the Bone’
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's Vietnamization program is ap proaching a critical test of credibility this month as the third phase of announced American troop with drawals from Southeast Asia nears completion.

headline: Songmy Captain Accused Of Responsibility in Deaths
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1— Capt. Ernest L. Medina was ac cused by the Army today of being “responsible” for the mur der of Vietnamese civilians al legedly killed by members of his infantry company in the vil lage of Songmy two years ago.

headline: Test of the War's Legality Voted By Legislature in Massachusetts
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 1—The Mas sachusetts legislature gave final approval and sent to the Gov ernor today a bill intended to force a court test of the con stitutionality of the war in Vietnam.

headline: Laotians Strengthen Hold on Sam Thong; Shell and Bomb Foe
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1— Laotian forces were reported to have strengthened their hold on Sam Thong today as North Vietnamese troops pulled back from the mountain valley town they captured two weeks ago but lost to counterattacking Laotian troops yesterday.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Order in the Courts
lead_paragraph: “The conduct and language of the petitioners... he unending villification heaped upon the Court, the almost uninterrupted flow of vile, demeaning, vicious, base and threatening language shouted by the peti tioners...must be unparalleled in court history.”

headline: FRANCE PROPOSES INDOCHINA PARLEY
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 1—The French Government called tonight for a general conference on Indo china to make the area as a whole “a zone of neutrality and peace.”
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: ENEMY IN VIETNAM OPENS WIDE DRIVE, ENDING LONG LULL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1—After six months of relative quiet, the Vietnam war flared up again today with a coordinated series of enemy shelling and ground attacks against American and South Vietnamese targets throughout the country.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Platform Unit Urges Asia Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 1 —Embattled New York Demo crats, badly divided on a state ticket, received for considera tion today a state platform that includes proposals for re structuring the state govern ment.
author: By Clayton Knowles Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodia Hints at Shift Toward Joint Troop Use
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1—A Government spokesman, asked today if concerted actions between Cambodia and Am erican or South Vietnamese troops were being carried out or envisaged, said that the answer was negative as far as South Vietnam was concerned but that he preferred not to comment on the United States ??
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April I (UPI) —The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Vietnam:

headline: Enemy Fire Kills U.S. General, The Fifth to Die in Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: April 1 (AP)—Brig. Gen. Wil liam R. Bond, commander of the United States 199th Light Infantry Brigade, was killed by enemy small‐arms fire today. He was the fifth American gen eral killed in action in the Viet nam war the four others died in aircraft crashes.

headline: Fulbright, Fearing a ‘Disaster’, Urges Nixon to End War This Year
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2—Sen ator J. W. Fulbright said today that President Nixon's policy for Vietnam was not working, predicted that it would lead to a major disaster if it continued, and urged the President to reach a political settlement in Viet nam and in Laos and Cambo dia, the former French Indo china, this year.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodia Frees 486, Called Last of Sihanouk's Political Prisoners
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 2—The new leadership of Cambodia released today 486 persons described as all the remaining political prison ers jailed by the ousted Chief of State, Prince Norodom Si hanouk. In a ceremony, outside the National Assembly, the prisoners—including old men, women and children born in jail—were pronounced “patriots whose revolt against abuses, corruption and the absence of all social justice was fully justified.” They were given mimeographed documents bearing their thumbprints and attesting their release. Prisoners from the provinces were given the equivalent of $i or $2 for bus fare home. The prisoners applauded the announcement loudly and joined in a Gov ernment ‐ sponsored cheer: “Long live Lon Nol! Long live Sirik Matak! Long live Cheng Heng!” The three leaders are the Premier, First Deputy Premier and Pro visional Chief of State, who deposed Prince Sihanouk. They did not attend the cere mony. The Government, rep resented by Trinh Hoanh, secretary general of the National Committee of Salvation — the movement that overthrew the Prince two weeks ago—and deputies and ministers used the occasion to impress on the freed prisoners and the several thou sand spectators that the new leaders were restoring rights that Prince Sihanouk, “intoxi cated with personal power,” had unjustly abrogated.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Crippled Veterans Find Hospitals Crowded and Attitudes at Home Ambiguous
lead_paragraph: “The only time the American people ever see a Vietnam casualty is when he's got blood running out of him on the Cronkite program. After that, he's forgotten.”
author: By Sandra Blakeslee

headline: VIETNAMESE COOL TO FRENCH PLAN
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 2—North Viet nam, the Vietcong and the Sai gon delegation to the peace talks took a reserved attitude today toward a French sugges tion for a general conference on peace and neutrality in Indo china.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Attacks Ebb in Vietnam After 61 Americans Are Killed in 2‐Day Surge
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2 (AP)—A wave of heavy en emy attacks that struck across South Vietnam for two days ebbed tonight, and the United States command said the worst of the fighting appeared to be over.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) —The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been hilted in Vietnam:

headline: White House Asks Rise of $65‐Million For Veterans' Care
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2— President Nixon asked Congress today for a $65‐million increase in the Veterans Administra tion's budget for health care to expand medical programs for the increasing number of Vietnam veterans.

headline: The Indochinese Puzzle: U.S. Holding to Its Policies
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2—Two weeks after the overthrow of Prince Sihanouk in Cambodia, this capital does not know whether that country is drifting toward civil war or coming under solidified and “friendlier” rule.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Philippine Senators Agree On Inquiry Into U.S. Funds
lead_paragraph: MANILA, Friday, April 3—A committee of the Philippine Senate investigating the use of United States funds for a Philippine group in South Viet nam has agreed to begin with an inquiry into possible secret agreements between the Philip pines and United States.

headline: War Foes to Fight Counterinsurgency On U.S. Campuses
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2— Antiwar protesters announced today the beginning of a na tional drive to force Govern ment‐sponsored projects involv ing counterinsurgency off the campuses and eventually out of existence.

headline: Chase Assailed on World Issues
lead_paragraph: Stockholders of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, meet ing yesterday afternoon under extraordinary security arrange ments, peppered David Rocke feller with an assortment of questions and protests that turned the annual meeting into a noisy—though orderly— forum dealing largely with international affairs.
author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr

headline: A Test of Legality Of War Advances
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 2 — Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed today a bill challenging the le gality of the war in Vietnam.

headline: March in Capital Tomorrow to Back Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2—A march on Washington is sched uled for Saturday to support “victory over the Communists in Vietnam.”
author: By Paul Delaney Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 Airmen Not P.O.W.'s, North. Vietnamese Say
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3— The mother of one United States airman and the wives of three others shot down in the Vietnam war were told to day at the North Vietnamese Embassy that none of the men had ever been prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

headline: Foe Said to Have Left Cambodian Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3— According to authoritative re ports reaching here, the prin cipal Communist political and military headquarters for South Vietnam was hurriedly moved late last month from Cambodia to South Vietnamese territory.

headline: Combat G.I.'s Tell of Using Marijuana
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3—Nearly one out of five front‐line soldiers surveyed in an elite American combat unit in South Vietnam said re cently that they smoked mari juana at least once a day, according to an Army physi cian's study.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 U.S. COURTS BAR G.I.'S TEST ON WAR
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 3 (UPI)—Two Federal courts rejected today the first attempt by a Massa chusetts serviceman to bring suit under a new law challeng ing the President's authority to commit troops to combat zones such as Vietnam.

headline: Fighting Rages as G.I.'s Pursue Foe Near Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (AP) — The United States infantrymen pursuing an enemy battalion toward the Cambodian border encountered heavy resistance today, and contact continued into the night, field reports said.

headline: CAMBODIA PLANS A REPUBLIC SOON, ONE LEADER SAYS
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 3—The new leaders of Cam bodia plan to proclaim a re public soon, probably this month, one of them said to day.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnam Students Plan to Boycott Classes
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)—Some 60, 000 students from four South Vietnamese universities will boycott lectures indefinitely to protest the detention of 41 students, without trial, a spokesman said today.

headline: WAR PROTESTERS SCORE THAI LINK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON April 4— The Student Mobilization Commit tee to End the War in Vietnam says it expects hundreds of thousands of high school and college students to stay away front classees on April 15 and to demonstrate against United States involvement in South east Asia.

headline: 50,000 IN CAPITAL SUPPORT THE WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4— About 50,000 people marched up Pennsylvania Avenue to a rally at the Washington Monu ment today to advocate “vic tory in Vietnam.”

headline: VIETNAMESE SHOW FEAR IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 4—South Vietnam, torn by war, looks like a haven to most Vietnamese living in Cambodia.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: In The Nation: Strong Move in Massachusetts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The impor tance of the Massachusetts Legislature's bold challenge to the war in Vietnam is not that the Supreme Court is likely to rule that this “undeclared war” is an unconstitutional exercise of Presidential power. It is rather that the Massachusetts bill is the longest official step yet taken in making war resist ance acceptable and legitimate. That means it is bound to be come even more effectively political.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: VIETCONG TROOPS SEEN IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: BAVET, Cambodia, April 3— Three Americans checking re ports of Vietcong presence around: this Cambodian border town halted their car here this afternoon to wait while about a dozen men—identified by vil lagers as Vietcong—crossed the road in single file 200 yards ahead.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese War Veterans Charge Neglect
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4—Pham Van Dan, 29 years old, has been out of the South Vietnamese. Infantry Rangers for nearly five years, but he still wears his uniform and his eyes reddened slightly the other day when he was asked why.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: The labor scene came apart in a big way last week, with more turbulence in more key sectors than the country had experienced in any single period since 1946. A few of the worst trouble spots had been smoothed out by week's end, but the price of peace was extremely high—so high that it threatened to give extra bounce to the upsurge in living costs that caused most of the strikes in the first place.

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years there have been hints from the Supreme Court that even the guardians of the First Amend ment are not immune to a natu ral law of dissent—that one's toleration of noisy protest tends to be in inverse ratio to one's distance from it.

headline: PALESTINIAN TIES GROWING ABROAD
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 —The voyage last week of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, to Pe king and Hanoi is part of the commando movement's grow ing role in international of fairs.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: What to Do When The Judge Is Put Up Against the Wall
lead_paragraph: IN 1944, the United States Govern ment tried 30 American Nazis and Fascists for undermining the mo rale of our armed forces then at war.
