lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15— About 1,250,000 Americans will lose their jobs as a result of reductions in military man power and spending either already made or planned in the next defense budget, De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says Nixon Criteria On Pullout Can't Be Met
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 15—Ha Van Lau, North Vietnam's repre sentative at the Paris peace talks, said at the 50th session of the talks today that President Nixon's three criteria for the withdrawal of United States forces “in fact can never be met.”
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: ALLIED FIRE BASE ATTACKED BY FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15—Enemy gunners are re ported to have fired about 100 mortar rounds into an allied artillery base near Cambodia and then launched a ground attack that died out after an hour of intense fighting. Allied soldiers killed 29 of the enemy, while suffering light casualties, military spokesmen reported here.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: FULBRIGHT TARGET OF AGNEW'S TAUNT
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Jan. 16—Vice President Agnew said here today that Senator J. William Fulbright “apparently has blown his cool again.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Foes of War Form Group to Forward Letters to P.O. W.'s
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 15—Oppo nents of the Vietnam war an nounced today the formation of a committee to “facilitate communication between serv icemen held in North Vietnam and their relatives in the United States.”

headline: Washington: Quarterback Nixon's ‘Game Plan’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15—That incorrigible football buff, Rich ard M. Nixon, has come to the end of the first quarter with his “game plan” intact. Like his friend Vince Lombardi of the Washington Redskins, he is sticking to fundamentals and controlling the ball.
author: By James Reston

headline: THIEU OPPOSITION IN SENATE UNITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Jan. 16—Senator Tran Van Don and 14 other members of the South Vietnamese Senate announced today the formation of a political bloc that they said would become the nucleus of a wider opposition front.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) —The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: Decision Called Firm
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reu ters)—Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers said tonight that President Nixon's decision to end the United States com bat role in the Vietnam war was “irreversible” and would lead to the eventual removal of all American troops.

headline: SOUTH KOREA DENIES ATROCITY CHARGES
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15 — The South Korean Defense Ministry denied today as “un founded” and “deplorable” the charges that South Korean troops had murdered hundreds of South Vietnamese civilians.

headline: SONG BY GUTHRIE BARRED AT TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 15— Arlo Guthrie found out today you can't “get anything you want” in Judge Julius J. Hoffman's courtroom.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: PEACE MASS IS SAID ON PENTAGON STEPS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) —A peace fellowship group, in cluding two clergymen now on trial for an earlier incident, conducted a mass without in terference today on the steps of the Pentagon.

headline: Westmoreland Comments
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Jan. 16 (UPI)—Gen. William C. West moreland, former commander of United States forces in Viet nam, said today that the Army “is not trying to hide any thing” in the investigation of the alleged Mylai massacre.

headline: 16 Die Near Songmy As Vietcong Attack Hamlet of Refugees
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 16 (AP) — Vietcong guerillas invaded a hamlet near Songmy early today and hurled dyna mite charges into houses, kill ing 16 persons and wounding 21, an American spokesman said.

headline: Contract Breach Charged
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 16 (AP)—A breach of contract complaint against the Army was filed yesterday in Federal District Court by an attorney for one of the four soldiers charged in connection with the alleged Mylai massacres.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) —The Pentagon today identifiedthe following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: How Big the Cutback?
lead_paragraph: The additional cutbacks in defense spending, sketched by Defense Secretary Laird the other day, need to be put in perspective lest they seem larger than they are. They amount only to the reductions in spending to come from a scaling down of opera tions in Vietnam plus a little more trimmed here and there from a bloated budget. They represent no fundamental shifts in strategy, much less any reorder ing of priorities.

headline: AGNEW, IN AUCKLAND, IS FIRM ON VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 16 (AP)—Vice President Agnew, winding up his Asian tour, declared tonight that the United States and its allies must stand firm in Vietnam and not be swayed by antiwar factions.

headline: 3 ‘Missing’ U.S. Servicemen May Be P.O.W.'s in North
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16— Three servicemen listed as missing in North Vietnam may be prisoners of war, according to new information received by the Defense Department.

headline: Topics: A Plan for a Progressive Cease‐Fire in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. The fundamental flaw in the Administration's program for Vietnamizing the war is that it does not facilitate the very compromise settlement that President Nixon has announced as his objective.
author: By Alexander L. George and John Wilson Lewis

headline: RADIO‐TV CENSORING DENIED BY PENTAGON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16—The director of information for the armed forces denied today that military officials censor the ra dio and television stations that broadcast news to United States servicemen overseas.

headline: Goodwin Tells Jury in Chicago He Knew No Plans for Violence
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 16—Richard N. Goodwin, an aide to Presi dent Kennedy and President! Johnson, testified today that he knew of “no plan for viol ence” by demonstrators at the Democratic Convention here in 1968.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Testimony on Mass At Pentagon Given By Senator's Wife
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) — Mrs. Philip A. Hart, whose husband is not only Michigan's senior Senator but also a ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, testified in a suburban Virginia Federal magistrate court today as a co‐defendant with seven other persons arrested for par ticipating in an unauthorized eucharistic mass in the con course of the Pentagon last No vember.

headline: Legionnaires Seek $200,000 for Calley Defense
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 16 (UPI) — American Legion mem bers here began today a na tional fund‐raising drive to col lect $200,000 for a legal de fense fund for Army Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering 110 Vietnamese ci vilians.

headline: Student Says Refugees Toldof Korean Slayings
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16—A student at Saigon Uni versity said today that in 1966 he interviewed at least 100 refugees who told him stories or gave eyewitness accounts of indiscriminate killings and de struction by South Korean sol diers in Phuyen Province.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Youth Hostel to Be Given By U.S. Actor to the Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 — After 20 months of running a hostel for Saigon's shoeshine boys and homeless children, a 26‐year‐old actor and newsman, Richard Hughes, is turning his humanitarian en deavor into a purely Vietna mese‐run program.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Church Head to Aid Troops
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 17 (AP) —The Rev. Robert V. Moss, president of the two‐million member United Church of Christ, said today that he would spend Easter in Vietnam to “assist chaplains in minister ing to combat troops.” Dr. Moss, here for the dedication of the $8‐million Beatitudes Re tirement Home, said the soldiers bear burdens “far heavier than most of us realize.”

headline: Democrats Are Not Finding Nixon an Easy Target
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—As the 91st Congress returns this week for its second session, Congressional Democrats suddenly find them selves bereft of issues at the very time they are casting around for political points to use against a Republican Administra tion in the Congressional elec tions next fall.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: Wives of 4 Missing Fliers Seek Information in Laos
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP)—The wives of four Amer ican fliers missing in Vietnam flew to Laos today to seek the assistance of North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao officials in obtaining information about their husbands.

headline: Six Aspiring Democrats Give State Preview at Syracuse Forum
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, Jan. 17 — Six Democratic politicians who want to be Governor, United States Senator or State Attor ney General sought some early traction for their bandwagons today here in the icy heartland of New York.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: The Two Nations At Wesleyan University
lead_paragraph: THE old John Wesley House, a splendid campus landmark with white Ionic columns, turned into the Malcolm X House one sunny day last April. Overnight it became a conspicuous presence on the startled New England landscape. The sky did not fall and the earth did not tremble; neither did the alumni with draw their support. But Wesleyan, a small, estimable, historically white university in Middletown, would never be the same. “We have passed the point of no return,” says a Wes leyan administrator. “The blacks are here in force and they are here to stay.”
author: By Richard J. Margolis

headline: A Scenario For the Fireworks At Tet
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Will the enemy launch an offensive during the Tet Lunar New Year holidays next month?

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Credit for Nixon

headline: U.S. SAYS VIETCONG SHOT 2 PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP) — The United States Command said today that the Vietcong had hauled two Amer ican captives from one village to another, placed them on ex hibition and then shot them to death.

headline: Hybrid Rice Helps Vietnamese Farms
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam— A middle‐aged man with mud‐stained ankles plods be hind a water buffalo in a landlord's flooded rice field, while hoping that the com batants on both sides of the war will leave him alone. That has been the picture of the South Vietnamese farm er for the past five years.
author: By James Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Austerity Chokes Vietnam Business
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam— Like a patient undergoing harsh cure, the South Viet namese economy was still gasping at the end of 1969 from a dose of bitter medi cine administered in the fall by President Nguyen Van Thieu.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Penn Central Service

headline: War‐Prisoners' Committee Opens Office Here Today
lead_paragraph: The Committee of Liaison With Families of Servicemen Detained in North Vietnam, or ganized by antiwar activists to facilitate the exchange of mail between American prisoners held in North Vietnam and their families, opens its office today at 365 West 42d Street, accord ing to the chairman of the group.

headline: Saigon: Funds Needed Urgently
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—As South Vietnam concluded a decade of war and faced the prospect of a reduced American presence in the coming dec ade, the need to attract foreign capital for reconstruction and growth took on a special urgency.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon's Nov. 3 Speech: Why He Took the Gamble Alone
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18— President Nixon's State of the Union Message Thursday is eagerly awaited in Washington, but it is not likely to be as revealing or profoundly impor tant—to him, to his staff, per haps even to the country— as his speech to the nation on Viet nam last Nov. 3.
author: By Robert B. Sempie Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Cyclists Race in Vietnam With Politics in Tandem
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 18—With army helicopters circling overhead for protec tion, 73 riders set off this morn ing on what must qualify as the world's most hazardous sports event: a six‐day bicycle race through half the length of South Vietnam.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Students and Soldiers Protest Closing of Antiwar Coffeehouse
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 18— One of the loudest, if not the largest, protest marches ever held in this city took place without incident today over the closing of the UFO, one.of the nation's first antiwar cof feehouses.

headline: Brody Says Drugs Inspired Giveaway
lead_paragraph: Michael I. Brody Jr., who has been writing checks to strangers for thousands Of dollars, says he made his decision to give away what he calls it $25‐million inheri tance while “I was tripped out on drugs.”
author: By Nancy Moran

headline: Cities Changing Shapes
lead_paragraph: Asia's cities are pouring more of their re sources into solving the problems that spring from rapid population increases. Expressways are unrolling in Japan and Australia. Singa pore is in the middle of a housing boom. But for the urban centers in South Vietnam, the struggle is to rebuild, a process that will re quire major aid from foreign sources.

headline: U.S. Airmen's Wives in Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 18 (AP)—The wives of four United States airmen missing for four years arrived here today hoping for information about their hus bands from North Vietnamese or Pathet Lao officials. The women, all from California, said they had written to North Viet namese and Pathet Lao officials in Laos several times without getting replies.

headline: 3 U.S. Helicopters Shot Down, Bringing War's Total to 3,342
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 (AP)—Three American heli copters were shot down over the weekend, the United States command said today. Five crew men were wounded.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) —The Defense Department to day the names of the following servicemen from the New York: area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: Peace Groups Picket Cahn Over Ban on Flag Symbols
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 19— About 100 representatives of peace groups picketed the of fices of Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn today to protest his ruling that the use of an American flag with symbols displayed across its face was a violation of state law.

headline: Marine Is Acquitted in Vietnam Killing
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19—An American Marine captain was acquitted tonight by a general court‐martial of the premeditated murder of a North Vietnamese prisoner of war.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Protests Broadcasts By Moscow on P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19—The Soviet Union said today that it would broadcast statements attributed to American prison ers in North Vietnam, and the State Department responded with a formal diplomatic com plaint.
author: By Peter Grose Special to The New York Times

headline: 18 Reported Killed by Enemy Mines at Training Base Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 — South Vietnamese military spokesmen said that 18 persons, including 16 South Vietnamese officer cadets and their instruc tor, were killed today when two Claymore mines that they say were planted by the Vietcong exploded in their training area about 12 miles northeast of Sai gon this morning.

headline: Three More Generals Reported Shifted by Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19—President Nguyen Van Thieu was reported today to have ordered the shifting of three more South Vietnamese commanding generals in what informed sources said was a major shake‐up brought about, at least in part, by American pressure to improve the per formance of the army.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Summer Offensive Expected
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18—An increasing number of senior American military planners are coming to believe that enemy commanders in Vietnam are building toward a major coun trywide offensive this summer, rather than next month as previously thought.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Artillery Commander In Copter Is Killed by Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (Reuters) — A Vietcong sharpshooter killed a United States Army colonel while he was flying in an observation helicopter, the United States command announced today.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Illegal War

headline: CONSPIRACY JURY HEARS EX‐U.S. AIDE
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 — A for mer high‐ranking Justice De partment official testified to day that the department made unsuccessful efforts to get Chi cago officials to negotiate with demonstrators prior to the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion here.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Galley Silent on Charges of Pre‐Songmy Murder
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 19 — First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with killing 109 Vietnamese men, women and children at Songmy, de clined to testify today at a hearing on an additional charge that he murdered a Vietnamese civilian about six weeks prior to the alleged Sonamy action.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Leftist Jailed in Tokyo
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Jan. 19 (Reuters)— A former leftwing student leader was given a 10‐month jail sentence today for having ordered six other students to invade a United States Army hospital in March, 1968. The court reserved judgment on six other radicals who led demonstrations protesting the opening of the hospital, at Camp Oji in Tokyo's northern suburbs, for treatment of wounded United States service men from Vietnam. Several hundred persons were injured in the rioting.

headline: 3 Copter Crewmen Rescued After Evading Foe 3 Days
lead_paragraph: I SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 (AP)—A rescue helicopter has located three American helicopter crewmen who had evaded the enemy for three days and lifted them to safety only 50 feet from a North Viet namese patrol, the United States Army announced today.

headline: Congress Learns Inflation Ranks As the Voters' Chief Concern
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Congress came back to the Capitol today with the state of the nation's economy as its chief concern.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu's Army Shifts
lead_paragraph: President Thieu's replacement of three major tac tical commanders in the Mekong Delta brings critical ly needed changes in the South Vietnamese Army.

headline: U.S. Voices Concern Over Intensity of Laos War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20—The United States expressed con ern today over the rising level of fighting in Laos. A State Department spokesman said it appeared that North Vietnam might be preparing to launch a “dry season offen sive” there.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Thant, in Paris, Says Saigon Needs Broad‐Based Regime
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 20 (AP)—Secre tary General Thant of the Unit ed Nations said today that South Vietnam's top priority was a “broad‐based govern ment.” He was immediately ac cused by Saigon's peace‐talk team of meddling.

headline: Murder Trial of a Sergeant In Vietnam Put Off 6 Weeks
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI)—The defense won a six‐week delay today in the court‐martial of a 20‐year‐old American solider charged with murdering a South Vietnamese man last September.

headline: Court Told Nixon Urged Galley Trial
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 20 — A report that President Nixon, Commander in Chief of American armed forces, had personally urged a murder trial for First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. was submitted today by defense counsel as an argument that the lieutenant could never receive a fair trial in a military court.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: '68 RIOT WARNING GIVEN TO CHICAGO
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 20—More than a month before the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion here, a United States Assistant Attorney General warned there might be a “na tional disaster” in Chicago's streets unless city officials and demonstrators developed a “working relationship.”
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: PAPAL AIDE, IN U.S., HOPEFUL ON NIGERIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20— Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, the Deputy Secretary of State at the Vatican, said today that he hoped that war‐torn Nigeria would accept relief aid from the Vatican..

headline: Atrocity Charges Studied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) —The Army told Representa tive Lionel Van Deerlin today that it was investigating charges that a United States infantry company used a South Viet namese village for “target prac tice.” The California Democrat released a letter from Maj. Gen. William A. Becker saying that reports that a ninth Infantry company division fired on vil lage huts in June, 1969, near Dongtam in the Mekong Delta were under active investiga tion. The allegations had been made by an Army doctor, Capt. J. L. Sugarman.

headline: BULLET IDENTIFIED IN PANTHER DEATH
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 20—A police firearms expert told a coroner's jury today that a bullet re covered from the body of the slain Black Panther leader Fred Hampton was from a 30‐caliber carbine.
author: By John Kifner Special to The New York Times

headline: Inquiry Finds No Violation by U.S. Military Network in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI)—Military investigators studying charges that the American Forces Vietnam Net work censors news broadcast to servicemen in the war zone agreed today that the network had not violated Defense De partment policies.

headline: U.S. Gives $50‐Million More To Pay for Saigon's Imports
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP)—The United States has given $50‐million more to South Vietnam to aid in financing im ports, it was announced today.

headline: Report Compiled in '68 Says Excessive Allied Bombing in South Vietnam Stirred Hostility to Regime.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON,. Jan. 21 — Some. South Vietnamese refu gees told American researchers in Saigon in 1968 of “exces sive and misdirected” allied bombing and shelling that made many of them hostile to the South Vietnamese Government.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: CHICAGO TRIAL TOLD OF A M'CARTHY PACT
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI)—A 1968 campaign aide to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy told a Fed eral court jury today that the Senator's staff antiwar protest leaders had an informal work ing agreement before and dur ing the turbulent Democratic National Convention.

headline: In The Nation: ‘Other Thoughts’ in Chicago
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 21—An air of unreality hangs over the trial of the so‐called “Chicago Seven,” and not merely be cause it keeps turning up such witnesses as Country Joe, the leader of the rock group known as Country Joe and the Fish.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Foe Shells 55 Targets in Heaviest Attacks in 7 Weeks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21—Enemy gunners fired rock ets and mortars into 55 military and civilian targets in South Vietnam last night in the most extensive shellings in seven weeks.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietcong Attack Delays Bicycle Race for 3 Hours
lead_paragraph: DINHQUAN, South Viet nam, Jan. 21 (AP) — The Vietcong delayed the Tour de Vietnam bicycle race for three hours today by attack ing South Vietnamese troops clearing the highway. One Government soldier was re ported killed.

headline: Aide Says Hanoi Will Not Publish Prisoner List
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 (Agence France‐Presse) — The chargé d'affaires of North Vietnam here said today that Hanoi would not publish the list of American pilots it holds prisoner.

headline: Saigon Delegation Arrives In Israel to View Defenses
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV, Jan. 21 (Reuters) —A seven‐man South Vietnam ese delegation led by Senator Tran Van Don, a former gen eral who now is a member of the South Vietnamese Senate Committee for National Secu rity, arrived here today to study technical aspects of the Israeli defense forces.

headline: Naval Officer Killed in War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) —Lieut. Terrence P. Ryan of Summit, N. J., of the Navy, has died of wounds suffered in the Vietnam war, the Pentagon an nounced today.

headline: Army Acts to Close Coast Coffee House Where G.I.'s Relax Off Duty and Damn the War
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 21 —In a quiet block far from the noise and the neon glitter of Tacoma's G.I. town, the coffee house sits almost hid den in a narrow, shabby store front.
author: By Earl Caldwell Special to The New York Times

headline: ...and on Foreign Policy
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's promise of a separate “State of the World” report to Congress may explain in part why he limited his foreign‐policy comments to gener alities. But, in that case, it is puzzling why he gave the subject 1,000 words of platitudes and optimistic predictions of peace in our time, skimming over some of the grimmer realities that face the United States.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: French Arms to Arabs

headline: President Terms Prospect For Peace Much Improved
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22—The prospects for peace Vietnam were described today by President Nixon as far greater than they were a year ago. He foresaw a good pros‐ pect of “a generation of unin terrupted peace” for America.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Another Folk Singer Silenced By Judge at Conspiracy Trial
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 — Songs and movements have no place in the Chicago conspiracy trial, Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled today.
author: BY J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Journalists Stuck in Elevator In Chicago City Hall
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) — Eleven Soviet newsmen, on their way to visit Mayor Rich ard J. Daley today, got trapped in a City Hall elevator.

headline: Transcript of the President's State of the Union Message to Joint Session of Congress
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's State of the Union Message to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: ANTIWAR GROUP ASKS F.C.C. FOR AD RULING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22—The Business Executive Move for Vietnam Peace charged today that the rejection of its radio spot commercials is a denial of free speech and violation of the Federal Communications Commission's fairness doctine.
author: By Terry Robards

headline: New Type of Miracle Rice Is Being Planted in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 22 (Reuters)— A new strain of “miracle” rice that combines high yields with better taste is being introduced to South Vietnam, which is al ready nearing self‐sufficiency in its staple food, the United States Embassy said today.

headline: Army Has New Suspect
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) — The Army reported today that it had added another sol dier to the list of those being investigated for possible charges in the alleged massacre at the South Vietnamese village of Songmy. Thirty‐two soldiers and former soldiers are now considered suspects. The latest suspect was not identified.

headline: Javits Arrives in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (UPI)—Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York arrived in South Vietnam today on his first visit here in four years. The Senator, who is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told newsmen that he planned to study the Vietnamization pro gram, the withdrawal of United States forces and foreign policy relations between the United States and the Government of South Vietnam.

headline: Saigon Bans Issue of Life
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (Reuters)—The South Vietnamese Government today banned the Jan. 19 issue of Life magazine, saying an article on the alleged massacre at Songmy included “extremely violent” pictures.

headline: FOE IS STEPPINGUP ACTIVITY IN DELTA
lead_paragraph: CHAUDOC, South Vietnam, Jan. 21—Here on the edge of the Mekong Delta and else where in the flat, fertile area life has become dangerous for civilians in recent months and progress of the pacification pro gram has slowed.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 72 of Enemy Reported Killed in Delta
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (AP)—Striking from a forest stronghold, enemy forces assaulted a command post of a South Vietnamese Marine bri gade in what was termed the biggest attack in the Mekong Delta in two months.

headline: Vietcong, in Paris, Allege a Massacre
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 22—The Viet cong asserted today that South Korean and South Vietnamese troops massacred more than 700 villagers last November in a pacification sweep command ed by Americans.

headline: A HANOI BUILD‐UP IN LAOS REPORTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — Officials of the State Depart ment said today that North Vietnam had recently massed more troops and military sup plies on the edge of the Plaine des Jarres in Laos than ever before.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: COURT BARS PAPER ON NONVIOLENCE
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 23—An un equivocal stand against violent demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion here was read into the record at the Chicago con spiracy trial today.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Cyclists End Race In South Vietnam With No Casualties
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 (AP)—The South Viet namese Government demon strated today that it could con duct a bicycle race along 290 miles of its roads so long as several thousand soldiers were available to protect the cyclists.

headline: TWO B‐52 MISSIONS REPORTED BY U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 (Reuters) — A United States spokesman said today that B‐52's struck targets around a Mekong Delta prov ince today and in a province near Saigon.

headline: Fighting is Repor??d
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 23 (UPI)—North Vietnamese reg ulars and Pathet Lao guerrillas were reported gaining ground against Laotian defenders today in a three‐pronged drive to take the strategic Plaine des Jarres.

headline: Topics: A Natural Refuge in a Predatory World
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.
author: By Brooks Atkinson

headline: Do We Need Those Troops in Europe?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—With “Viet namization” of the Vietnam war sufficiently established in the conversation of this city that most statesmen can roll the word out without dropping a syllable, there now is a new semantic challenge: the “Euro peanization” of the defense of Europe.

headline: STATE DEMOCRATS URGE END TO WAR
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 24— The Democratic State Com mittee urged President Nixon today “to move promptly and decisively toward a complete military withdrawal” from Viet nam.
author: By Thomas P. Ronan Special to The New York Times

headline: Court on Protesters
lead_paragraph: In 1967, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, then director of the Selective Service, sent a letter to draft boards throughout the country in which he encouraged them to accelerate induction of young men who turned in their draft cards in protest against the Vietnam war.

headline: Saigon Musician Jailed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (Reuters)—A Saigon military court has sentenced a young South Vietnamese musician to five years at hard labor for com posing antiwar songs, the Souht Vietnamese press agency said today. The musician was identi fied as Phan Van Thang, alsoi known as Mien Duc Thang.

headline: No Songs For judge
lead_paragraph: Judge Julius J. Hoffman, 74, has not been partial to young folk singers who have tried to sing their protest songs at the Chicago trial of seven defend ants charged with conspiring to start a riot at the 1968 Demo cratic national convention. Even the lilting soprano of pretty pop star Judy Collins did not move him last week. “No, no, no sing ing,” he ruled, when Miss Collins broke into a rendition of “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?” during her testimony for the de fense. “We are not here to be entertained.”

headline: DALEY AIDE'S TALK RECALLED IN TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 24—A radi cal leader and a lawyer for the City of Chicago traded barbed aphorisms on the eve of the 1968 Democratic National Con vention here, a witness told the Chicago conspiracy trial today.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Art Notes
lead_paragraph: ASERIES of lively, though unscheduled art events has been occurring at the Museum of Mod ern Art this past year—and not exactly with MOMA's wholehearted cooperation. I'm referring to the demon strations put on by the de termined and somewhat stud iedly seedy disorganization known as the Art Workers Coalition. (The AWC, in case you've just come in, is a loose‐knit group of museo phobic artists, writers, film makers and epheaneralists, who seek—without the aid of foundation money—to re form the art world structure. They have presented MOMA with an 11‐point list of de mands, ranging from free ad mission at all times to the establishment of a section de voted Ito the work of black and Puerto Rican artists.)
author: By Grace Glueck

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Korean Reprisal Policy

headline: ARMY FINDS RISE OF RACIAL TENSION IN STUDY OF BASES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 — A military survey of race relations at United States Army bases throughout the world has concluded that “all indications point to an increase in racial tensions.”
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: COEDUCATION AT BENNINGTON

headline: Bombers Strike in Delta And Northwest of Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 25—Waves of United States B‐52 bombers at tacked suspected enemy bases along the Cambodian and Lao tion borders northwest of Saigon yesterday and early today, mili tary, spokesman said.

headline: South Vietnam Charges Foe Killed 4,619 Civilians in '69
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (UPI)—South Vietnam pro tested to the International Con trol Commission today charg ing that 4,619 civilians were killed and 14,412 injured by Communist terrorist acts in 1969.

headline: Is South Africa next, after Vietnam is done?
lead_paragraph: It is 25 years since Cordell Hull, as Secretary of State, was lecturing the colonial powers “in relation to dependent peoples who aspire to liberty.” It is a dozen years since Richard Nixon, as Vice President, spent a month touring eight African states and came back to urge strong diplomatic links and a recognition of their development needs. It is 10 years since John Kennedy, as Presi dential candidate, paid $100,000 out of family funds for an airlift of 260 African students to American col leges, and so impressed men like Tom Mboya with this prompt gesture of practical help. Any number of anniversaries can be cited to suggest the time has come for a long and cool look at the relationship of the United States with independent Africa.
author: By Clyde Sanger

headline: Mr. Nixon, Reformer
lead_paragraph: In the lofty tones of his first State of the Union Message, President Nixon endeavored to give voice the state of the American mind. He placed his empha sis on the desire for peace rather than victory in Vietnam, on reform of existing institutions rather than creation of new ones at home, and on improve ment of the quality of life rather than on the quantity of material growth for the people of this country and the world.

headline: ANTIWAR SOLDIERS FACE ARMY TRIALS
lead_paragraph: FORT GORDON, Ga. Jan. 22 —Four Army privates who tried to open their own Investigation of war crimes are awaiting trial by special court‐martial on charges of undermining loyalty, morale and discipline.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Wilson Begins Trip to Washington
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Jan. 25 (AP)— Prime Minister Wilson of Britain arrived here today on his way to Washington for talks with President Nixon.

headline: U.S. War Outlays Aid Korea and Philippines
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—Sta tistics on United States spend ing for the war in Vietnam show that the conflict is provid ing significant benefits for the economies of South Korea and the Philippines as well as help ing to shore up their military establishments.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: ... and Troop Cuts
lead_paragraph: Financial pressures, and later the requirements of the Vietnam war, provided the original impetus in Washington for troop cuts in Europe. But the renewed debate has a very different financial base from that involved in the reductions that have already cut American forces in Europe by one‐quarter from the peak levels of the last decade.

headline: Javits Leaves Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25—Senator Jacob K. Javits Jeft Saigon today after a four‐day visit that he said had served to confirm his view that the United States should withdraw its troops from South Vietnam “at the earliest possible date.”
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Convoy in Ashau Valley Reported Attacked by U. S. Jets
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 26 (Reuters) — A United States military spokesman said today that helicopter gunships and Air Force fighter‐bombers attacked yesterday what was described as the first convoy of North Vietnamese supply trucks sighted in South Vietnam's Ashau valley since last summer.

headline: Calley Fund Angers Senator
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) — Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of. Ohio, re signed from the American Le gion today because, he said, one post has started raising funds to defend Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with mur dering civilians at My Lai, South Vietnam. The post is in Cleveland, and Senator‐ Young was a charter member of it.

headline: 4 Wives of Missing Pilots Tour Facilities in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (Reuters) — The wives of four United States airmen shot down over North Vietnam vis ited a military hospital here where wounded North Vietna mese prisoners are treated.

headline: Romney Says He'd Rather Stay In Cabinet Than Run for Senate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) — George Romney said today that he had no plans to run for Senator this year. But he declined to rule out the possibility that he or his wife might become a candidate if Michigan Republicans cannot agree on someone else.

headline: Thieu, Elected by 37 % in '67, Asks Runoffs in Presidential Races
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26—President Nguyen Van Thieu, who was elected in 1967 with only 37 per cent of the vote, proposed tonight that run‐off elections be held if no presidential candidate won a majority on the first ballot in future elections.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Samuels Makes His Campaign for Governor Official
lead_paragraph: Howard J. Samuels, who be gan putting together a cam paign organization 10 months ago, made it official yesterday by announcing that he would seek the Democratic nomina tion for Governor.
author: By Richard Reeves

headline: GOODELL ASSAILS U.S. WAR SPENDING
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Goodell told the Women's City Club yesterday that the time for rhetoric was past and the need now was for “money muscle” from Washington to meet the nation's urgent domestic needs.

headline: BATTLES INCREASE IN SOUTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (AP)—The United States Command reported today in creased battle action by both allied and enemy forces in all four military zones of South Vietnam.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) —The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: In the Midst of the War, a Placid Beach
lead_paragraph: VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 — Hunched low over their small motorbikes, four Americans in plastic helmets and motorcycle jackets roared down this afternoon from the hill overlooking this beach re sort and bounced over the sand to the edge of the sea.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Judge Says Daley Is ‘a Good Mayor’
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 — Judge Julius J. Hoffman said today that, as far as he was con cerned, Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was “a good Mayor.”
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Economic Impact of Vietnamization Plan Is Debated
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26— President Nguyen Van Thieu said in Saigon a couple of weeks ago that he was com piling a list of arms, materials and funds that he expected to get from the United States as American troops are withdrawn and South Vietnamese forces take over more of the fighting.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: CALLEY CHARGES FOUND UNCLEAR
lead_paragraph: FORT PENNING, Ga., Jan. 27 (AP)—The Army must spell out whether it will try to prove) that First Lieut. William L. Cal‐1 ley Jr. personally killed Viet namese civilians ordered others! to do it, or both, a military, judge ruled today.

headline: U.S. Is Reported to Have Hired Sihanouk Foes for '67 Missions
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — The United States used a Cam bodian sect dedicated to the overthrow of the legitimate government of Cambodia on covert missions into that coun try in 1967, according to testi mony at the trial of a Green Beret captain convicted in 1968 of killing one of the members of the sect.

headline: Report Shows U.S. Pays Taxes To Nations Getting Military Aid
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) —In a two‐year period, while the United States committed ex tensive sums for the war in Vietnam, South Vietnam col lected $28‐million to $34‐mil lion in taxes from the United States Government.

headline: 15 Football Stars Picked To Tour U.S. Military Bases
lead_paragraph: Four men who competed in a recent National and Ameri can Football League champion ship series are among 15 play ers named yesterday to tour United States military bases, hospitals and outposts in the far east, including the war zones of South Vietnam.

headline: Chicago Police Aide Says Ohio Professor Hit Him
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP)—A high police official testified to day that a Cleveland professor hit him and threw a traffic bar rier toward a sergeant in street disorders the week of the Democratic National Conven tion in 1968.

headline: AN ANTIWAR VOTE ASKED IN ASSEMBLY
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Jan. 27—Hoping for a lively debate, if not ap proval, 26 Assembly Democrats introduced a resolution today urging immediate withdrawal from Vietnam by United States troops.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: Elmira G.I. Killed in Vietnam
'68 YIPPIE PLANS STUNNED MAILER
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 27—“Wow!” said Norman Mailer when he first heard the Yippie strategy for the 1968 Democratic Nation al Convention here.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Weighs Tet Truce
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Jan. 28 (AP) — President Nguyen Van Theiu is planning to order a cease‐fire for the Tet lunar new year but has not decided the length or timing, a Govern ment spokesman said today.

headline: Nixon and Wilson Discuss Major Issues
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27—In what has become an almost an nual rite of British‐American friendship, Prime Minister Wil son arrived here amid pomp and ceremony for a round of talks with President Nixon and other senior United States offi cials.

headline: U.S. COURT IS ASKED TO RULE ON FLAG USE
lead_paragraph: A Federal judge in Brooklyn said yesterday he would seek the convening of a three‐judge constitutional court to rule on the use of peace symbols in conjunction with the American Flag.

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) —The Pentagon announced to day the names of 19 American servicemen killed in Vietnam. The list included Specialist 4 Nathaniel Thomas, of the Army, of Elmira, N. Y.

headline: New U.S. Pullback From South Vietnam Is Beginning Today
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP)—The withdrawal of 50,000 more American troops will begin tomorrow with 3,000 marines from 19 units leaving over a five‐day period, the, United States Command an nounced today.

headline: Garden Thronged for Songfest In Aid of Vietnam Moratorium
lead_paragraph: A capacity crowd of 21,000 was at Madison Square Garden last night to see performers ranging in style from East Har lem to Las Vegas in a benefit for the Vietnam Moratorium Committee.
author: By Mike Jahn

headline: U.S. TROOPS UNCOVER BIG NEW ARMS CACHE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)—United States troops searching through a huge enemy arms cache in the jungles northwest of Saigon uncovered two and a half tons of arms and nearly 250,000 rounds of ammunition, American head quarters said today.

headline: 65% in Poll Support Nixon Policy on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28— Support for President Nixon's. Vietnam policies is holding firm, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Transit as State Issue

headline: CENSORSHIP DENIED BY U.S. COMMAND
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)—The United States command today denied charges that unfavorable news reports were censored by the Armed Forces Vietnam Network.

headline: Chicago 7 Judge Bars Ramsey Clark As Defense Witness
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 —Judge Julius J. Hoffman barred Ram sey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, from testifying today as a witness for the defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) —The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
lead_paragraph: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

headline: SAIGON ‘NEWSMEN’ WERE U. S. AGENTS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) — American officials said today that two United States Government agents were infiltrated into the Saigon press corps but were withdrawn aft er their identity had been ex posed.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Responding to the firing at an Ameri can reconnaissance plane over North Viet nam, American fighter‐bombers attacked a missile site inside North Vietnam on Wednes day, the United States command in Saigon announced early today. One of the attack ing planes and a rescue helicopter were shot down. Washington officials said the incident did not reflect a change in American pol icy. [Page 1, Column 1.]

headline: Two Testify That Professor Was Beaten at Convention
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP)— Two free lance photographers testified yesterday that they saw a deputy superintendent of police beat an antiwar leader during street violence the week of the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention.

headline: Bunker Says Enemy Remains A ‘Force to Be Reckoned With’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 29—The United States Ambas sador, Ellsworth Bunker, today described 1969 as a year of meaningful progress in South Vietnam, but conceded that the enemy “is still a military force to be reckoned with.”

headline: ‘Silent Majority,’, U.S.I.A. Film, Fails To Stir Foreigners
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29— “The Silent Majority,” a con troversial film produced by the United States Information Agency to show that President Nixon has ample public sup port for his policies in Vietnam, has been less than a smash hit abroad.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Antiwar Group Planning Feb. 14 Parley on Tactics
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) —A student antiwar group an nounced today a conference, open to the entire antiwar movement, in Cleveland Feb. 14–15 to plan a spring ac tion campaign.

headline: SEALE, PEACEABLE, RETURNS TO TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 29—Bobby G. Seale returned to the Chicago conspiracy trial today and fi nally got a chance to speak out at length.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: No Relief for the Riders...
lead_paragraph: The much‐abused riders on all the mass transit lines in the metropolitan area are on the verge of open rebel lion. The latest affront is the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority's order for higher fares on the Long Island Rail Road, effective tomorrow—an order so certain to stir additional outrage that the Long Island trainmen are threatening to strike unless they get police protection.

headline: U.S. PLANES MAKE RETALIATORY RAID IN NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 30—United States fighter‐bombers attacked an antiaircraft missile base 90 miles inside North Vietnam on Wednesday after an unarmed American reconnaissance plane was fired upon by missiles, they American command announced here early today.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 U.S. AGENTS POSED AS SAIGON NEWSMEN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 29 (AP)—Four United States Government in vestigators—not two—were in filtrated into the Saigon press corps to spy on the newsmen, official sources conceded today.

headline: U.S. Denies Violation
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 29—The United States affirmed today that it sends reconnaissance planes over North Vietnam with fighter escorts, but denied that this violated the 1968 understand ing that halted the bombing raids.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Aide Rules Out Any Forced Concessions
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 31 (UPI)—The chief adviser of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks here returned to day from consultations in Hanoi and said that his Gov ernment was ready for seri ous negotiations. However, he said that Hanoi would make no concessions at the negotiating table under United States military pres sure.

headline: Nixon to Decide in Month On Israel's Arms Requests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — While insisting that he was not partial to either side in the continuing conflict in the Mid dle East, President Nixon said this evening that he would decide within a month how many more weapons the United States would sell to Israel.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Denies Agents Posed as Newsmen To Spy on the Press
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30—The United States Mission said in a statement issued here today that four agents fraudu lently accredited as newsmen had been on a mission “com pletely unrelated to the local Vietnamese and foreign press corps or their activities.”

headline: BATTLE IN VIETNAM NOW IN QUESTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)—Offi cers said today that reports yesterday of a major battle be tween United States soldiers and enemy battalions near Tay ninh had been made by a unit commander and that “we are not convinced” of the accuracy of the reports.

headline: Defense Nears End of Chicago 7 Case
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 30—The de fense in the Chicago conspiracy trial neared the end of its case today in a session marked by the appearance of several prominent witnesses.
author: By J. Antiiony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine Killed in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) —Lance Cpl. Erick W. Beattie of Staten Island, a marine, has been killed in action in Viet nam, the Pentagon announced today.

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: The Washington Record
Earlier Clashes Over the North Conceded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 — The United States com mand acknowledged today that there had been periodic air‐to ground engagements in North Vietnam since the bombing halt 15 months ago that had not been made public because they were considered to be “insig nificant.”
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet‐Hanoi Trade to Rise
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 28 (Reuters)—The North Vietnam ese have signed an agreement with the Russians increasing their exchange of goods by 30 per cent this year, the North Vietnamese press agency said today. North Vietnam will ex port ready‐made clothes and other consumer goods in ex change for fuel, textiles and other comomdities, the report said.

headline: LINDSAY SCORES MIDEAST POLICY
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 28 — Mayor Lindsay sharply criticized tonight the Administration's policy in the Middle East, warn ing that to assume the role of a “benevolent neutral” would be tantamount to an “abdica— tion of our moral responsi bility.”
author: By Irvng Spiegel;Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine ‘Just for Laughs,’ Canadian Returns a Hero
lead_paragraph: CAMP PENDLETON; Calif. Feb. 28 (AP)—Cpl. Robert Dalton a young‐Canailian Who says he Joined the United States Marine Corps “just for laughs,” is going home a hero, the holder of the Nayy Cross.

headline: Cambodia Frees 5 U.S. Sailors Who Crossed Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 (UPI)—Cambodia re leased today the five United States Navy men who “were captured Feb. 5 when an American gunboat sailed up the Mekong. River into Cam bodian territory, apparently by mistake.

headline: FOE SHOOTS DOWN 3 COPTERS IN DAY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 (AP) — The United States Command reported to day that three Army helicopters had been lost to enemy gunners in a single clav's action.

headline: Laos 1: New Round In a Pocket War
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — Last September the Government forces in this divided country scored an unexpected and spec tacular military success They drove the North Vietnamese in vaders and their feeble local client, the Pathet Lao, from the Plaine des Jarres, a strategic re gion in the mountainous north that lad‐beetrtheld by the Com inunists since 1964.

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: IN VIETNAM: THE FRONT VS. THE REAR

headline: Arbitrariness in Saigon
lead_paragraph: The Saigon Government has taken a tardy first step toward reversing a dangerously arbitrary action with its decision to order a new trial for a neutralist legis lator summarily convicted by a military court last week on charges of pro‐Communist activity and then roughly seized in his sanctuary in the National Assem bly. But it remains highly doubtful whether opposition leader Tran Ngoc Chau should ever have been brought to trial in the first‐place.

headline: Cyrus Eaton Says Hanoi May Soon Name Prisoners
lead_paragraph: Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist, said yesterday that he was confident the North Vietnamese would soon release a list of United States prison ers and would allow the cap tives to write their families.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Communication Policy

headline: CHICAGO 7 FREED ON $155,000 BAIL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Feb. 28—The seven defendants in the Chicago con spiracy trial were released from jail,today in a‘total of $155,000 bondAbout five hours after the United States Court of Appeals For the Seventh Circuit granted hero half the severimenwalked put of Chicago Federal Build Mg into a shonting crowd of supporters and newsmen.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas;Special to The New York Times

headline: Sihanouk Guides Affairs in Cambodia With Special Regard for the Chinese
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 22—Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Chief of State and absolute ruler of Cambodia, has told vis itors that if his country ever had become Communist it should be the Chinese who do the job, not the Vietnamese.
author: By Henry Kamm;Special to The New York Times

headline: Lieutenant Weds Sarah Ashton Nuese
lead_paragraph: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 28—St. Michael's Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Sarah Ashton Nuese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Nuese, to Lieut. Landon Ketchum Thorne 3d, U.S.M.C.R., a Vietnam veteran, who is sta tioned at Parris Island, S. C. He is the son of Mr. Thorne Jr. of New York and Boca Grande, Fla., and Mrs. Alice Barry Thorne of Rome.

headline: 5 Accused Marines Are Identified
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 (AP) — The United States Marines disclosed to day the names of five men charged with the murder of 16 Vietnamese women and children at Sonthang village Feb. 19. The five, all mem bers of a combat patrol, are: Lance Cpl. Randell D. Herrod, 20 years old, of Calvin, Okla.; Pfc. Thomas R. Boyd, 19, of Evansville, Ind.; Pfc. Michael S. Krichten, 19, of Hanover, Pa.; Pfc. Samuel G. Green, 18, of Cleveland and Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz, 21, of Weirton, W. Va. Of the five, only private Schwarz is married. All of the men havepeen decorated and three of them—Corporal Herrod and Privates Boyd and Krichten—hold the Pur ple Heart.

headline: In the End The Saigon Comedy Was Not Very Funny
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — The scene alter nated between comedy and tra gedy. There was the defiant op position legislator, Tran Ngoc Chau, spraying himself with de oderant and polishing his shoes with a dirty sock; while outside his refuge in the National As sembly, the police maneuvered into position for a raid that would end his four‐day sit‐in and send him to prison for the start of a 20‐year sentence at hard labor.

headline: Violence by Students Is Linked to Powerlessness
lead_paragraph: ISLA VISTA, Calif., Feb. 28 —As highway policemen pa trolled this small college town today, the University of Cali fornia campus community here searched for the Iroots of the recent violence that resulted in more than 100 arrests and in juries and the destruction of several buildings, including a bank.
author: By Steven V. Roberts;Special to The New York Times

headline: Another War:
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Fifteen years ago Graham Greene's English correspondent in “The Quiet American” strolled down Rue Catinat toward the Saigon wa terfront and observed, “I could see lamps burning where they had disembarked the new Amer ican planes.”
author: By Herbert Mitgang

headline: U.S. Officers Avoid Controversy In Murder Charge Against Five
lead_paragraph: LANDING ZONE BALDY, South Vietnam, Feb. 28—Amer ican officers at this base south of Danang, assigned to deal with the case against five young marines facing murder charges in the deaths of 16 South Vietnamese civilians nine days ago, appear to be taking pains to avoid the con trovorsy that surrounds the alleged massacre at Songmy..
author: By James P. Sterba; Special to The New York Times

headline: LAOTIAN PROTESTS TO BRITAIN, SOVIET
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 1 (Reuters)— The Laotian Gov ernment has sent a letter to Britain and the Soviet Union protesting North Vietnamese military activity in Laos, Bri tish diplomatic sources said to day..

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: President's Policy.

headline: Boston War Protest Planned
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 —The New England Antiwar Conference concluded a week end of deliberations at the Massachusetts Institute of Tech nology today after deciding to sponsor a mass nonviolent dem onstration in Boston on April 15 against the Vietnam war.

headline: Saigon Court Won't Let Chau Call U.S. Envoy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 2 (Reuters)— The chairman of a South Viet namese military tribunal today rejected a defense lawyer's re quest to call the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, to testify for the defense of Tran Ngoc Chau..

headline: Two Patrolmen Are Killed as Police Helicopter Crashes in Queens
lead_paragraph: Two patrolmen, one of whom a former Army heli copter pilot who had ‘been shot down twice in Vietnam, were killed yesterday when their Police Department heli copter crashed in the drive way of a Glen Oaks, Queens, home while on a routine traffic patrol.

headline: NEW AID APPROACH SOUGHT FOR ASIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 1—A task force in the State Depart ment has just begun work on confidential project to deter mine a new approach for eco nomic aid to Southeast Asia after the Vietnam war..
author: By Richard Halloran; Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52's STRIKE AGAIN ON HO CHI MINH TRAIL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 (AP)—With enemy activity in South Vietnam lim ited at present to terrorist and rocket and mortar attacks, United States B‐52 bombers were diverted again today to attacks on North Vietnamese supply depots along the Ho Chi Minh trail in eastern Laos, re liable sources said..

headline: Guard Pulled From Area Of California Student Riots
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 2 (AP)—The last National Guardsmen were withdrawn to day from the, community adja cent to the University of Cali fornia campus here, leaving local officers to deal with youths who last week fought policemen with rocks and bottles and burned a Bank of America to the ground.

headline: 25 STUDENTS HELD IN ILLINOIS PROTEST
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.,.March 2— Students and the police clashed on and around the, campus of the University of Illinois to night following an antiwar demonstration earlier against a General Electric Company recruiter.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) —The Pentagon today identi fied the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: B‐52'S BOMB DELTA CLOSE TO CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 2 (AP)—Twenty Ameri can B‐52 bombers rained tons of explosives today on the Seven Mountains region about eight miles from Cambodia in the Mekong Delta, where North Vietnamese troops are reported to have been en trenched for months.

headline: 2 SAIGON DEPUTIES FASTING FOR CHAU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 3—Two South Vietnamese deputies began a 48‐hour hunger strike in the lobby of the National Assembly building this morning to pro test the trial of Deputy Tran Ngoc Chau and what they termed other violations of the Constitution by President Ngu yen Van Thieu.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: TEN U.S. JUDGES ASK GUIDE ON CONTEMPT
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 2 (AP)— Ten Federal judges filed peti tions today asking the United States Court of Appeals for the seventh circuit for guidelines on contempt citations in connec tion with the Chicago riot trial.

headline: COMPUTER JUDGING PACIFICATION DRIVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 2 (AP)—United States officials disclosed a new method today for measuring pacifica tion of villages in South Viet nam.

headline: Indian Fans Divided Over Harrelson's Shorn Locks
lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz., March 2— In Cleveland, it seems, the hottest issue under debate is not civil rights and it's not the Vietnam war. It's Ken Harrelson's hair.
author: By Murray Chass Special to The New York Times

headline: A PLAN FOR VIETNAM PROPOSED BY VANCE
lead_paragraph: Cyrus R. Vance, former Unit ed States negotiator at the Paris talks, said last night that Presi dent Nixon's program of Viet namization made a settlement of the war in Vietnam too de pendent on what the enemy does.

headline: U.S. Aides Decline to Estimate Pullout Schedule
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3— Top United States military ad visers in Vietnam repeatedly declined to estimate at a public hearing in the Senate today how soon the South Vietnamese forces could take over the com bat responsibilities from the American troops.
author: By Tad Szulc;Special to The New York Times

headline: ALLIES REPORT 186 OF ENEMY KILLED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 (AP)—Military sources reported today that during the last 24 hours allied forces killed 186 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers in fighting ranging from the Mekong Delta to the central coast.

headline: Kunstler Urges Resistance To ‘Illegitimate Authority’
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI, March 3 (AP) —William M. Kunstler, an at torney for the Chicago 7, told a cheering crowd of 1,300 at the University of Cincinnati to day to “resist illegitimate au thoriey, let your voice be heard and don't stop until things changed.”

headline: Guard Deployed at the U. of Illinois
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 3— Several hundred National Guard troops were ordered onto the campus of the University of Illinois tonight to disperse crowd of 5,000 students and to enforce a 10:30 P.M. curfew.

headline: Albany Allows C.P.A.'s To Keep Silent on Clients
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, March 3—Final leg islative approval was voted to day on a bill to assure that communications between certi fied public accountants and their clients would not be divulged.
author: By Francis X. Clines;Special to The New York Times

headline: The High Stakes in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3— For almost a decade, the offi cial though private judgment here has been that the defense o Laos, the Asian kingdom of two and a half million people, is not in itself a vital interest of the United States
author: By Max Frankel;Special to The New York Times

headline: French Living in Saigon Cherish Old Memories
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnarq, March 4 — Business has not been quite so good for Mrs, Aimee Galaup, who owns the Lyne Flower Shop here, since” the French pulled out of Viet nam. That was 16 years ago.
author: By Oloria Emerson;Special to The New York Times

headline: Daley and Judge Hoffman Praised by Oklahoma House
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 4 (AP) — The House passed a resolution today commending Chicago Mayor, Richard J. Daley and United States District Judge Julius J. Hoffman for their conduct during the Demo cratic convention riots and the trial of the Chicago seven.

headline: Bomb Found and Disarmed At Oakland Army Barracks
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif., March 4 (UPI)—A time bomb was dis covered today in a barracks at the Oakland Army Base, a major shipping point for troops going to Vietnam.

headline: In The Nation Waist‐Deep in the Little Muddy
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Kunstler Talk Allowed
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, March 4 (UPI)— The acting president of the State University at Albany said today that. his administration would make no attempt to ban a speech by the Chicago Seven defense attorney, William M. Kunstler, on campus tomorrow night. Dr. Allan Kuusisto said he hoped there would be no violence when Mr. Kunstler addressed the student body in the campus gymnasium.

headline: SMUGGLING OF FUNDS FROM SAIGON IS SEEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4— American civilian pilots are illegally flying about $400,000 weekly in checks and cash out of Saigon to black market money changers in Bangkok, Thailand, according to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut.

headline: U.S. JETS ATTACK GUNS IN CABODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 5 (AP)— American fighter‐bombers at tacked enemy gun positions in Cambodia two days ago after a South Vietnamese district town along the border was struck by mortars, the Unitec States command reported today

headline: National Guard Deployed Again at U. of Illinois
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 4—About 450 National Guard troops were called to the University of Illinois campus tonight for the second night in a row to enforce a curfew as student demonstrations continued.

headline: Chau Convicted, but Sentence Is Cut
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 5 (AP) — A military court today convicted the National Assemblyman Tran Ngoc Chau for the second time of pro‐Communist activity, but reduced the 20‐year sentence gave him last week to 10 years.

headline: Connecticut Soldier Killed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) — The Defense Depart ment announced today that Specialist 4 Victor Del Greco Jr., of Manchester, Conn., of the Army had been killed in action in Vietnam.

headline: Vietnam Peace Talk Session Cut Short
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 5—The United States again pressed the Com munist delegations at the Viet nam peace conference today to give details on American pris oners.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: RED FORCE IN LAOS IN STRONG POSITION
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March —With about three months of dry weather ahead, the North Vietnamese were holding‐ the same ground in Laos today that they; occupied last year at the end of their annual dry season offensive. This puts the Communist forces in a strong position.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Support for Judiciary

headline: Thieu and Chau; Prosecution of Opposition Deputy Viewed as Naked Display of Power
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5 — The conviction of Tran Ngoc Chau today on charges of pro‐Communist ac tivities is the culmination of what independent observers here agree has been the most naked display of presidential power by Nguyen Van Thieu since his election in 1967. The
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Dellinger Says Chicago 7 Presented ‘Rational’ Case
lead_paragraph: David Dellinger, one of the defendants in the Chicago Sev en conspiracy trial, said yester day that the defendants had tried to present’ a “rational, lu cid explanation” of their case.

headline: Muskie Assails Nixon on War, Calls for New National Debate)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5 Senator Edmund S. Muskie charged today that the Nixon Administration',s Vietnam poli cies “cannot bring peace.”
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: 113 Americans Killed in Week; War Toll Highest in 3½ Months
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5 (AP) — American bat tle deaths rose past 100 last week for the first time this year, despite relatively light enemy activity, the United States command reported today.

headline: Chau, Sentenced, Says He Will Serve Nation Again After Peace
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5—Tran Ngoc Chau, National Assembly member who was sentenced to 10 years at hard labor today on charges of having been in contact with the Communists, said later that he would resume his service to his country “after peace has been restored.”
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) —The. Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: After Dark in Queson Valley: ‘If It Moves, Shoot It’
lead_paragraph: QUESON, South Vietnam, March 3—The dust of the dry season is beginning to blow in the faces of the United States marines in this desolate valley again as the northern monsoon clouds lift and the sun heals the mud ruts in the 10‐mile road that threads from the paved coastal highway to this district capital.
author: By James P. Sterba;Special to The New York Times

headline: Guardsmen Are Withdrawn After Illinois U. Protest
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, III., March 6 (UPI)—Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie today recalled the 750 National Guardsmen he had ordered to the University of lipnois cam pus to control violent student demonsteations.

headline: INJUNCTION DELAYS TRIAL OF WAR FOES
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 6 —Judge James F. Gordon of the United States District Court issued a temporary injunction today prohibiting Meade County officials from prosecuting six supporters of an antiwar cof feehouse in Muldraugh, Ky., on indictments returned Feb. 16.

headline: Group Asserts That Hanoi Has Identified 14 P. O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: An antiwar organization an nounced yesterday it had re ceived a cable from the Gov ernment of North Vietnam con firming that 14 American serv icemen were being held as prisoners of war.

headline: GOODELL EXPLAINS SENATE POSITIONS
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, March 6—“You made a lot of friends in your last speech last fall, a local Republicazi official in Rome, N. Y., toldSenator Charles E. Goodell this morning but then you went back to Waqhingtonl and lost them all.
author: By Richard L. Madden;Special to The New York Times

headline: Rutgers Speech by Rubin Delayed by Bomb Scare
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 6—A speech at Rutgers University by Jerry Rubin, one of the defendants in the Chi cago Seven conspiracy trial, was interrupted by a bomb scare tonight.

headline: Even the Postcards in Saigon Depict G.I.'s n Battle
author: By Gloria Emerson;Special to The New York Times

headline: Ghosts of Vietnam Haunt the Report on Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6— The ghosts of bitter memory in Vietnam haunt P:esident Nixon's first formal report to the nation on Laos today.
author: By Max Frankel;Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Aide Blames U.S. for Chau Trial
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 — A top official in the South Vietnamese Government sought today to divert criticism of the conviction of Deputy Tran Ngoc Chau to the United States Embassy.

headline: FIGHTING RAGES NEAR CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (AP)—Sharp fighting raged in a jungle near the Cambodian border today be tween a company of American riflemen and a North Vietna mese force believed to be guarding enemy supplies, the United States command said.

headline: Brooklyn Man Killed in War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)—The Defense Depart ment announced today the names of 10 men killed in the Vietnam war. Among them was George T. Olsen of Brooklyn, a Specialist 4 of the Army.

headline: ALBANY WEATHERS KUNSTLER SPEECH
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, March 7—“Offi cials at the university are cau tiously optimistic that trouble can he avorted!”
author: By Francis X. Clines;Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese Senate Passes Land Reform Bill
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (UPI)—The South Vietnamese Senate has passed major land reform legislation sought by President Nguyen Van Thieu to permit the Gov ernment to give free land to soldiers and war widows.

headline: U. S. UNITS BATTLE FOE NEAR BORDER
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (AP) — United States troops operating in jungle neat the Cambodian border clashed today for the second day in. row with North Vietnamese troops believed to be protecting caches of rice and arms, allied spokesman said.

headline: Chicabo 7 Lawyers Post Bond in Contempt Case
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI)— William M. Kunstler and Leon ard Weinglass, attorneys for the Chicago 7 in their recent con spiracy trial, posted bond today on the contempt sentences im posed on them by United States District Judge Julius J. Hoff man after the trial.

headline: Rapping With The Panthers In White Suburbia; Suburbanite What do the Panthers want in the long run? Black Panther The overthrow of the capitalist‐racist system.
lead_paragraph: ONE evening late in December was invited along with 20 other white suburbanites to to meet and question two Black Panther leaders in a plush, 14‐room, Westchester home, set on three‐and a‐half wooded acres. The confronta tion was filmed for three hours by the news department of a major net work. The producer and his stars ar rived, appropriately, 20 minutes late and were then seated on a very nice soft, blue couch facing a semicircle of whites. The living room was large and furnished in a style best described as “indifferent Colonial.”
author: By Gnrald Emanuel Stearn

headline: Nixon Tries Diplomacy On Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The North Vietnamese and their Pathet Lao allies produced the first impor tant indication last week that their offensive in Laos is intend ed to force the United States into political concessions there— and perhaps in Vietnam. From Hanoi, the Pathet Lao informa tion bureau issued a five‐point statement Friday demanding, in essence, that the United States withdraw from Laos completely and that a new coalition govern ment be established under Pathet Lao domination.

headline: G.1.'s in Vietnam Mail ‘Flood’ of Guns to U.S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) —United States sol dders In Vietnam are sending a “veritable flood” of illegal automatic weapons and ex plosives through the mails into this country, according to Customs Commissioner Miles J. Ambrose.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: New Foreign Policy

headline: Hanoi P.O.W. Lists Include No New Names, U.S. Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 7 (Reu ters)—The Defense Department said in a statement today that not one of 27 United States prisoners of war named by North Vietnam this week was new to its list of known pris oners.

headline: Threat to Paris Talks?
lead_paragraph: The Soviet warning that Hanoi will shortly break off the Paris peace talks if the United States continues to downgrade them must be taken seriously, despite the refusal of North Vietnamese and Vietcong repre sentatives to confirm that they have such plans. The Soviet Ambassador to France, Valerian Zorin, is too old a diplomatic hand to have made such a prediction without instructions.

headline: U.S. JUDGE URGES DECORUM IN COURT
lead_paragraph: A Federal appellate court judge warned yesterday that obstreperous and disorderly conduct by defendants in court was threatening to become a “major epidemic.”
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: Bank to Reopen Branch Ruined in Coast Rioting
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (UPI) The Bank of America will reopen its burned out branch office near the University of California at Santa. Barbara next Monday, A. W. Clausen, president of the bank, an nounced Thursday.

headline: Laotian Reds Outline Peace Plan
