lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, Oct. 23—Vice President Agnew called Mayor Lindsay of New York “our po litical conglomerate” here to night. He also criticized the Mayor and others who have defended draft resisters.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: North Vietnam Will Receive More Soviet Arms and Aid
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP)— The Soviet Union has agreed to provide North Vietnam with additional military and eco nomic assistance. Tass, the So viet press agency, reported to day.

headline: U.S. Says Unit in Vietnam Used Banned Defoliant
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23—Troops of the Amer ical Division have violated Pentagon order by continuing to use a chemical defoliant identified as a factor in ani mal birth defects, the United States command said today.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Plundering South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The current war is destroying un told human and material resources South Vietnam. Not including the forces of the N.L.F., the army of the Republic of Vietnam numbers 1,000, 000 men; to this figure must be added the forces of self‐defense numbering 1.000,000 men, and police forces num bering 100,000 men.

headline: Brandt and Scheel Confident Coalition Rule Will Continue
lead_paragraph: BONN, Oct. 23—Chancellor Willy Brandt land his coalition partner, Foreign Minister Walter Scheel, held a joint news conference today to ex press confidence that they could surmount opposition pres sure and continue governing un til their term ran out in 1973.
author: By David Binder Special to The New York Times

headline: CLASSES OFFERED TO V. A. HOSPITALS
lead_paragraph: The city Board of Education has offered to set up special educational programs for hos pitalized veterans of the war in Vietnam.
author: By Leonard Buder

headline: North Vietnam to Punish Misuse of Public Office
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 24 (Agence France‐Presse)—A decree for the protection of government property has been promulgated by President Ton Duc Thang, the newspaper Nhan Dan reported today.

headline: 2 Students Sentenced In Anti‐Nixon Protest
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP) — Two University of Tennessee student have been sentenced to the Knox County Workkhouse on disorderly con duct charges stemming from President Nixon's visit to the Billy Graham Crusade on the campus last May 28.

headline: Education
lead_paragraph: Last January, a special Presi dential task force submitted rec ommendations on the needs of higher education to the White House. The document — and covering letter by Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University and chairman of the group — remained under wraps until recently, when it was made public without comment or ex planation.

headline: DISABILITIES RISING FOR U.S. VETERANS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. Oct. 24 (UPI) —The number of Vietnam vet erans receiving disability com pensation has risen from 8.287 ao 188,353 in less than threel years, the Veterpn5 Aclministra tion has announced. Compensa tion to veterans disabled while on active duty in the armed services during the Vietnam war now totals more than $285‐ million a year, the V.A. said Thursday.

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: Trouble for a judge is the judge giving an order and some one disobeying it. Last week, in a crowded courtroom on the 13th floor of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, John M. Murtagh had trouble.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Arthur Goldberg's response of firing two of his campaign aides who were heckling Governor Rockefeller during a campaign appearance on the Lower East Side deserves a bit more reflec tion than it was apparently given.

headline: Soldiers Arriving for Service in Vietnam Find Little Cheer in Nixon's Plan to Step Up Withdrawals
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Oct. 13—Pfc. John McIntell, a 23‐year‐old electrician from the Bronx, is not cheered by Presi dent Nixon's announcement of the accelerated withdrawal of troops from Vietnam.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Fighting in Vietnam Reduced as Storm Approaches Coast
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24 (AP)—A typhoon cut into allied military operations today as it moved inland to ward the northern coast of South Vietnam and forced pre cautionary evacuation of a military hospital and some planes in Danang.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The at mosphere in the Oval Room of the White House was de liberately casual and relaxed last Thursday as the photog raphers and reporters bustled briefly around President Nixon and his Soviet guests. They fell into easy ban ter.

headline: Morale Sag Afflicts Career Servicemen
lead_paragraph: The morale of the profes sional American fighting man has been shaken by the frustra tions of Vietnam, a wave of antimilitarism in the United States, race troubles, drugs and reverses and scandals in indi vidual services like the Sonmy affair.
author: By Drew Middleton

headline: Thieu Ends Parley, but Saigon Gives No Details
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25—President Nguyen Van Thieu has ended a two day meeting with all of South Vietnam's major appointed of ficials, but there is no Indica tion that any major decisions were made at the gathering, the most comprehensive in re cent memory there.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Palme Critical on War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) —Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden said today that the Vietnam war was a civil war, not aggression by the north against the south, and the sooner the United States recog nized this, the sooner peace would come.

headline: FOREIGN LEADERS MEET WITH NIXON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25— President Nixon conferred at the White House today with six foreign heads of state and gov ernment then flew to his Camp David retreat in Maryland to rest overnight and prepare for another round of personal diplomacy here tomorrow.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Rehabilitation Is Rare for Vietnam's Many Wounded Civilians
lead_paragraph: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam —One of the most wretched problems facing the Saigon Government is civilian war cas ualties—rehabilitation for the, hundreds of thousands who are maimed.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. CASUALTIES IN LAOS REPORTED I IN SECRET ACTIONS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25—Highly placed sources said today that United States Special Forces troops leading clandestine operations in Laos had suffered casualties in re cent months that never had been made public.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your highly partisan editorial of Oct. 16 in support of Dr. Harvey B. Scribner's refusal to testify in court on behalf of the existing examination procedures for school principals does little service to the cause of better school leadership selection that it hopes to promote.

headline: Ceausescu Visits Nixon at the White House for Talks on World Issues
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26— President Nixon discussed Indochina, Communist China, the Middle East and Euro pean security for two hours today with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, who maintains cordial relations with all the sides in the con flicts. Mr. Ceausescu arrived by helicopter from Williams burg, Va., to a colorful recep tion on the White House lawn. The talks ran 30 min utes overtime, forcing a de lay in a luncheon for the Ru manian leader at the State Department. Mr. Nixon went out of his way to publicize President Ceausescu's two‐ day stay in Washington even though he had already been entertained at the White House on Saturday at a din ner for 31 chiefs of state and government who were in the United States for the 25th anniversary of the United Nations. Mr. Ceausescu was the only Communist head of state to attend the celebra tions, and the Nixon Admin istration, pleased with Ruma nia's independent foreign pol icies in the Communist world, displayed warm friendship for him. This afternoon Mr. Ceausescu met with Secretary of State William P. Rogers, George F. Shultz, director of the White House Office of Man agement and Budget, and Sec retary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin. Then President Ceausescu and his wife attend ed a White House dinner.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Recess for Election. Hurts College Athletic Finances
lead_paragraph: Ohio Wesleyan University has 80 athletes on its football roster. Last Friday, however, when the school began a two‐ week election recess, Coach Jack Fouts had to trim 27 members temporarily from the toorra.

headline: Shadow Over Fort Hood
lead_paragraph: The first court martial of a United States soldier on charges growing out of the alleged massacre of Viet namese civilians at Mylai thirty months ago, has been seriously compromised by the action of a House Armed Services subcommittee that investigated the Mylai incidents.

headline: Army Begins Moving to Rescind General's Controversial Medal
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 (AP)—The Army command in Saigon has recommended that an American general be stripped of the nation's third highest award for valor in combat because it was based on a fabricated citation. Informed sources disclosed that Army headquarters here were awaiting approval from authorities in Washington, in cluding the Department of the Army, before taking action to withdraw a Silver Star from Brig. Gen. Eugene P. Forrester.

headline: CAMBODIA DRIVE OPENED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 (AP)—Led by two armored columns and supported by American artillery, 6,000 South Vietnamese troops were report ed to have pushed into the war ravaged Cambodian town of Snoul today in a new offensive.

headline: TRIAL OF BLACK G.I. OPENS IN GERMANY
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 26—Sgt. James Earl Hob son, who was arrested 43 times as a youth in Chicago's black ghetto and who was later dec orated for heroism in Vietnam, went on trial before a general court‐martial today on charges of attempted murder and con spiracy.
author: By David Binder Special to The New York Times

headline: Asia Expert Says Peace Talks Must Be Widened
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26—A former Government specialist on Asia said today that allied intervention in Cambodia had made it “almost impossible” to negotiate a Vietnam settlement in Paris without enlarging the talks to deal with Cambodia and Laos as well. Chester L. Cooper, former aide to W. Averell Harriman and for two decades a Govern ment official said at a news conference that he believed that President Nixon's latest proposal for an Indochina con ference and an Indochina cease fire reflected recognition that the Paris talks were unlikely to make much progress as pres ently constituted.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY COURT TOLD OF RACIAL TENSION
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 27—A United States Army prosecutor, opening his case against Sgt. James E. Hobson in a general court‐martial here, said today that he intended to show that the Vietnam battle field hero and one‐time Chicago delinquent had only aided and abetted others in a bloody grenade‐throwing incident.
author: By David Binder Special to The New York Times

headline: French Are Negotiating Trade Pact With Hanoi
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 27— France is negotiating a five‐ year commercial treaty with North Vietnam. This was dis closed today in a communique after a meeting of the Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community, or Com mon Market.

headline: G.I. Says He Cannot Recall Shooting at Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Oct. 27 (AP)—Specialist 4 Robert W. T'Souvas, one of 10 soldiers charged in the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, in South Vietnam, took the witness stand today at his pretrial hearing and said he did not remember whether he had shot two Vietnamese persons.

headline: Calley Returns to Vietnam to Prepare for His Defense
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 28—First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. re turned to South Vietnam to day to gather evidence to de fend himself against charges that he had killed more than 100 South Vietnamese in the alleged massacre at Sonmy in 1968.

headline: Saigon Forces to Push Deeper Into Cambodia in Search of Foe
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP) — The comman der of a new South Vietnamese offensive in Cambodia said to day that his forces would push deeper into that country to try to force the North Viet namese to fight.

headline: Students’ Interest in Campaign Found Ebbing as Election Nears
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 Student interest in politics has declined sharply since last spring, when hundreds of thou sands of young people demon strated against the incursion into Cambodia and the killings at Kent State.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Plans to Revoke General's Medals
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP)—The Army's Sai gon command is revoking two medals for bravery in combat that were awarded to Brig. Gen. Eugene P. Forrester on the basis of fictitious citations, an Army spokesman said tonight.

headline: Ceausescu Ends U. S. Visit After Meeting With Nixon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27—A United States Marine Corps hel icopter flew President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania on this gray autumn afternoon from the White House to Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, where he boarded a Soviet‐made airliner for the trip home.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Kheel Doubts the War Can Be Settled in Paris
lead_paragraph: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor negotiator, has con cluded as a result of recent talks with the various dele gations in Paris that the Viet nam war will not be settled in Paris.

headline: SAIGON UNITS REPORT BATTLE NEAR SNOUL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Thursday (Reuters) — South Vietnamese troops killed 44 guerrillas in a sharp clash near. Snoul in Cambodia, a military., spokesman said today.

headline: CALLEY IN SAIGON SEES ARMY AIDES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28—Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering at least) 102 South Vietnamese civilians, conferred with Army officials here today amid the secrecy of a crucial military operation.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Dines

headline: Gromyko, in Britain, Bars Wide Vietnam Parley Now
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 28 (UPI)— Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko told British leaders today that “the time is not ripe” for an international peace conference on Viet nam, Government officials said.

headline: MYLAI DEFENDANT ACCUSES ABRAMS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Oct. 28 — An Army Sergeant charged with murder at Mylai 4 has accused Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the commander of United States Army troops in South Vietnam, of allowing prisoners to be beaten and tortured in his presence.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Officials in Sweden Believe Anti‐Americanism Is on Wane
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 28—Unit ed States officials, seeking to strengthen their Government's shaky relations with Sweden, are convinced that the outpour ing of anti‐Americanism in recent years among students, radicals and politicians has steadily declined in the last few months.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Episcopal Bishops’ Stand

headline: Galley Returns to Area of the Alleged Massacre
lead_paragraph: SONMY, South Vietnam, Oct 29—The Vietnamese of Sonmy say that 570 civilians were massacred here on March 16 1968, when an American infan try company entered the area, but none of them know the name of Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr., nor what he looks like, nor do they understand why he was in Quangngai Province to day.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Voters in State Sampling Stress Moral Positions of Candidates
lead_paragraph: Most elections are decided by issues, candidate person ality and party loyalty. The findings of The New York Times / Yankelovich survey, conducted among a sample of 1.912 registered voters from all over the state, suggests this may be less applicable in the election for Governor and Senator.
author: By Daniel Yankelovich

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: Don't go away bored yet. The subject isn't quite dead. Chicago may have fallen on us last winter like a hail of cuckoo clocks and struck us dizzy; but the hour is past now and we may yet figure out what happened. Judging from this first trickle of serious books on the subject, there is still much to be said about the conspiracy trial of the Chicago Eight‐ Seven‐Nine (subtract Bobby Seale and add the defense lawyers William M. Kunstler and Leonard Weinglass). And I'm not in cluding Tom, Hayden's “Trial” (Holt, Rine hart & Winston, $4.95), which ought to be read, or Joseph Okpaku's “Verdict!: The Exclusive Picture Story of the Trial of the Chicago 8,” with drawings by Verna Sa dock (The Third Press, $7.95; paperbound, $3.95), which is so much poorly written scattershot. These two are partisan books and not what I have in mind at the mo ment.

headline: Beret Captain's Murder Conviction Is Overturned
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29—The 1968 murder conviction and sentence of a Green Beret cap tain involved in clandestine missions into Cambodia were set aside today by three judges of the Army Court of Military Review.

headline: How to Settle Vietnam
lead_paragraph: As one professionally interested in negotiation, I went to Paris to see if it looked like a negotiated settlement in Vietnam is possible.
author: By Theodore Kneel

headline: Lindsay in Buffalo
lead_paragraph: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Oct. 29 — Mayor Lindsay came here today to praise Arthur J. Gold berg but talked as if he came to bury the Nixon Administration.
author: By Frank Lynn Special to The New York Times

headline: Eggs and Rocks Thrown at Nixon After Coast Talk
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 29— Demonstrators threw eggs, rocks, and placards at Presi dent Nixon's limousine tonight as he left the San Jose Muni cipal Auditorium following a political speech.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. War Dead Below 50 For the 4th Week in Row
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (AP) — The United States command reported today that 43 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, three more than the week be fore.

headline: NIXON ‘PLAN BURIED,’ REDS SAY IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 29 — The Com munist delegations at the Viet nam Peace talks in Paris insist ed today that they had “buried deeply” Pres'dent Nixon's latest peace proposals and refused to comment on reports from Washington that they might still be interested.

headline: U.S. Says Soviet Violated Consul Pact in Plane Case
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29—The United States charged the Soviet Union today with a “clear violation” of the consular convention between the two countries and called for the immediate release of the Unit ed States Army plane and passengers detained in Ar menia since they landed there eight days ago.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Economic Policy Is an Art
lead_paragraph: Item. The Prime Minister of Singa pore, Lee Kuan Yew, when passing through Cambridge recently, asked me why an advanced technology like America's should insist on producing low‐productivity textiles and common shoes. I touched a nerve of a New England radio audience when I quoted my answer. “We should move our resources to more efficient uses and turn over to the developing countries primitive activities that any emerging economy can do with low‐wage labor.” Item. The single question I am most asked when lecturing abroad is this: “Professor Samuelson, doesn't Amer ica's prosperity depend upon Cold War expenditures and imperialistic ven tures like that in Vietnam?”
author: By Paul A. Samuelson

headline: VIETNAM PENALIZES AMERICAN REPORTER
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct, 30—The South Vietnamese national press center has with drawn the press accreditation of the American journalist and former social worker who first publicized the “tiger‐cage” pris on cells on Con Son, an island 60 miles off South Vietnam.

headline: 50,000 Said to Flee Floods in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP)—Offi cials estimated today that the heaviest floods in six years in three northern provinces of South Vietnam had left 50,000 people homeless.

headline: Democrat's Big TV Push Perils Fannin in Arizona
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Oct. 30 — Sam Grossman, a newcomer to Ari zona, to the Democratic party and to politics, threatens to unseat Senator Paul J. Fannin with an aggressive television campaign financed mainly out of his own Docket.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Deaths From Drug Abuse Rise Among Vietnam G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Oct. 30—The United States Com mand disclosed today a rise in deaths of soldiers from drug use in Vietnam and ascribed the increase to greater use of hard drugs and a more acces sible supply of “high potency heroin.”
author: By Titer Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 10‐Year Sentence Of Saigon Deputy Annulled by Court
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Oct. 30—The Supreme Court today annulled the 10‐year sentence imposed on Representative Tran Ngoc Chau, the controversial Deputy jailed earlier this year.

headline: ludge Advocate General To Act on Fate of Captain
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Army said today that Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, the Judge Advocate General, would appoint an officer to de termine whether Capt. John J. McCarthy Jr. of the Special Forces will be retired for the 1967 murder of an alleged Vietnamese “double agent”

headline: Rummage Sale in Saigon Turns Chaotic
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31—The American and British women of St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Saigon held a charity rummage sale to day that quickly turned into a rout. Half of the goods—mostly clothing discarded by departing Americans—were stolen.
author: By Iver Peterson;Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR RALLIES HELD ACROSS U.S.
lead_paragraph: Protesters in cities across the country staged generally peace ful demonstrations, parades and rallies against the Vietnam war yesterday, three days before the Tuesday elections.

headline: TRADE BY FRANCE WITH HANOI SMALL
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 31 — Lacquered screens, straw mats, wicker baskets, specialty rice em broidery and a very high qual ity of hard coal are some of the products offered French consumers as a result of trade agreements with North Viet nam stretching back to 1955.
author: By Clyde H. Farnsworth;Special to The New York Times

headline: Peking and Hanoi Sign Pact
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 31 (UPI)—Com mu??st China and North Viet nam signed an agreement today covering living standards and working conditions for Chinese technicians working Vietnam, Hsinhua, the official China Press Agency, said in a broad cast monitored here

headline: HANOI AGAIN BLOCKS VISIT BY INDIAN AIDE
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Oct. 31— India has been rebuffed again by North Vietnam in her at tempts to play an intermediary role in Vietnam peace negotia tions.

headline: Approaching the Elections
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At an afternoon rally before a sizable student crowd at the University of Tennessee, Sen ator Albert Gore recently declared that Vice President Agnew “is our worst disaster since Vietnam.” As one man, the students leaped to their feet, cheering and whistling; even Mr. Gore, one of the best stump orators in the country, appeared taken aback by the enthusiastic response to his remarks; and the uproar went on for well over a minute.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Stamps
lead_paragraph: POSTMASTER GENERAL Winton M. Blount un veiled on Oct. 21 de signs of two 6‐cent stamps to be issued later this year honoring American serv icemen of past wars, and pay ing homage to men held as prisoners of war, or missing and killed in action in Viet nam. Both stamps will be printed on the same sheet. Mr. Blount has also an nounced issuance of a 6c stamp next year commem orating the 450th anniversary of the introduction of sheep to the North American conti nent.
author: By David Lidman

headline: HEAVY RAINS BRING THE WAR TO A HALT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (Reuters)—Monsoon rains sweeping across the northern provinces of South Vietnam have resulted in an unofficial truce in the war as military forces concentrate on aid in stead of destruction.

headline: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL SOME CAMPAIGN ADS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) — The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee accused the Committee for a Responsi ble Congress today of using what it called “artfully con trived and deceitful” newspaper advertisements in an attempt to link some Democratic can didates with extreme and radi cal positions.

headline: THIEU SAYS PEACE CAN'T BE OBTAINED AT TALKS IN PARK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 31—President Nguyen Van Thieu declared to day that the Communists had no intention of negotiating a settlement of the Vietnam war unless they were assured of total domination of the country.
author: By Alvin Shuster;Special to The New York Times

headline: STUDENTS IN POLL BACK ARMY DUTY
lead_paragraph: A nationwide survey of 25,000 high school students has found that 43 per cent say they would volunteer for two years of mili tary service if the pay was in creased and the draft ended.
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm

headline: 1,000 in San Francisco
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UPI)—About 1,000 young peo ple marched to the city's Civic Center today to demonstrate their opposition to the war in Vietnam and President Nixon.

headline: The Nixon Campaign
lead_paragraph: A long tedious campaign nears its climax. Through weeks of apathy, Republican candidates across the country — led first by Vice President Agnew, then by President Nixon himself — have sought to whip up emo tions about crime, campus disorders and pornography. A cynical, coolly calculated effort has been made to dis tract attention from the Administration's record in eco nomic affairs, and foreign policy — a deliberate effort to create scapegoats and then identify the Democrats with them.

headline: Screen: Allusive 'WUSA':Newman Stars in Tale About Radio Station
lead_paragraph: Booze in his thermos, a garment bag slung over his shoulder, out of the morning strolls Paul Newman, itinerant radio announcer, to offer his services to WUSA, patriotic hate station broadcasting from New Orleans.To Newman comes Joanne Woodward, a wandering harlot with a heart of gold, a loving nature, a carved-up face, a certain vulnerability, and a fund of moral rectitude deep enough to float a generation of movie whores. And to them both comes Tony Perkins, shy social worker engaged among the black poor in a mysterious research project—which he learns too late is a fraud designed to discredit welfare, a fraud perpetrated by Pat Hingle, power-mad master of WUSA.Thus Stuart Rosenberg's "WUSA," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse and Plaza theaters, sets the stage for what it clearly intends as a major understanding of social forces at work in America—reactionary social forces, and in the South.If it were an ordinary bad movie (and it is a very bad movie), "WUSA" might, in spite of the distinguished names, and less distinguished presence, of its leading actors, be dismissed with no more than a nod to the tension between Rosenberg's ponderously emphatic direction, and Robert Stone's ponderously allusive screenplay. I suspect Stone wins out, for "WUSA" feels more like poor theater than poor moviemaking—so, that it continually suggests a failed version of "The Balcony," even though it strives to fall short of "The Manchurian Candidate."But at least in its ambitions, "WUSA" is not an ordinary bad movie. For in its climax, a huge white-power rally sponsored by WUSA, it means to hold a mirror up to middle America, to show the hate behind the innocence, the chaos implicit in the call to law and order.So, while Perkins stalks the auditorium catwalks with high-powered rifle, like the shade of Laurence Harvey (who is also in this movie, but in another role), Newman prepares to purge himself, to tell the country what it is like it is, when all hell breaks loose after the firing of the would-be assassin's bullet.In this sequence, during which Newman explains Vietnam to a panic-ridden, rioting mass of the thin-lipped pinch-faced silent majority, "WUSA" has its crucial image, and, presumably, its rational. But in this sequence it displays most brazenly the utter gratuitousness of all its images, the bad faith that informs its self-righteous view of Southern demagoguery, the poverty not of mainstream America but of its own ideas about mainstream America.Despite its obsession with collecting evidence, and its handy school of pseudo-documentary, "WUSA" fights unreal battles with an unseen enemy. Lacking either the grace of art of the vitality of guerrilla theater, it can offer only the coarsest nourishment—and only to the elaborately self-deceived.
author: By Roger Greenspun

headline: Weyand Gets Fourth Star
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (Reuters)—Lieut. Gen. Fred erick Weyand today received fourth star to make him a full general and at the same time became deputy commander of United States forces in Viet nam.

headline: Yale Regains a Bit of Its Boola Boola
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1— When a massive antiwar demonstration was proposed recently for the Town Green here this weekend, many peo ple at Yale fretted that it might hurt local peace can didates because voters were getting weary of all demon strations. There were other misgivings, too.
author: By Steven R. Weisman;Special to The New York Times

headline: Slaying Spurs Disorders
lead_paragraph: NEW CASTLE, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP)—A black Vietnam veteran was shot to death in front of a tavern early today and the resulting disorders brought in jury to nine persons, including five policemen, the police said. According to the police, more than 100 persons poured onto streets from taverns on the city's south side and began smashing windows after Ronald Mitchell, 21, was shot in the stomach from a passing vehicle. The police said they had no sus pects in the shooting.

headline: Shells Said to Kill 6 in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 2 (AP)—Vietcong gunners were reported to have shelled Saigon early today for the first time in three months, and authorities reported six Vietnamese were killed and 15 wounded and a cluster of hous es was destroyed.

headline: ‘BIG MINH’ IMPLIES HE'LL FIGHT THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Nov. 2—Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh, one of the most pop ular figures in South Vietnam, broke a year‐long political si lence yesterday with a broad hint that he would challenge Nguyen Van Thieu for the pres idency next year.
author: By Alvin Shuster;Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
author: Lyman M. Tondel Jr. President, New York State Bar Association, 1968‐69 New York, Oct. 28, 1970;[Rabbi] MARTIN SIEGEL Lawrence, L. I., Oct. 27, 1970;GEORGE G. GERSON Bronx, Oct. 24, 1970

headline: President Nixon and Vietnam
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7th the President an nounced an Indo‐China peace initiative as a serious effort to lay the basis for a settlement of the conflict. This comprehensive program containing a number of features new to the U.S. negotiating position has the agree ment and support of the governments of South Vietnam, Laos and Cam bodia.
author: By Mrs. Oswald B. Lord

headline: POLITICAL ISSUES ARISE IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1—Cambodia declared herself a republic last month, but she has not decided what kind of a republic she wants to be.
author: By Henry Kamm;Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Rides Copter Over the Sonmy Area
lead_paragraph: QUANGNGAI, South Viet nam, Nov. 2 (AP)—Smiling and giving the peace sign, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. today flew in a helicop ter over the, area involved in the accusation that he mur dered more than 100 Vietna mese villagers two and a half years ago.

headline: 2,000 MOURN DIEM AT SAIGON GRAVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2—Nearly two thousand Roman Catholics gathered in the rain today around the un marked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem while the city around them took a Government holi day to celebrate President Diem's overthrow and assas sination seven years ago.

headline: Mrs. Binh Indicates Vietcong Might Deal With ‘Big Minh’
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 2—Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, chief negotiator for the Vietcong at the Vietnam peace talks here, indicated to day that her side might be pre pared to deal with a South Viet namese government headed by Gen. Duong Van Minh.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Nixon's Stand on Smut
author: P. FRANK WINKLER Middlebury, Vt., Oct. 25, 1970

headline: CASUALTY FIGURES PUT AT 5‐YEAR LOW
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) —United States casualties in Vietnam hit a five‐year low last week, the Pentagon announced today, although the exaact fig ures were not given.

headline: STOCK OF A‐ARMS IS TERMED HUGE
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Nov. 2 — World military expenditures leveled off last year but nuclear stock piles were vast enough to blast every person in the world with the equivalent of 15 tons of TNT, a wide‐ranging survey of armament and disarmament said today.
author: By Bernard Weinraub;Special to The New York Times

headline: TROOPS IN VIETNAM TO GET TRIPS HOME
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 3—The United States command has doubled the leave time available to sol diers serving in Vietnam to en able them to hitch a free ride back to the United States for a two‐week visit.
author: By Iver Peterson;Special to The New York Times

headline: LIBERALS ACCUSE HOUSTON'S POLICE
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Nov. 2—Represen tatives of a coalition of 12 lib eral and radical groups, most of them antiwar, accused the Houston Police Department to day of protecting two “night rider” members of the Ku Klux Klan who allegedly committed vandalism.
author: By Martin Waldron;Special to The New York Times

headline: New Type of Gallup Poll Finds Most Favor Total Pullout in ’71
lead_paragraph: A new kind of Gallup Poll shows a majority in favor of withdrawing all American troops from Vietnam by the end of next year and a major ity in favor of wage and price controls.

headline: ENEMY IS REPORTED NEARING PNOMPENH
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP)—A Cambodian military spokes man said today that elements of a North Vietnamese division had moved into flooded areas just across the Mekong River from Pnompenh with the ap parent mission of battering the capital's defenses.

headline: STATEMENT BY HANOI IN U.N. ACCUSES U.S.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3—A North Vietnamese statement accusing the United States forces of a general pol icy of civilian massacres in South Vietnam has been circu lated here to all members at the request of the Hungarian Government.

headline: Calley Trial Motions Delayed
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 3 (AP)—Final arguments on mo tions and selection of a court martial panel to try Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. on charges stemming from the alleged massacre at Mylai, have been postponed to Nov. 10. Lieuten ant Calley is charged with the slaying of 102 Vietnamese civil ians.

headline: Calley and Lawyer Get Depositions Near Sonmy
lead_paragraph: CHULAI, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 (AP)—First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. completed an evidence‐gathering mission today in the Sonmy area. He is facing trial on charges that he killed more than 100 Vietnamese villagers there more than two years ago.

headline: Saigon Estimates Flood Toll at 193
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 (UPI) — Last week's floods, the worst in six years, left at least 193 persons dead and more than 204,000 homeless in the five north ern provinces, South Viet namese military, authorities reported today.

headline: Colonel Denies Mylai Case Was Influenced by Publicity
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Nov. 3 (AP)—The officer who conducted the Army's equiva lent of a civilian grand jury investigation in one of the 10 Mylai cases denied today that publicity surrounding the al leged massacre of Vietnamese civilians had influenced his de cision to recommend that the case be tried by court‐martial.

headline: Vietcong Gone, Bombers Gone, but Not Village's Scars
lead_paragraph: CHOTHOM, South Vietnam, Nov. 1—All through the nine teen‐sixties this hamlet and much of the surrounding coun tryside in the Mekong Delta belonged to the Vietcong. For a year it has been held by the South Vietnamese Government, and the countryside appears to be secure.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal;Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
author: Charles U. Lowe M.d. Scientific Director National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Bethesda, Md., Oct. 23, 1970

headline: NO SECOND TERM, THIEU INDICATES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 (UPI)—Pesident Ngu yen Van Thieu of South Viet nam indicated tonight for the first time that he might not seek a second term in elections scheduled for September, 1971.

headline: Marines Accuse a Sergeant of Desertion
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 — A young marine sergeant from West Babylon, L.I., who de clared he was a defector in Sweden last August before re turning to the United States, was charged by the Marine Corps today with desertion, abandoning arms and aiding the enemy.

headline: SOVIET SOFTENS LINE ON NIXON PEACE PLAN
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 4—The So viet Union today repeated its opposition to President Nixon's Indochina peace proposals and reiterated its support for the proposals of the Vietnamese Communists.

headline: Letters to the Editor
author: CONSTANCE M. KINGSLEY Hicksville, L. I., Oct. 23, 1970;JOSEPH MITTEL Stamford, Conn., Oct. 26, 1970;MARIAN ANDERS Brooklyn, Oct. 31, 1970

headline: U.S. BASE IS GIVEN TO SAIGON FORCES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4 (Reuters)—The South Vietnamese Air Force took over an air base in the Mekong Delta today from the United States.

headline: 24 Americans Killed in Week, Lowest Toll in War Since ‘65
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 — The United States command reported today that 24 American soldiers were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the lowest weekly toll in five years.

headline: Vietnam Flood Toll Now 237
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (AP)—The death toll from floods that swept South Vietnam's five northern prov inces last weekend reached 237 today.

headline: War Review Panel Assails Johnson's Administration
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) A top‐level military review board has blamed the Johnson Administration for some of the mistakes of the Vietnam war, asserting that long‐range con tingency plans were ignored by not calling up the reserves and by planning for a short war.

headline: SUPPLY BUILD‐UP BY FOE REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5—The United States Secretary of the Air Force, Robert C. Seamans Jr., reported today that the North Vietnamese had carried out an extensive build up of supplies in their southern provinces.
author: By Alvin Shuster;Special to The New York Times

headline: Diplomatic Probing Expected
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5—A prolonged period of diplomatic exploration is foreseen by Unit ed States officials before ac tual negotiations on a Vietnam peace settlement are likely to get under way. These could in clude secret talks in Paris and contacts elsewhere through friendly governments, the offi cials said.
author: By Tad Szulc;Special to The New York Times

headline: Glaciers and Open Doors
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 5—Measuring the prog ress of Vietnamese peace negotia tions is something like measuring the speed of a glacier. In neither case is there detectable movement and yet, if one looks back over a period of time, it is possible to discern change with respect to fixed landmarks.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Rescuer of Apollo 13 Crew Killed by Mine in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov, 5 (AP) —A member of the team that helped recover the Apollo 13 astronauts when they splashed down from their troubled flight to the moon has been killed by a land mine in Vietnam,

headline: They Asserts Nixon Lied And Is Rebuked by Bruce
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 5— American and Communist negotiators at the Vietnam peace talks here charged each other with dis courtesy today as the confer ence settled back into a fa miliar routine, of non‐negotia tion.
author: By Henry Giniger;Special to The New York Times

headline: Market Place:
lead_paragraph: This is a period of deep concern over the social re sponsibility of corporations. Many commentators are be ginning to ask whether the corporation has the right to carve out profits at the ex pense of the ecology of the land—or even at the expense of human lives.
author: By Robert Metz

headline: Two Replacements Named To Cailey's Trial Board
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 6 (AP)—Two, replacements have been named to the 10‐member court‐martial board that will try Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. on murder charges in the death of 102 Vietnamese civil ians at Sonmy.

headline: Battle in Cambodia Reported
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 6 (AP)—A Cambodian military spokesman reported today that about 200. North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers am bushed Cambodian troops west of the Angkor temples in northwest Cambodia, starting an eight–hour battle. The spokesman said casualty fig ures were not available, but field reports indicated they might be high.

headline: 6,000 Saigon Troops Advance In New Operation in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 (AP) — Six thousand South Vietnamese troops ad vanced across a 100‐mile‐wide front in southeastern Cambodia today in a major new opera tion.

headline: Vietnam: Remembered
lead_paragraph: London, Nov. 6—When it is all over, some day, what shall we have learned from the war in Vietnam? What will it have told us about America and the world, about the use of power, about the relationship between polit ical ends and military means?
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Vietnam: ‘Miss Fix‐It’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON— Americans — well intentioned, liberal‐minded Americans especially have an almost ungovern able urge to play the, role of Miss Fix‐It. If things go wrong, Miss Fix‐It, American liberal model, just has to move and fix everything up right.
author: By Stewart Alsop

headline: Vietnam: Who Profits From the War?
lead_paragraph: When confronted with a grave crime a classical, basic question immediately poses itself: who profits from it? For any war the same question also arises: to whose advantage is this war being fought? This is also the proper way to look at Vietnam with its military stale mate. The purpose of that war is, we are told, to contain communism and to guarantee a freely elected govern ment in order to honor American com mitments. But what is happening in reality? The gain is entirely on the Communist side.
author: By Oskar Morgenstern

headline: Vietnam Options
lead_paragraph: The President's new Vietnam pro posals have once again raised the hopes of a negotiated settlement. How ever, although his five‐point plan is eminently fair it is unlikely to be ac cepted in Hanoi.
author: By Morton H. Halperin

headline: U.S. ASKS U.N. ACTION ON PRISONERS OF WAR
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6—The United States called here today for United Nations action to press North Vietnam to allow identification of war prisoners and to allow access to them by the Red Cross.

headline: U.S. Base Transfer in Vietnam: Lots of Paper and Some Discord
lead_paragraph: SOCTRANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 5—The transfer of the United States Army helicopter base here to the South Vietna mese Air Force yesterday ap peared as effortless as the cer emonial hauling down of the Stars and Stripes.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal;Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam: Unspeakable Thoughts
lead_paragraph: MAJORCA — Consciousness has a strange way with conscience: more often than not, it is a kind of un peaceful coexistence. Each has a tendency to avoid looking at each other. What we are witnessing today in the U.S.A., largely as a consequence of Vietnam, is a fusion between conscience and consciousness, and it is difficult to see how this could fail to lead the country toward a meta morphosis, or at least to a change.
author: By Romain Gary

headline: Rabbi Loses Court Motion To Bar Hogan From Trial
lead_paragraph: Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, who was arrested last May on charges that he disrupted serv ices at Temple Emanu‐E1 while seeking contributions for black militants, lost in a move yes terday to disqualify District At torney Frank S. Hogan from prosecuting him.

headline: Cambodian Leader States Nixon Promised More Aid
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 7 (AP)—Cheng Heng, the Cam bodian Chief of State, said to day that President Nixon had personally promised him a big ger military and economic aid package to underwrite Cambo dia's war against the North Vietnamese and Vietcong. But he said the size of the figure was still being discussed.

headline: Why Vietnam went wrong—a version without villains
lead_paragraph: America in Vietnam. By Chester L. Cooper. Foreword by Ambassador W. Averell Harriman. 559 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $12.
author: By Ronald Steel

headline: Air Traffic Heavy in Southern Laos
lead_paragraph: ABOARD U.S.S. SHANGRI LA, off North Vietnam, Nov??2 (AP) — So many American planes are bombing the Ho Chi Minh trail in southern Laos that military officials have es tablished traffic patterns simi lar to those in use at major American airports.

headline: Vietnamese Veteran Is Neglected
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7—Five months ago Nguyen Bang, who had lost both leg?? while fighting for the Green Berets, drank an overdose of medicine in an effort to kill himself. His mother found him and carried him to the hospital.

headline: How to Misread the Election
lead_paragraph: Of all the silly and self‐serving in terpretations of the 1970 election, the prize goes to the propagandists in the North Vietnamese capital of Hanoi. They are telling the world that Presi dent Nixon has been rebuked, and re pudiated by the American people, and this is not only wrong but dangerous.
author: By James Reston

headline: The Vietnam Veteran: Silent, Perplexed, Unnoticed
lead_paragraph: There were no victory pa rades, no brass bands, no cheering crowds when Wendell Sissler came marching home from Vietnam.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr

headline: Grenades Kill 18 in a Pnompenh Theater
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov 7 (AP)—Two grenades exploded in a movie theater here tonight and the police reported 18 per sons killed and 46 wounded.

headline: Christmas Cards for G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 7 (UPI) — Three Villanova Uni versity students have sounded a call on 500 college campuses for a drive to send a Christmas card or greeting to each of the 344,000 American servicemen in Vietnam. The three are Rob ert J. Breslin Jr. of Manhasset, L. I.; Thomas Creagh, also of Manhasset, and Tom Treacy of Plainview, L. I.

headline: YOUTHS FELL SHY OF ELECTION GOAL
lead_paragraph: LOS ??ANGELES, Nov. 7—Last spring, in the emotional back wash of Cambodia and Kent State, many students vowed to work for a “new Congress” that would end the war and reorder national priorities.
author: By Steven V. Roberts; Special to The New York Times

headline: A Call for Peace in Laos
author: By Prince Souphanouvong

headline: Thieu, Minh and Peace
lead_paragraph: The stalemate in the Paris talks, President Thieu's cocktail banter about stepping down and a call for peace and “national reconciliation” by his leading rival, General “Big” Minh, are stirring new interest in South Vietnam's impending presidential campaign. There is speculation in Paris and Saigon that Mr. Thieu's with drawal or his defeat in the election might open the way to negotiation for a political settlement between the Com munists and a new Saigon Government.

headline: Mrs. Johnson Says Officials Keep Her Husband Informed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) —Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that her husband was receiving White House briefings every Friday on world events.

headline: Shell Kills 3 G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. (Reuters)— Three United States soldiers were killed and three wounded today when one apparently stepped on an unexploded ar tillery round. The incident oc rcurred about 350 miles north east of Saigon.

headline: Nixon Reported Eager to Name Southerner to Supreme Court
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 9 —President Nixon intends to nominate a Southern conserva tive to the Supreme Court at the first available opportunity, and apparently believes that the new Senate would approve such a choice.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr.; Special to The New York Times

headline: JUSTICES REJECT BAY STATE’S SUIT ON VIETNAK WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9—The Supreme Court refused today to hear the challenge by the State of Massachusetts to the constitutionality of the Vietnam war.
author: By Fred P. Graham; Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: DAVID NEMIROFF New York, Nov. 4, 1970

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: Robert Brill is a lawyer, as were his father and his grandfather before him, in Rosetta, Ill. (pop. 32,800). He owns a farm, where he raises food for his own table. He hunts and fishes for the same pur pose. He has a wife, who loves the sherry bottle more than life, and two children —a girl in high school and a boy who sought first to evade the draft by decamping to Montreal and then went to Vietnam and became a pro fessional soldier. Brill does his own share of drinking, with vodka in stead of coffee for breakfast, a can of beer be tween his knees while he's driving, a bottle in the back seat and a bottle in the office desk. Brill drinks because he is in ?? constant state of rage: “There is only one way to react in a stupid‐ass proceeding, and that is, every time they hit you, smash back at them insanely. You don't do this because your legal grounds are any good. It's how things work. If you can make it painful enough for them this time, maybe they'll go hit some other poor jerk next time.”
author: By John Leonard

headline: Army Will Restudy Charges on Medina Over Sonmy Deaths
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Nov. 9 (AP)—Charges against Capt. Ernest L. Medina in the al leged massacre at Sonmy more than two years ago have been returned to a military investi gating officer for further study, the Army announced today.

headline: Attacks Reported on Cambodian Posts
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 9 (Reuters)—North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops were re ported have launched coor dinated attacks today against Government military positions and towns northeast of Pnom penh.

headline: Cambodians’ Bid to Laotian For U.S. Arms Is Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON?? South Vietnam?? Nov. 8—According to informed sources, Cambodian officers are discussing with members of the entourage of Prince Boun O??m, the feudal chief of southern Laos, the possibility of sending sizable numbers of Cambodian troops to Laos to be equipped with United States arms.
author: By Henry Kamm; Special to The New York Times

headline: Peace Talks in Paris Are Put Off a Week
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 10 (Reuters) —All four delegations to the Vietnam peace talks here have agreed to postpone this week's session because of the death of Chares de Gaulle, a spokesman for the Vietcong delegation said today.

headline: In Normandy, Mixed Feelings
lead_paragraph: EVREUX, France, Nov. 10— In 1356, according to the guide books, John the Good seized Evreux from Charles the Bad. Then he burned it.
author: By Richard Eder; Special to The New York Times

headline: Big Minh Hears Question From Many: Will He Run?
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 10 — Automobile traffic near the villa on Hongthaptu Street has picked up lately. Ambassadors, politicians, re tired generals and various reli gious figures have been arriv ing with increasing regularity these days to chat with Gen. Duong Van Minh, the man most likely to challenge President Nguyen Van Thieu in the elec tions next year.
author: By Alvin Shuster; Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Going Paris Rites ogers and Kissinger
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 10—President Nixon will at tend memorial services for Charles de Gaulle, the White House announced today. Mr. Nixon will leave Washington tomorrow morning with a small official delegation, attend the service at Notre Dame Cathe dral in Paris on Thursday, and return to Washington late Thursday night.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr.; Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Jury to Hear Witnesses Barred In First Mylai Trial
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 10—The military judge in the murder trial of First Lieut. Wil liam. L. Calley Jr. opened the way today for testimony by key, prosecution witnesses who were barred from taking the stand at the trial of another defendant in the alleged mas sacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Communist Party Aide Is Indicted in Contempt
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) —Arnold S. Johnson, public re lations director of the Commu nist party of the United States, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today for contempt of Con gress.

headline: Ky Due Next Week on Delayed Visit
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) —State Departmentofficials said today that Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky of South Vietnam would visit the United States next week: For security rea sons, the time and place of his arrival were not disclosed.

headline: Australian Prime Minister Is Heckled on Indochina War
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 10— Antiwar demonstrators draped a Vietcong flag across the shoulders of Prime Minister John G. Gorton at an election rally in Perth today. The flag was immediately snatched away by one of Mr. Gorton's aides.

headline: Treasury Will Extend Combat‐Zone Benefits
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) — The Government will extend its combat‐zone tax benefits to military per sonnel serving in certain Southeast Asian posts outside Vietnam, the Treasury De partment announced here to day.

headline: Blount in Paris for Talks On Holiday Mail to P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) —Postmaster General Winton M. Blount is in Paris on the first leg of a journey that might take him to Hanoi to assure that Christmas mail gets to Americans held prisoner in North Vietnam, Government sources reported today.

headline: Key Item on Political Agenda: The Economy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The election has left the Gov ernment with a sizable hang over. There is work to be done, in all three branches, but there are already signs that the next campaign will merge imper ceptibly into the last and leave the politicians reeling for quite a while. Even now, the per‐ formance or me economy, the war in Vietnam, the re form of the wel fare system, the effort to combat crime and the integration of schools are being measured for their effects on the race for President two years hence. In both parties, the thought is taking hold that the economy looms largest in this catalogue and that everything from the budget to the lowliest appro priation bills will therefore be subject to unusual partisan maneuvers. News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel; Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 American Foes of War Face Court Tests in Japan
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 10—A 26‐year old American Quaker woman, whose ancestors arrived in Pennsylvania with William Penn, sits in a narrow hotel room at Tokyo International Airport fighting deportation, while at a United States Marine Corps stockade in Iwakuni, southern Japan, a I9‐year‐old Vietnam war veteran prepares his defense against charges of desertion and riot.
author: By Takashi Oka; Special to The New York Times

headline: SALUTE TO VETERANS IS UPSET AT HUNTER
lead_paragraph: More than 200 antiwar stu dents yesterday disrupted a “Salute to Our Veterans” cere mony sponsored by a conserva tive student group at Hunter College.

headline: High Court Asked to Rule On Vietnam War Objection
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) —The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to rule out draft exemptions for men who are conscien tiously opposed to the Vietnam ese war but not to all wars.

headline: Vietnamese Savant Sees Vital Future Role for U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11—Nguyen Dang Thuc, One of Vietnam's leading thinkers, be lieves that Americans should play a significant role in post war Vietnam

headline: ENEMY AMBUSHES CAMBODIAN UNITS
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 11 (AP) — Two battalions of Cambodian troops were am bushed today 35 miles north of Pnompenh on Highway 7. The scene was about five miles east of the district capital of Skoun. There were no reports on cas ualties. Two companies were sent to reinforce the ambushed units, officers at Skoun said.

headline: Some Service Academy Alumni Ask Prompt Pullout From War
lead_paragraph: An organization of service academy alumni called on President Nixon yesterday to “put aside self‐serving political goals” and promptly withdraw all troops from Vietnam.

headline: MYLAI PROSECUTOR WON'T FIGHT RULING
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 11 (UPI)—The prosecutor in the case of S. Sgt. David Mitchell, charged with assault with in tent to murder in the alleged Mylai massacre of civilians in South Vietnam, says he plans no changes in his case despite a ruling in a similar case in Georgia.

headline: Blount Asks Aid on P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Nov. 12—Post master General Winton M. Blount today requested the help of the International Committee or the Red Cross in getting Christmas mail to American prisoners of war in North Viet nam.

headline: Calley Court‐Martial Opens Officially at Ft. Benning
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 12—Two probable themes in the defense of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. emerged to day when his court‐martial for the premeditated murder of 102 South Vietnamese civilians of ficially opened more than two and a half years after the al leged massacre at Sonmv.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: NO U.S. WAR DEAD FOR 2‐DAY PERIOD
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Nov. 13 (AP)—The United States command reported yes terday that on Tuesday and Wednesday American forces in Indochina had gone through two days without a combat fatality for the first time in five years.

headline: GROMYKOANDPOPE HAVE A LONG TALK
lead_paragraph: ROME, Nov. 12—The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, had an unusually long audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican this afternoon after three days of talks with Italian Government leaders.

headline: Nixon Meets Podgorny For Brief Chat in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 12 — President Nixon chatted briefly and in formally late this afternoon with Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet President.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: NEW PANEL CALLED FOR CALLEY TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 13—Attempts to complete a military jury, for the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. failed again today after extensive questioning of a panel of Army officers,
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Ky Will Arrive Tomorrow For a 2½‐Week U.S. Visit
lead_paragraph: Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam is to arrive in New York tomorrow after noon for a two‐and‐a‐half‐week visit to the United States, the spokesman for Saigon's observer mission at the United Nations said yeaterday.

headline: 6 U.S. P.O.W.'s Dead, Hanoi Reports
lead_paragraph: North Vietnam has informed an American peace group that six United States servicemen it held prisoner have died. Hanoi also confirmed the iden tities of four additional Ameri can prisoners.

headline: Early Discharges For Christmas Set; Furloughs Urged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) —Many American servicemen whose terms of service are just about up will be given a Christmas bonus in the form of a discharge up to two weeks earlier so they can shed their uniforms before the holidays, the Pentagon said today.

headline: Chicago 7 Judge Ordered To Review Link to Jury
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 13 — The United States Court of Appeals ordered Judge Julius J. Hoff man today to hold a hearing as soon as possible to determine the nature of any communica tions between the judge or Fed eral marshals and the jury in the Chicago conspiracy trial.
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. WARNS HANOI AS JET IS DOWNED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned North Vietnam today that the United States stood ready to retaliate against any continued firing at Ameri can reconnaissance aircraft.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Painless Taxes

headline: No Wonder Most Mothers Give Up
lead_paragraph: BASICALLY most adults are suspi cious of those who write for chil dren. At least in the years I have been writing children's books and plays, I have found this to be so. There seems to be the unspoken assumption that it is obviously an inadequacy on my part which might improve with ex perience, if not age. Of course, it hasn't. Although I have been a foreign corres pondent in both Korea and Vietnam, and have had adult plays produced in summer stock, I still continue quite con tentedly writing for young people. And I suppose it is because I feel, as C. S. Lewis did, that it is the best form for what I have to say about the things that really matter to me.
author: By Betty Jean Lifton

headline: U.S. Deserter Loses Plea; Sweden Will Deport Him
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 14 (Rue ters) — The Swedish Cabinet has turned down a final ap peal from an American military deserter who is scheduled to be deported next week — the first United States deserter to be sent home from Sweden.

headline: AUSTRALIAN RACE FOR SENATE BITTER
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 —Campaigning for the Senate elections next Saturday has de veloped into an acrimonious contest between Prime Minister John G. Gorton and Edward Gough Whitlam, head of the opposition Labor party.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: A Former P.O.W. Relates His Experiences in Hanoi
MAJOR ARMY UNITS BEING RESHUFFLED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) —The Army has announced a reshuffling of major units growing out of the reduction of United States forces in Viet nam and a parallel cutback in over‐all American arms strength.

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Robert Shaplen

headline: Returning Casualties Need Long, Costly Care
lead_paragraph: Although the Vietnam casual ties have been at their lowest point in five years these past few weeks, it would be tragic if the public were lulled into apathy. An enormous problem still exists: 300,000 total cas ualties, 100,000 seriously wounded, 5,000 severe injuries of the upper extremities.
author: By Howard A. Rusk M.D

headline: A U.S. Marine in Japan Becomes an Antiwar Symbol
lead_paragraph: IWAKUNI, Japan, Nov. 13— A shy 19‐year‐old Marine pri vate on trial in a drab Quonset hut here has become the latest symbol of confrontation be tween antiwar partisans—both American and Japanese—and the United States military establishment.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI DENOUNCES LAIRD'S WARNING
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 14—The North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks denied today that there was an understanding with the United States concern ing unarmed reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam.

headline: 4TH JUROR CHOSEN FOR GALLEY TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 14 —The selection of a military jury to try First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for his role in the alleged Mylai massacre stalled again today after the fourth juror was chosen.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Art Sale to Aid An Orphanage
lead_paragraph: The An Lac Orphanage in Saigon, Vietnam, will receive 50 per cent of the proceeds of a sale of the brush paint ings of Mon‐ying Chow next Saturday at the China Insti tute at 125 East 65th Street. The sale will be held from 1 to 5 P.M. Mrs. Chow, who came here from Hong Kong for the exhibition, will dem onstrate her art at 3 P.M.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John E. Corbally Jr

headline: Solving an Ugly Dilemma
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The greatest lesson of the Vietnam war is that America still has many commitments abroad and still retains foreign policy aims that can no longer be maintained by the kind of military establishment, strategy or net work of alliances now employed.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Hanoi Word on Mail Awaited
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) —Postmaster General Winton M. Blount, back from Paris where he attempted to arrange delivery of mail to American prisoners in North Vietnam, says he will await word from the Government in Hanoi be fore taking further steps.

headline: Hijacking:
lead_paragraph: Raffaele Minichiello is a cor poral in the Marine Corps and a veteran of the war in Vietnam. Last November, Minichiello, fac ing a court‐martial for burglary and contending that he had been treated unfairly by the Marines, decided to return to his native Italy — the hard way.

headline: PAKISTANI SIGNS CHINA TRADE PACT
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, NOV. 14—A new agreement on economic cooperation was signed in Pe king today between Pakistan and Communist China.

headline: Saigon Cost of Living Rises 2.8% in Week, U.S. Reports
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 (UPI)—The cost of liv ing in Saigon rose 2.8 per cent last week, according to a re port made public by the United States Embassy.

headline: Ky Here for U.S. Visit; Pickets Stage a Protest
lead_paragraph: South Vietnam's Vice Presi dent, Nguyen Cao Ky, slipped uneventfully into New York last night under heavy security guard to begin an unofficial two‐and‐a‐half‐week visit to the United States.
author: By Terence Smith

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Preferential Voting Backed
author: Harold M. Olmsted Jamaica, N. Y., Nov. 4, 1970; Chester Wells Morss Brooklyn, Nov. 5, 1970; Lorrin S. Anderson New York, Nov. 7, 1970; Dorothy Dunbar Bromley New York, Nov. 9, 1970; Geoffrey H. Moore Commissioner of Labor Statistics Washington, Nov. 12, 1970; Arthur Schlesinger Jr. New York, Nov. 5, 1970

headline: The Post‐de Gaulle Era
lead_paragraph: Charles de Gaulle's influence on the life of France over the past three decades has dominated the obituaries, but the consequences of his departure may also prove profound.

headline: ALLIES EXPECTING ATTACK NEAR DMZ
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Green Berets Face A Big Cut in Forces As Policies Change
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 — The Special Forces, the United States Army's specialists in guerrilla warfare and military intelligence operations, are fac ing a major cutback in their strength as a result of a basic change of emphasis on what their primary mission should be.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi to Allow P.O.W.'s To Get Bigger Packages
Ky Sees Fall of Cambodia If Saigon's Forces Leave
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine Correspondents Elect
lead_paragraph: The New York Chapter of the Marine Corps Combat Cor respondents Association has elected Charles J. Gilroy Jr. as its new president. Mr. Gilroy, who served as information offi cer for the Vietnam headquar ters of Gen. Creighton Abrams before retiring from active duty, is special assistant to the man ager of the William J. Burns International Detective Agency.

headline: Rockets Strike Bienhoa Air Base, Northeast of Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tues day, Nov. 17 (Reuters)—The big Bienhoa air base was struck by more than a dozen rockets this morning, apparently fired by Vietcong guerrillas.

headline: Thanksgiving With Nixons
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) —President and Mrs. Nixon will give a Thanksgiving Day dinner at the White House for about 100 Vietnam war veterans in Washington area hospitals. The White House announce ment today said the hospitals would select the patients to at tend. Last Thanksgiving—their first in the White House — the Nixons gave a similar dinner for residents of Washington‐ area homes for the elderly.

headline: Merton Perry, Reporter, Dead; Covered Vietnam War 6 Years
lead_paragraph: BELOIT, Wis., Nov. 16 (AP)— Merton D. Perry, who reported the war from Vietnam as bu reau manager for United Press International and then as cor respondent for Newsweek maga zine, died of a heart attack yes terday morning in the Beloit Hospital. His age was 41.

headline: Mitchell Trial Delayed
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 16 —The court‐martial of Staff Sgt. David Mitchell resumed here today after a 26‐day post ponement only to become en snarled in another delay that forestalled testimony of de fense witnesses for at least one more day.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Jobless Rate for Veterans Expected to Grow Higher
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) —Returning Vietnam war vet erans are having an increas ingly tough time finding jobs despite special Government help, and the situation is likely to grow worse as the United States reduces its war role, the Labor Department said today.

headline: Washington: For the Record
Calley Jury Picked
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 16—A six‐man military jury for the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was com pleted today.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Thais Plan Pullout by '72
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednes day, Nov. 18 (AP)—Thailand will withdraw all its 12,000 troops from South Vietnam by 1972, the Premier, Thanom Kit tikachorn, said today.

headline: U.S. Details Case Against Calley
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: RISING USE OF LSD WORRIES THE NAVY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 — A Navy narcotics investigator told a House Armed Services sub committee today that a major concern of the Navy was “the alarming increase in LSD use in the naval service.”
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: NUREMBERG AND VIETNAM: An American Tragedy. By Telford Taylor. 224 pages. A New York Times Book: Quadrangle. $5.95. Paperbound, $1.95.
author: By John Leonard

headline: G.I.'s at Korean DMZ Glad They're Not in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: AT THE DEMILITARIZED ZONE, South Korea, Nov. 17— Life is dreary in late fall in the bleak hills where American and North Korean troops face each other without seeing each other and when there is only the icy Manchurian winter to look for ward to.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Common Market vs. World Market
author: PAUL DE HEVESY Hove, Sussex, England, Nov. 11, 1970

headline: Saigon Reports Seizure of Huge Ammunition Cache in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (Reuters) —South Vietnamese forces con tinued their push into north‐ east Cambodia today after re porting the discovery of big food and equipment dumps.

headline: WITNESSES BACK MYLAI SERGEANT
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 17 —Three former members of the infantry company that en tered the hamlet of Mylai No. 4 more than two years ago said today that they had seen Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shoot into a group of South Vietnamese civilians. But they said they had not seen S. Sgt. David Mitchell near the ditch where the shooting occurred.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: KY IS IN COLORADO TO VISIT ACADEMY
Texan to See Hanoi Official
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (Reu ters) — Representative Robert Price, Republican of Texas, an nounced today that he planned to meet a North Vietnamese of ficial in Paris next week and was optimistic about getting in formation on American prison ers. He met the official, Nguyen Minh Vy, on Sept. 11.

headline: NIXON ASKS A RISE IN CAMBODIAN AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — President Nixon asked Congress today for a sixfold increase in economic and military assist ance for the Cambodian Gov ernment as part of an over‐all supplemental request for $1.03‐ billion more in foreign aid funds for the present fiscal year.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: GRENADE KILLS NINE AT MOVIE IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP)—A hand grenade exploded in a crowd watching a movie 20 miles northeast of Saigon last night, killing nine civilians and wounded 43 other persons, south Vietnamese military headquarters reported today.

headline: Statement at Mitchell's Trial Lays Killings to Calley
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 18— A sworn statement that ac cused First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of ordering and then helping to carry out the killing of at least 100 South Viet namese civilians was read into the record today at the court‐ martial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐G.I. Says He Witnessed Slaying of Unarmed Civilians at Mylai but Did Not See Calley
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 18—A former Army combat photographer testified today that he had seen American sol diers slay unarmed Vietnamese civilians in four separate in cidents in the alleged massacre at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Ky Greets South Vietnamese At Kansas Army College
lead_paragraph: LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 18 (AP)—Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky of South Vietnam exchanged warm greetings with 11 South Vietnamese at tending the Army Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth today.

headline: GEN. WALT CITES LESSONS OF WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — Gen. Lewis W. Walt, the assist ant commandant of the Ma ri?c Corps, today pondered the lessons of the Vietnam war, the things to bear in mind “if we were to go into this kind of war again.”

headline: FOE SAID TO SEND MORE MEN SOUTH
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — North Vietnam is sending near ly twice as many troops southward along infiltration routes in the early weeks of the dry season this year as it did in 1969, senior United States officials said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Medals System Under Study by U.S.; Many Awarded Though War Wanes
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 — The awarding of medals to United States ser vicemen has come under review here and in Washington to de termine how much represents accomplishment and how much has been allowed to lapse into procedure and public relations.
author: By Iver Peterson  Special to The New York Times

headline: DEATHS OF G.I.'S LAID TO DRUG IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP] —A large influx of highly po tent, cheap heroin in Vietnam has increased the drug‐related death rate of soldiers there, an Army official told Congress today.

headline: JURORS ON STAND IN CHICAGO 7 CASE
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 19—The con spiracy case of the Chicago Seven was returned to open court today as Judge Julius J. Hoffman began a hearing to determine whether he or any of the Federal marshals at the trial had improper communica tions with the jurors while they were deliberating.
author: By Seth S. King  Special to The New York Times

headline: LOW‐COST FLIGHTS FROM VIETNAM DUE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 —Pan American World Airways and the United Service Club, a nonprofit organization that charters flights for military personnel, disclosed today that low‐cost flights for soldiers coming home on leave from South Vietnam would begin shortly.

headline: 15 Die in Crash of Marine Rescue Copter
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP)—A United States Marine helicopter returning from a rescue mission crashed into a mountain yesterday, kill ing 15 marines, including the members of a patrol that had called for the rescue.

headline: AID TO CAMBODIA STIRS CRITICISM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 —The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed today to hold hearings on the Nixon Administration's request for $1‐billion in additional military aid. A major debate appeared to be building up over $155 million for Cambodia that was included in the request.
author: By John W. Finney  Special to The New York Times

headline: A WITNESS TELLS OF MYLAI SLAYING
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 19 — A witness testified to day that Capt. Ernest Medina shot a prostrate Vietnamese woman during the alleged Mylai massacre.
author: By Homer Bigart  Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The removal of Dr. Arnold Einhorn, Chief of Pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital for the past twelve years, from his post is deplorable.

headline: Major Medals Given By U.S. in 3 Wars
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 —Following is a list of awards and decorations from all services issued for heroism in World War 11, Korea, and Vietnam. The figures given for Vietnam are current to Oct. 1.

headline: HANOI WARNS U.S. ON AERIAL CHECKS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 19—North Viet nam warned the United States today that it would continue to oppose reconnaissance flights over its territory and the Unit ed States made it clear that it had no intention of abandon ing such flights.
author: By Henry Giniger  Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. Denies Seeing Troops Kill Civilians
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 19 —With his eves brimming with tears, S. Sgt. David Mitchell took the witness stand in his own defense today and testi fied that he had not seen Amer ican troops kill any civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Copter Pilots Disgruntled by ‘I've‐Been‐There Medals’
lead_paragraph: FORT RUCKER, Ala., Nov. 18 — Among men who had one of the most dangerous jobs in Vietnam — piloting helicopters — there are gripes and dis gruntlement about how the Army awards its medals.
author: By Robert M. Smith  Special to The New York Times

headline: MYLAI PANEL TOLD OF SHOTS AT DEAD
