lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 20 —A ditch piled with the bodies of Vietnamese men, women and children became a casual target for two American soldiers in the allegea Mylai massacre, Government witness testified today at the court‐martial of First Lieec. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: War and G.I. Morale
lead_paragraph: It was in April, 1968, that I first heard a Vietnam veteran describe seek‐and‐destroy mission as “seek‐and avoid.” He said that most of the men in his company, an infantry unit sta tioned near Danang, didn't think the war seemed “worth it” in terms of life, limb and disrupted youth. “On patrol,” lie explained “we were sup posed to go a mile and engage Charlie, right? What we did was go a hundred yards, find us some heavy foliage, smoke, rap and sack out.”
author: By Fred Gardner

headline: GUN SITES TARGET
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Saturday, Nov. 21—The Hanoi radio reported that “wave after wave” of United States bombers attacked targets in North Vietnam early today, including a prisoner of war camp where the station said there had been “a number of United States prisoner of war casualties.”

headline: Laird Links Troop Withdrawal To Funds for Aid to Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 —Secretary of. Defense Melvih R. Laird cautioned today that a Congressional refusal to pro vide $155 ‐million in military aid for Cambodia could slow American troop withdrawals from South Vietnam.
author: By Joan W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Militarism Versus Strangelove
lead_paragraph: In June of 1969 at Guam President Nixon announced the plan for reduc tions in military strength and a phased withdrawal of American armed forces from South Vietnam. America, twenty five years after the glories and vic tories of World War II, is now under taking a limited withdrawal from its aggressive policies of involvement and intervention in the affairs of nations undergoing social and political change which are not of direct concern to the security and welfare of the United States.
author: By James A. Donovan

headline: Nuremberg in Son My
lead_paragraph: The ultimate question of “guilt” in the trials of the Son My troops is how far what they did departed from gen eral American military practice in Vietnam as they had witnessed it. This may not be germane to the ques tion of legality under the Geneva Con ventions or the Articles of War. But the defense of superior orders has its true base not in technicality but in equity. It is properly invoked by the low‐ranking soldier in mitigation of punishment for conduct, even though unlawful, that is not too far removed from the behavior authorized or en couraged by his superiors.
author: By Telford Taylor

headline: G.I. IN MYLAI CASE CLEARED BY ARMY
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 20 —S. Sgt. David Mitchell, the first soldier to face court‐mar tial on charges stemming from the alleged slaughter of South Vietnamese civilians at the hamlet of Mylai 4, was ac quitted tonight by a seven member panel of officers.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Hanoi Radio reported that “wave after wave” of United States fighter bombers at tacked targets in North Vietnam early to day, including a prisoner of war camp. The station said at least three jet bombers and one helicopter had been shot down. In Washington, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird confirmed the raids in a statement. He said the bombers had struck south of the 19th parallel, in response to “attacks on our unarmed reconnaissance aircraft.” [Page 1,

headline: War and the Court
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Nov. 20—One of the great functions of the Supreme Court is to make America face basic moral and institutional problems that, long avoided, have caused fissures in the society. The Warren Court did so, notably, in its bold decisions on race and legislative apportionment.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Army Revokes Award Of Bronze Stars to Dogs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)—Army officials admit ted today that two dogs were awarded Bronze Star Medals in South Vietnam last month.

headline: Chicago Juror Recalls Deadlock Notes
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 20 — Mrs. Kay Richards Stevens, the young woman juror who be came the self‐appointed ne gotiator in the deliberations of the jury in the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, testified today that the jury notified Judge Ju lius J. Hoffman on two occa sions that it was unable to reach a verdict.
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE SURPRISED BY U.S. BOMBINGS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21—Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, deplored tonight “renewed reliance on military pressure” that he said was evident in the bombings) of North Vietnam.
author: By Paul Delaney  Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese Deserter Loathes His Life of Fear
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21—A deserter from the South Vietnamese Army has been hiding in his family's crowded house in a Saigon suburb for more than two and a half years, loathing what his life has become.
author: By Gloria Emerson  Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Delegates Assail U.S. Bombings; Hint at Boycott of Paris Peace Parley
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 21—The North Vietnamese reacted today to the American bombing of their territory with a hint that they might boycott the peace talks here.

headline: REFUGEES ACCUSE THE CAMBODIANS
lead_paragraph: POIPET, Cambodia, Nov. 15 —Vietnamese refugees at a detention center here com plain of a lack of food and say Cambodian guards attack their women.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal  Special to The New York Times

headline: MYLAI TRIALS STIR FEW IN WAR ZONE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21—A sign of the appar ent emotional exhaustion and weariness felt by many South Vietnamese and United States soldiers is the lack of interest in the trials of Americans ac cused in the alleged massacre at the hamlet of ?? 4.

headline: Navy Reports Sinking Trawler Off Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Nov. 22 (AP)—Amer ican vessels sank a trawler presumed to have been North Vietnamese, in a battle on the South China Sea as the trawl er attempted to infiltrate South Vietnam, the Navy an nounced today.

headline: VIETNAM ALLIES PLAN BOOBY TRAP REWARDS
lead_paragraph: QUANG NGAI, South Viet nam, Nov. 21 (AP)—Allied mili tary officials plan to reward civilians who report mines and booby traps along South Viet nam's north‐central coast in Quang Ngai Province, a strong hold of the Vietcong.

headline: Army Reports Officers Knew of Banon Defoliant
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21 (AP)—Several offi cers of the America] Division knew that the Pentagon had prohibited the use of a chem ical defoliant when their troops used it last summer, the United States command said today.

headline: Princeton Students and Faculty Fear Survey on Antiwar Protest
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 21—Some students and faculty members at Princeton Universi ty are opposing a survey con taining information about a demonstration last May against the Institute for Defense Anal yses, a Defense Department re search facility here.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The President and his staff turned their ener gies last week to the business of government and away from the exigencies of partisan politics, which have preoccupied them for so long. The change brought an odd sense of quiet and order —and even reconciliation—to the White House; but the effects were felt in Congress, the Cabi net and beyond.

headline: College‐Level Vocational Schools Boom
lead_paragraph: OKMULGEE, Okla., Nov. 19 —Only 20 per cent of Ameri can youths today graduate from college with a four‐year degree or better. Bill Risner, a wiry, 24‐year‐old Vietnam veteran with short brown hair, a shy manner and a Marine Corps bulldog tattooed on his right arm, is one of the other 80 per cent.
author: By William K. Stevens Special to The New York Times

headline: 26 ARRESTED HERE IN ANTIWAR MARCH
lead_paragraph: Twenty‐six demonstrators were arrested yesterday after noon when they crossed police barricades in zn act of civil disobedience following a rally against genocide.”

headline: RADICALS GATHER TO ‘FUSE CULTURE
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, Nov. 21—They chanted “Om” for the love of Allen. They watched films of the American bombings in North Vietnam. While babies and leashless dogs scampered in and out of a packed room, they were exhorted to avoid “radical theatrical funk” be cause “wearing a beret doesn't make you Ohe Guevara.”

headline: Ky:
lead_paragraph: Two months ago the projected Washington appearance by South Vietnam's Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky at a right‐wing “March for Victory” rally brought pro tests from hawks as well as doves. The election‐eve trip was postponed only after the Nixon Administration's private remon strations were followed by Vice President Agnew's public warn ing that the visit would not “serve a useful purpose.”

headline: REGULAR FLIGHTS MADE OVER NORTH
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 —American jet fighters equipped for high‐speed reconnaissance have been flying over North Vietnam almost daily in the two years since the bombing halt was announced.

headline: 2 Factories in Saigon Are Producing 5 Cars a Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam, Nov. 21 (UPI)—The Vietnamese have begun producing their own automobile. The jeep‐like veh icle, called the Dalat after a resort city in the Central High lands, is made in cooperation with Citroën of France.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: American planes yesterday ended their one‐day bombing of North Vietnam. De fense Secretary Laird said the raids had been authorized to destroy antiaircraft in stallations that have been shooting at Amer ican reconnaissance planes, but there were strong indications that a principal aim was the destruction of war stocks. American officials disputed reports from North Viet nam that targets in the Hanoi‐Haiphong area, well north of the 19th parallel, had been hit. [Page 1, Columns 6‐8.]

headline: Report From Hanoi Says U.S. Bombs Shake City
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 21—Hanoi shook today from the blast of bombs only 25 miles away as United States aircraft carried out raids start ing at 2:30 A.M.

headline: Mylai G.I., Freed, Will Make the Army A Lifetime Career
lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, TEX., Nov. 21 (UPI)—S. Sgt.David Mitchell, his right hand smoothing the two neat rows of medals clipped to his green wool Army tunic, said today he wanted to be a soldier for life.

headline: Bombs Over North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The American bombing raids against North Vietnam this weekend must inevitably arouse concern both over the nature and the significance of the raids.

headline: NEW U.S. POSITION
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: It Tolls for Thee
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Nov. 22—George Orwell could not have improved on Defense Secretary Laird's phrasing in the an nouncement of renewed American bombing in North Vietnam. There was not even any bombing in it—just “protective reaction strikes.” They had been made against “missile and anti aircraft gun sites and related facili ties” in response to “attacks on our unarmed reconnaissance planes.” It all sounded so clean and just.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Indications mounted in Washington yes terday that a main reason for the weekend bombing of targets in North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia was to block offensives ex pected throughout Indochina in the coming months. Administration officials said that they would not rule out similar air strikes at areas in Laos and Cambodia containing concentrations of enemy soldiers and sup plies. [Page 1, Column 8.]

headline: GOODELL INDICATES HE MAY QUIT PARTY
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Goodell indicated yesterday that he might leave the Republican party if the Nixon Administra tion continues a, practice of “reading out” liberals from the G.O.P.

headline: Details of Raids Kept Secret in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 22—The United States command has imposed an al most total blackout on infor mation about the American air raids against North Vietnam yesterday, including routine details normally made public after similar raids in the past.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Wedding: Family Matter
Raids Reported in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. 22 (AP)— American bombers turned to targets in Laos and Cambodia today after major raids in North Vietnam.

headline: Nixon's Game Plan: New Faces, New Ideas and New Programs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21— This is half‐time in the Nixon Administration, even though a weary Congress is still on the field, running out the clock on 1970. President Nixon, not un like the coach of a tiring squad, has withdrawn from partisan conflict to develop what is widely called a new game plan for the second half of his term, starting in January.
author: By Max Frankel; Special to The New York Times

headline: INDOCHINA RAIDS SAID TO BE AIMED AT FOE'S BUILD‐UP
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 — There were increasing indica tions today that the big United States air strikes against North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia this weekend were ordered by President Nixon to deter the enemy from offensives through out Indochina in the coming months.
author: By Tad Szulc; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. RESCUE FORCE LANDED WITHIN 23 MILES OF HANOI, BUT IT FOUND P.O.W.'S GONE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird disclosed today that a small task force of Army and Air Force men landed about 23 miles west of Hanoi over the weekend in an unsuccessful at tempt to free American prison ers thought to be held at a camp there.
author: By William Beecher; Special to The New York Times

headline: Victory Through Air Power?
lead_paragraph: There is now good reason to believe that the wide spread weekend air assault on North Vietnam repre sented an effort to block a new Communist build‐up South Vietnam through American air power and did not simply constitute a “protective reaction,” as billed.

headline: Normal Operations Resumed By U.S. Planes in Indochina
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. 23—American aerial warfare over Indochina resumed its normal course to day, with United States jet strikes reported against sus pected enemy positions in Cam bodia, Laos and South Vietnam, and reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam to assess the results of Saturday's raids.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Text of Pentagon News Conference on U.S. Rescue Mission Into North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: I want to give you now the details of the only opera tion that took place north of the 19th Parallel this past weekend.

headline: Fulbright Committee Asks Explanation for Air Raids
author: By Tad Szulc; Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon and the Rescue Mission
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 — There is a single threat of con cern that binds together every one of President Nixon's spec tacular military ventures in Vietnam this year: his anxiety about the consequences of the American withdrawal.
author: By Max Frankel; Special to The New York Times

headline: PEACE TALKS OFF WEEK IN PROTEST
lead_paragraph: CHOISY‐LE‐ROI, France Nov. 23— North Vietnam and the Vietcong said today that they would not attend this Wednes day's scheduled session of the Vietnam peace talks to protest the American air attacks on North Vietnam last weekend.
author: By Eric Pace; Special to The New York Times

headline: A HOFFMAN ORDER TO JURY RECALLED
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 23—A Fed eral deputy marshal, Ronald Dobroski, testified today that he had taken a note from the Chicago conspiracy jury to Judge Julius J. Hoffman during the jury's deliberations and had been ordered by the judge to tell the jurors to continue their deliberations.
author: By Seth S. King; Special to The New York Times

headline: A Girl in Saigon Gives Christmas Her Own Touch
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23—A small Vietnamese girl in pajamas, who has no idea of what Dec. 25 means to others, is a sudden reminder of Christmas on a noisy Saigon street.
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet View of Raids Termed Relatively Mild
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW. Nov. 23—The Soviet Union reacted official ly today to the latest Ameri can bombing raids over North Vietnam with a statement affirming support for Hanoi but avoiding direct involve ment.

headline: French Newsman Sees
Thant Terms U.S. Raids ‘Disturbing Development’
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Nov. 23—Secretary Thant to day said that American air strikes against North Vietnam over the weekend were “a dis turbing development.”

headline: U.S. Information on P.O.W.'s Appears Limited
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23— Conversations with Administra tion officials suggest that the information the United States has on American prisoners of war in North Vietnam is lim ited and imprecise.
author: By Neil Sheehan; Special to The New York Times

headline: Two Mylai Witnesses Say Citations Were False
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov 2.3 —Two key Government wit nesses at the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley, Jr. stated under cross‐examina tion today that the decorations they received for rescuing chil dren during the alleged Mylai massacre were based on false citations. One of the two further said he was an occasional user of marijuana.
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Transcript of Senate Committee Hearing on P.O.W. Rescue Effort
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the transcript of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's open hearing Washington yesterday on the rescue mission in North Vietnam as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News. Among those questioning Secretory of Defense Melvin R. Laird were Senators J. W. Fulbright, Frank Church and Claiborne Pell, Democrats, and Georce Aiken. Republican.

headline: Ky Says He's an ‘Ex‐Hawk Turned Dove’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 — Nguyen Cao Ky, South Viet nam's often controversial Vice President, pictured himself to day as a misunderstood mod erate, “an ex ‐ hawk turned dove,” whose primary interest is in ending the fighting that has wracked his country for 20 Years.
author: By Terence Smith; Special to The New York Times

headline: 17 DEAD IN VIETNAM AS AIRCRAFT COLLIDE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (AP)—A helicopter carrying South Vietnamese troops col lided today with a light United States plane in the Mekong Delta 80 miles south of Saigon.

headline: U.S. Marshal in Chicago 7 Trial Recalls Only One Deadlock Bid
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 24— Under persistent questioning by a de fense attorney, Deputy Federal Marshal Ronald Dobroski said today that the jury in the con spiracy trial of the Chicago Seven had sent only one dead lock message during five days of deliberations and this had been sent on Saturday, the day the deliberations began.

headline: TV Review
lead_paragraph: As a sequel if not an answer to Channel 13's re cent controversial program on “Schoolhouse or Jail house,” the noncommercial outlet offered 90 minutes last night under the title of “Schools Can Work.” The value of the program was that it underscored the fact that in a complicated urban school system no one has a single pat answer to all the system's problems. Not prin cipals, Board of Education officials teachers, parents, students or bystanders.

headline: Vietcong Using Different Name For Shadow Regime in the South
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 24—The Vietcong “shadow government” apparently has changed its name from the Provisional revo lutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam to the Government of the Re public of South Vietnam.
author: By Tillman Durdin; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Court Backs Discharge For Antiwar Navy Officer
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 24 (AP)— A young Navy officer who signed a petition to the Penta gon objecting to the war in Vietnam is getting his discharge by order of a Federal judge.

headline: Windows at Stanford Broken In a Vietnam Bombing Protest
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP)—Rock‐throwing demon strators broke 49 windows at Stanford University last night in a protest against the United States bombing of North Viet nam last weekend.

headline: Another Spasm in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: PARIS—The peace negotiations in Paris have changed very little during the past eighteen months but the war in Indochina has. Nothing confirmed this fact more strikingly than last weekend's U. S. air raids on the North.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: LAIRD WOULD SEEK BOMBING IF ENEMY BREACHED‘ACCORD’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he would recommend to President Nixon the resumption of full‐scale air attacks on North Vietnam if the enemy engaged in major violations of a tacit understand ing with the United States that halted the bombing two years ago.
author: By Tad Szulc; Special to The New York Times

headline: TRIAL OF CALLEY TOLD OF STRAFING
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 24— A former helicopter gun ship pilot testified today that he saw Vietnamese civilians cut down by strafing as they streamed in paic out of Mylai 4 on the morning of the alleged “massacre,” March 16, 1968.
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: Pope Plans Vietnam Plea on Trip
lead_paragraph: ROME, Nov. 24— Vatican in formants said today that Pope Paul VI was planning to broad cast an appeal for a negotiated peace in Vietnam and Cam bodia when his plane passes over or near Indochina Friday.
author: By Paul Hofmann; Special to The New York Times

headline: TWO BRING LETTERS FROM 320 P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: Two American lawyers who were in Hanoi during the Amer ican attempt last weekend to rescue prisoners of war said here yesterday that they had brought back letters from 320 of the known 339 prisoners.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: New Strategy in Vietnam

headline: LAIRD REVEALS U.S. PLANNED TO KEEP CAMP RAID SECRET
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Nixon Administration disclosed the commando raid last Satur day on the empty prisoner‐of war camp in North Vietnam to avoid a “credibility problem” with the American public.

headline: U.S. BOMBERS STRIKE FOE'S SUPPLY ROUTES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 25 (AP)—The United States command said today that bomb ing by B25's and fighter‐bomb ers continued today against North Vietnamese supply routes in Laos and Cambodia and that reconnaissance operations were conducted over North Vietnam.

headline: TAXPAYER LOSES BID TO FIGHT WAR FUNDS
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals here held yesterday that Walter G. Pietsch, of Rego Park, Queens, could not bring a court challenge to the right of Congress to authorize funds for the war in Vietnam just because he is a taxpayer.

headline: Hoffman Sets Tomorrow For Trial Recollections
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Nov. 25 — Judge Julius J. Hoffman decided today that he needed more time to study the Chicago conspiracy trial record before placing into the appeal record his recollec tions of any communications he might have had with the jury.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: International Defense Secretary Laird told the House Committee on Foreign Affairs yesterday that the Government had not “necessarily” planned to disclose the commando raid Fri day on an empty prisoner‐of‐war camp in North Vietnam. He said the news had been made public to avoid a “credibility prob lem” after North Vietnam had reported air raids near Hanoi. [Page 1, Column 5.]

headline: Psychiatrist Says ‘Brutalizing’ Vietnam War Causes Problems for Ex‐G.I.'s
author: By Richard Halloran; Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD CHALLENGED ON DEAD P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25— The head of an antiwar group accused Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today of hav ing distorted for political pur poses information on American prisoners in North Vietnam that the group has been pro viding.
author: By Neil Sheehan; Special to The New York Times

headline: Pope, on Eve of Trip to East, Says He Will Be a ‘Fisher of Men’
lead_paragraph: ROME, Nov. 25—Pope Paul VI, on the eve of the longest journey he has undertaken dur ing his pontificate, stressed again today that he would be traveling as a bishop, pastor, missionary and “fisher of men.”
author: By Paul Hofmann; Special to The New York Times

headline: Foreign Relations Committee Meets Congenially With Ky
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) —Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam met today with some of the United States Senate's harshest critics of the Vietnam ,war and of the Saigon Government.

headline: Hanoi Charges U.S. Bombers Killed 49 Civilians During Raids
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP)—North Vietnam charged today that United States war planes killed at least 49 North Vietnamese civilians —including 28 in one restaurant and six in a hospital—during the air raids last Saturday.

headline: How P.O.W. Camp Raid Was Planned
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25— The planners of the comman do raid on a North Vietnam ese prison camp last weekend had to take into account the position of the moon and So viet satellites and to gather men from all over the world.
author: By William Beecher; Special to The New York Times

headline: Representatives Urge Use Of Secret Mylai Testimony
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 25 (UPI) — A group of Repre sentatives urged today that secret Congressional testimony concerning the alleged Mylai 4 massacre be turned over to the Fort Benning military tri bunal hearing the court martial of First Lieut William L. Calley Jr.

headline: Thant Makes Appeal
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 — Secretary General Thant renewed his appeal to North Vietnam today to permit the Red Cross or other appro priate humanitarian organiza tions to see American war pris oners. He made a similar plea last February.

headline: News Trip to Carriers In Tonkin Gulf Canceled
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP) — The Navy canceled this morn ing a planned visit by news men to aircraft carriers in the Gulf of Tonkin.

headline: Tokyo Court Bars Ouster Of Protester From Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 25 (AP) — Miss Barbara Bye of Brooklyn, who has been confined to her hotel room at Tokyo's Haneda Airport for 26 days because immigration authorities sought to prevent her entry, may not be deported summarily, the Tokyo. Appellate Court ruled today.

headline: CHRISTMAS LETTERS FOR P.O.W.'S SOUGHT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) —A nationwide drive is under way to collect 100 tons of mail for a Christmas display of con cern for missing and captive United States servicemen in Southeast Asia.

headline: Saigon Slum Girl Meets Her Father, African President
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Re public. Nov. 26 (AP)— Until last week, 17‐year‐old Martine sold cigarettes on the streets of Saigon in South Vietnam and lived in a shack built with flat tened beer cans. Today, she is the daughter of a President and riding in a limousine.

headline: MAN WITH A KNIFE CHARGES AT POPE IN MANIA AIRPORT
lead_paragraph: MANILA, Friday, Nov. 27—A 35‐year‐old Bolivan who identi fied himself as a surrealist painter and a foe of hypocrisy and superstition hurled himself, brandishing a knife, toward Pope Paul VI at Manila Air port this morning. The Pope was unhurt and apparently un touched.
author: By Henry Kamm; Special to The New York Times

headline: Raid on a P.O.W. Camp: Build‐Up—and Letdown
author: By Robert M. Smith; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. WAR DEATHS AT 65 FOR WEEK
Bombing the Peace Talks
lead_paragraph: Nowhere has air power failed so significantly to win a war as in Viet nam. Not only has air power failed to win here, it has failed, at great cost, to accomplish its most specific missions: to interdict enemy supply lines, to weaken the enemy's capac ity and will to resist.
author: By David Schoenbrun

headline: HANOI INSISTS U.S. HIT FAR IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 26—North Viet nam continued to insist today that American bombers ranged far north of the 19th Parallel last Saturday and Sunday, and a spokesman here said that 49 civilians had died in the raids and 40 had been wounded. The Hanoi radio gave the same fig ures in a broadcast earlier today.
author: By Henry Giniger; Special to The New York Times

headline: 45 of 229 Die in Crash Of Vietnam‐Bound Plane
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 27 — A DC‐8 jetliner carrying 229 per sons, most of them military per sonnel bound for Vietnam, crashed and exploded during take‐off tonight, killing 45 per sons.

headline: Queens Man Says He Plans To Take War Suit Higher
lead_paragraph: A Queens man whose chal lenge to the constitutionality of the war in Vietnam was re jected Wednesday by the United States Court of Appeals said yesterday he planned to carry his case to the Supreme Court.

headline: F.B.I. REPORTS PLOT BY ANTIWAR GROUP TO KIDNAP U.S. AIDE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — A militant antiwar group led by two Roman Catholic priests is plotting to kidnap a White House aide or other public of ficial, J. Edgar Hoover, direc tor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.
author: By Fred P. Graham; Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 1 — No Title
U.S. SAYS PLANES HIT HANOI REGION TO COVER MISSION
author: By Tad Szulc; Special to The New York Times

headline: Parts of Pnompenh's Defenses Reported Shattered by Enemy
JAPANESE REPORT U.S. PLAN TO CUT FORCES BY 12,000
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 28— The United States is contemplating a major reduction of its forces in Japan, partly for budgetary reasons and partly to carry out President Nixon's policy of reducing American military in volvement in Asia, informed sources said here today.
author: By Takashi Oka; Special to The New York Times

headline: Trick by a Suspicious Sergeant Turns lip Vietcong Supporters
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Whither Vietnamization?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of seeming quiescence in Vietnam, the news last week of new bombing raids and a derring‐do attempt to rescue prisoners of war in the North raised once again a question that is too often forgotten. Where is Vietnamization taking us?
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Pope Cautions Asia on Militant Atheism
lead_paragraph: MANILA, Sunday, Nov. 29— Pope Paul VI in a broadcast “message to Asia” today warned the continent against what he termed militant and aggressive atheism.
author: By Paul Hofmann; Special to The New York Times

headline: Missions to Save Pilots Downed in Indochina More Complex Than P.O.W. Camp Raid
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: P.O.W. Camp Raiders Honored At the Half in Army‐Navy Game
lead_paragraph: The leading participants in the American raid Nov. 21 on an American prisoner‐of‐war camp near Hanoi were honored yesterday during half‐time cere monies at the Army‐Navy game in Philadelphia.
author: By Paul L. Montgomery

headline: A ‘Little Vatican’ on the Move Aids Traveling Pontiff
lead_paragraph: MANILA, Nov. 28—A few hours after the attempt on the life of Pope Paul VI by a dagger‐wielding Bolivian at Manila airport yesterday, mes sages of good wishes for the Pontiff started flowing in here from kings, presidents, religious leaders and private admirers all over the world.

headline: 79, Mostly Vietnamese, Missing on U.S. Plane
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Nov. 29 (AP) — A United States Air Force trans port carrying 73 South Viet namese and six American crewmen has been missing for three days, the U.S. com mand said today.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
Vietnam Bombing By U.S. Is Assailed At Talks in Sweden
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 28— The bombing of North Vietnam last weekend was condemned as “a new U.S. crime of aggression” at a world conference on Viet nam, Laos and Cambodia that opened here today.

headline: Television This Week
lead_paragraph: TODAY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 29

headline: A Matter of Credibility
lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Laird says the Administration decided to publicize the commando raid on an empty prisoner‐of‐war camp near Hanoi because of “a certain problem of credibility in our society.” But nearly every thing connected with this brilliantly executed but none theless abortive mission—especially the official explana tions and claims for it—is likely to widen that home‐front credibility gap.

headline: Vietnam:
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Except for the outcome, it was as Ameri can as John Wayne. President Nixon preferred the metaphor of football, meaning that when you're in trouble you aim for surprise; players call it going for the long one, throwing the bomb.

headline: Raid on P.O.W. Camp in Delta Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 30 (AP)—United States‐South Vietnamese raid ing party attacked a Vietcong prison camp in a bamboo grove in South Vietnam's Mekong Delta and freed 19 Vietnamese, the United States Navy an nounced today.

headline: FULBRIGHT SEES PENTAGON TAKING TOP POLICY ROLE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — Senator J. W. Fulbright charged today that the Defense Department had displaced the State Department as the pri mary formulator of American foreign policy, particularly in Southeast Asia.
author: By Terence Smith; Special to The New York Times

headline: Sontay Raid: Was It a Violation?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29—The wide publicity given the daring but fruitless attempt to free American prisoners in North Vietnam has virtually sub merged the questions of whether that raid — and the massive American bombing that coin cided with it—violated Presi dent Johnson's understanding with Hanoi about ending the bomb ing of the North. Privately, officials in the Nixon Ad ministration mar vel at the ability of Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird to divert public attention from that issue and to put senatorial critics of the bombing on the defensive.
author: By Hedrick Smith; Special to The New York Times

headline: BREZHNEV VOICES HOPES FOR BERLIN AND MIDDLE EAST
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 29—Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, expressed optimism today about the chances for a Middle East settlement and for a Big Four accord on Berlin.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman; Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Re‐escalating the Vietnam War
